Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: What amazes me about the latest epic 'Marvel' Comics movie is how many things go right.  With the ensemble of so many superheroes placed on one screen:  [Captain America, (Evans); Black Widow, (Johansson); Iron Man, (Downey, Jr.); The Incredible Hulk, (Ruffalo); Thor, (Hemsworth); and Hawkeye (Renner)]; the results easily could have been a cluttered mess.  Instead, nearly all the necessary elements are properly placed.  First of all, the menace of Thor's brother, Loki (Hiddleston), and his army of gothic extraterrestrials provides enough peril to keep all the mighty guardians on the ropes for substantial stretches of the film.  The second element is keeping the mood intact.  'The Avengers' gets campy in plenty of places, yet stays serious enough to sustain its suspense.  How a movie juggles these two mood swings can easily make or break it.  ('Star Wars' is the supreme example of stellar success; while 'Armageddon' remains a prime contender as one of the worst juggling acts.) Between the nimble work of Screenwriter/Director, Joss Whedon, (with screenwriter, Zak Penn) and editors (Ford and Lassek), the film seldom loses a step or its nerve.  Added to that Samuel L. Jackson, as helmsman Nick Fury, the story stabilizes and prevents the exposition from becoming cloudy or long-winded.One of the ingenious elements found in the fray is the chemistry of characters and the interplay of their indomitable egos.  Front in center for both the banter and suspense is top ego, 'Iron Man' (Oddly, one of the few icons who relies on human invention rather than on superhuman strength.) played by Downey, who by his talent and the usual snappy script, propels the entertainment to its best heights.  However, "The Incredible Hulk" (played by an unusually fragile Ruffalo) goes closest to the precipice of danger, providing an unstable danger to the core team.  In an unusual twist, these superheroes are at such odds with each other, the threat of their enemies remains elusive until they can get their act together.The plot is perhaps the lesser player next to the clashing arcade.  Loki who is the incorrigible demi god (and brother Thor's alter ego) has an insatiable desire to subjugate everyone on planet earth.  Using the forbidden, frozen substance used in the film 'Thor,' Loki and his henchmen seek to change and control mankind with this power and convert mankind by servile fear.While 'The Avengers' is nearly pitch perfect entertainment, not all of the conflicts and dialogue succeeds.  While I loved and admired all the wonderful, escapist elements the movie offers, it lacked some of the overall quality found in recent 'Marvel' offerings.  It doesn't match the perfection of the first 'Iron Man,' the poignancy of 'Thor,' nor the cohesiveness of 'Captain America: The First Avenger'. A comparison with comic book classics such as 'The Dark Knight,' 'Spiderman 2,' or the splendor of the first two 'Superman' movies, and this film surely falls short. (Although I certainly admired how they wove all the recent 'Marvel' movies so seamlessly together--another tell-tale sign that this movie could have easily been a disaster!)But where `The Avengers' succeeds, it does so in spades.  As perfect popcorn entertainment, 'The Avengers' gets it right--good enough to spend your extra dollars for 3D or I-Max, and enough for people with home entertainment centers to be extra grateful during Thanksgiving or another part of the holiday season when this film will undoubtedly come out on DVD.

reviewText: You will be very unlikely to run into anybody this weekend(or the next couple of weeks for that matter)who didn't like "The Avengers",the superhero movie to end all superhero movies.I would be slow to call it a masterpiece,but it's so likable and action-packed that in my opinion,it comes damn close.Director Joss Whedon lets you know that he was the right one to bring this $220 million superhero powerhouse to the big screen,and his cast dosen't dissapoint either.From my standpoint,Robert Downey,Jr.,Chris Evans,and Mark Ruffalo give the best performances in the film(Downey espicially,since his last outing as Iron Man was so downright full of himself to the point of nauseam).He takes a step back and down from his pedestal to be a team player.Evans as Captain America(who is my all-time #1 superhero)brings us a Steve Rogers who is still out of his own place and time,but always ready to jump into action when the situation and movie calls for it.Ruffalo downplays the scientist with an angry green-man complex role so much that he seems to not be trying all that hard to bring it across(not that he needs to,of course).Chris Hemsworth was actually better in this film as the god of thunder Thor,than he was in his own film last year.Renner,Johanssen,Jackson,Gregg,and last but not least Hiddleston as the uber-baddie god of mischief Loki are all excellent in their own scenes (with or without the avengers).Bottom Line-GO SEE THIS MOVIE AND ENJOY EVERY SINGLE MOMENT OF IT!!!.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: You've already seen the Avengers and that's ok.You've seen it in every other Marvel movie yet released.  You've definitely seen the finale, and even the McGuffin, because they took it straight from the first Transformers movie.  The Avengers is great fun, but it's fading from memory faster than who won last season's American Idol.While fans of Joss Whedon will likely be pleased, I think his victory with the Avengers is a double edged sword.  He carefully corrals the thicket of big names here, but in the process we're stuck with a laundry list of cliche scenes, a very weak villain, dialog that exists purely to waste time and characters who rely far too much on their costume to get them through the movie.One can't shake the feeling, no matter whose names appear as writers, the Avengers smacks of committee construction.  Excluding Sam Jackson, most of what is here is by the numbers.  There are precious few moments of humanity in a story that should be overflowing with it.  In this respect,  think this movie is a polar opposite of Ang Lee's HULK.  A film that was painfully boring, but also full of human touches - it had a style that could have been robbed like a gold mine to add more character in the place of the dreadful and endless expository dialog exchanges before we're shuttled to the MIchael Bay Transformers action scenes we've seen a thousand times by this point.But is it bad?  Heck no.  The Avengers is ultimately a good time if you can settle for less.  There are no motivations for anything in the film other than to recycle everything that's already been done and play it safe to please an audience.  Yes, you've seen the Avengers already, but that's ok.B-
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: In addition to being an excellent adaptation of the Marvel Comics Strip adventures, this feature winds a fabulous yarn that leads to the creation of the TV series currently airing on ABC as Agents of SHIELD. The cast of the feature film does not overlap TV series beyond one part literally 'resurrected' from the film, however, the same fascination with Super Heroes aka normal humans who discover/develop super-skills is key to the drama.As always, Robert Downey, Jr., receives top billing and is prominent in the portrayal of Iron Man... Samuel Jackson does the role of Nick Fury justice but, the characters doe not reappear in the TV series; nor does Hawkeye, Hulk, Black Widow, Thor, or Captain America. It is the relatively minor part of Agent Phil Coulson, acted by Clark Gregg, that returns to small screen as team leader and organizer of the Agents of SHIELD.All in all, the film stands by itself as a decent adaptation... with thrills, special effects and drama enough to pull off a major coup for Marvel Comics... and lead to the television series.
summary: Rediscover the Roots of Agents of Shield TV series

reviewText: I bought this movie specifically for the 3D effects. Very disappointing. I have several IMAX 3D blu ray discs at home and their 3D effects are just amazing. Most stores use them to showcase their 3D TV's. So, I use that as a standard when comparing 3D blu ray discs.Well, this movie falls way short of that standard. It appears to be a 2D movie converted to 3D, as opposed to being originally filmed in 3D. As a result, the 3D effects don't "pop" out of the screen as much. There's definitely no WOW factor. I enjoyed the movie, but was very disappointed with the 3D effects. If you like this movie, save your money and just buy the 2D version.Would have given it a better rating than 3 stars if it had better 3D.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I'm not fond of superhero movies. By definition a superhero is near indestructible and the final outcome inevitable. So to succeed with a super hero movie requires super creative writing. Fortunately for "The Avengers" the script focuses on the human element - our weaknesses, our egos and ultimately our strengths. In short our heroes need to become more than the sum of their super powers. Everything about this film worked for me. The script is fast moving, clever, witty and entertaining, allowing all the superheroes some quality time in this movie. The director (Joss Whedon) is simply masterful. By comparison I watched, back-to-back, the last outing of the the Transformer series of film - The Avengers is a better film in every department.Nit-picking is always fun however. Notice the helicarrier has a flight deck that terminates directly over one of the lift fans. Can you imagine the down draft that creates for departing / arriving aircraft?

reviewText: I'd rank this movie up there with The Dark Knight and Spider-Man 2 as the most "true to comics feeling" that you'll ever see on the big screen. As a kid growing up I loved the Avengers, and the way this movie played out is exactly as I envisioned them fighting it out as I read the comics as a kid. It was like watching your childhood fantasies realized, in comic book form.This movie could have been a mess. Meshing 6-7+ different characters together is a huge challenge but Joss Whedon pulls it off. Using Nick Fury and SHIELD as the glue, they gather up all the heroes to stop a crisis without ever crossing that campy or uncomfortable line. The actors and writers did their part by adding some strong back-and-forth repartee between them that will cause some laughs as well as some "I can't believe he said that" moments. The action scenes are top notch, most of them true to the comics and the final flurry of an action scene that ends the movie will leave you in awe, wishing for more.The negatives about this film are few but there are some. The film slows down significantly in the middle, with a lot of dialogue and not a whole lot else going on...maybe they were just building up to the last scene but at times it felt like the movie kind of dragged on a bit before it got good again. Also the main villain seems to be Loki but he actually takes a rather large back seat to the invading aliens, which kind of take over the movie at the end. It was disappointing to not see Loki really put up a fight, especially towards the end....I know he is the trickster god and manipulation is his game (and there are elements of that), but it would have been nice to see him do a bit more here than just take a break for large parts of the movie.Still, despite those things, this was a movie that once I saw it at the theaters, I knew I had to own it on DVD. I can only hope the second one is better, as the build-up has already begun (Iron Man 3 is out at the time of this posting), and the proposed villain revealed at the end of this movie left a lot of us drooling for more.
summary: One of the best superhero movies ever made
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Look, on an average caper, let's say some mad scientist trying to take over the world with some big-time one- size- fits- all invention and is just missing one little exotic thing, or some bad guys, maybe a drug cartel, are trying to dope up the world, and want an exclusive, unencumbered franchise or, maybe , some guy, some off- the- wall political guy, who never heard of Hitler or Tojo and who runs a place like Ruthenia wants to flex his muscle and exercise his army,  you only really need one larger than life super-hero, max. But when they, the aliens (from outer space or maybe just Moslems or something), want to come to the good green earth and take it over, then wait a minute, then you better call on the services of every super-hero who still draws, or is still capable of drawing, breath, no question. Guys like Agent so and so, the dishy gymnast flip dame with the Russian name, Captain America, Thor, Iron Man, guys with big thrust arrows, and hell, even the Hulk for some beef so they, those aliens know, or show be on notice to know, that there is going to be hell to pay if someone other than earthlings want to wantonly exploit the earth 's resources.And that little idea, that little band of brave brothers and sisters (and their support structure) saving the day against some neurotic Loki from who knows where and his mercenary army ready to proclaim himself king of the hill is what drives this very long, action- packed film. Of course, like in all professions, professions that have super-stars anyway, the collective does not gel right off so there is the usual bickering and working at cross-purposes before everybody gets on the team. And then watch out because no way is some half-mad Loki (and some kin to Thor, of all people) going to take his massive, seemingly never-ending and well-equipped army against the good folks of New Jack City (hey, haven't those citizens had enough lately why not pick on say, Charleston , South Carolina or some place like that) without a fight to the finish, And there you have it. Oh, except this thought, if the American government hired this little heroic band then that seven hundred billion defense budget could be reduced to the price of airfare and a new change of clothes. Watch this one while waiting out a snowstorm like I did.
summary: Out In Super-Hero Be-Bop American Night

reviewText: I can live without Captain America and Thor -- even in the comics they were never my favorite superheroes, which is why I never followed The Avengers -- but I'm a sucker for Iron Man, particularly as inhabited by Robert Downey Jr., an absolute cinematic treasure. The movie is worth watching just for Downey's snarky performance. Some of the other actors seem like tree trunks compared to the effortless vibrancy that Downey brings to his role.The action scenes are plentiful and well-constructed, the special effects are special, but what I really like about The Avengers is the script. The decision to have superheroes sniping at each other until they had a reason to come together was inspired. Joss Whedon's dialog is snappy, smart, funny, and occasionally inspiring. Okay, what I also like is the chance to look at Scarlett Johansson and Gwyneth Paltrow, but their sensuality is sadly downplayed in favor of high-tech gear and explosions. Still, watching the Hulk pummel Loki almost makes up for the waste of two wonderful actresses.
summary: A smart script and Robert Downey Jr. make this movie a success

reviewText: I finally watched the Avengers, and I don't really know what to say. Ruffalo was excellent as Banner/the Hulk (best Hulk so far), Evans really IS Captain America (I wasn't so sure with the first movie), I have accepted Hemsworth as Thor (and he did a fine job here), Downey Jr. (what can you say besides the fact that he was born to play Stark/Iron Man, don't think anyone else could pull it off and still have the movie magic seen here), I even think Jeremy Renner turned out to be a good casting choice for Hawkeye (get a costume on him, maybe not in the comic's purple, but with the horned mask). I was not thrilled with Scarlett Johansson as Black Widow (she looked bored or like she wished she was somewhere else), and though I usually like her, it didn't work in this situation. Cobie Smulders was a nice surprise and loved her as Agent Hill. The rest of the cast were fine (Sam Jackson is going to be Sam Jackson, and it's too late to bitch, he is cemented in the Nick Fury role), it was great to see Harry Dean Stanton discover Banner in a pile of Hulk induced rubble, and while some people have been negative, Tom Hiddleston is perfectly smarmy as Loki. Unfortunately, Gwyneth was looking a little rough this time around (sorry, but it's true) as compared to her Pepper Potts from the first Iron Man. Oh my Lord, she was absolutely stunning/radiant/perfect in that one!The biggest congratulations go to Joss Whedon, though. I've been a fan of all of his work since the first episode of Buffy my girlfriend made me watch back in 1998. Joss really gets his characters to interact well with each other emotionally, and his timing and snappy dialogue are always spot-on. There are still scenes from Buffy that I need Kleenex to get through, just one  example is Spike comforting Buffy after her mother dies (although he was coming to kill her, he sees her crying and sits down and asks her what's wrong, then pats her on the shoulder). I am glad Joss is signed on for the second Avengers movie, because he really pulled off a difficult task in this one. Unlike the X-Men or Fantastic Four (sorry for even mentioning Reid Richards & Co.), who all lived in the same place and/or had commonalities as either mutants or people bombarded by galactic radiation, the Avengers is a motley group of completely different superheroes from different times, dimensions, backgrounds, etc. I wasn't sure how Whedon would do with the massive action scenes because he always had to do things on such a small scale and budget before this, but my worries were unfounded as the action was very well done. All in all a thoroughly enjoyable film.Some superhero movies have really become quite good since Sam Raimi raised the bar with the first two Spider-Man outings. They, along with X-Men: First Class, DC Comics' Dark Knight trilogy, and this, The Avengers, have all been wonderful. Love feeling like a kid again when I watch a movie! Marvel Studios, I have a whole pile of suggestions for new adaptations that don't involve Ben Affleck or Daredevil..

reviewText: Of course I wanted to like this, and going in, I was confident that it would be a five star blast. But from the first scene on, I had the alarming sense that something was badly wrong. Yes, it is the best reproduction of an action comic on screen, but aside from the verbal sparring, I don't see anything here that tops something like X2 (beyond the superfighting). I can understand how lovers of the source material would adore this movie, but please don't expect any more than that. Don't be confused by Nolan's films or Whedon's pedigree (or the fanboy love) into anticipating genuine drama, story intrigue (or coherence) from a movie constructed around a string of powers fights.I had wanted to say that this was the best movie that could have been delivered under the intense fan-service constraints imposed on its creators. But (after seeing it four times and falling asleep twice) I can't. This isn't The Dark Night. There's a huge amount of enjoyable detail here that improves over the earlier movies in this franchise, but there are many elements that still seem ham handed. Some examples:* The first post-credits scene has Black Widow escaping from bondage; an awesome scene in the trailer. This is undercut in the movie by revealing that her captors already know her identity and that they have essentially surrendered. Fighting her way out of a chair is cool in itself, and the movie seems to be satisfied with that & unconcerned that the setup lowers the dramatic stakes. Before the fight begins, she is presented as neither vulnerable nor in peril.* The entire plot of the movie (before its interminable climax) turns out to be an elaborate scheme to unleash a monster from among the good guys. We never find out exactly why this is Loki's scheme (except in the deleted scenes: it's a prophylactic) but, in any case, it doesn't lead anywhere & isn't really motivated by anything. Angel (series 4) had exactly the same problem with unmotivated antagonism but it is MUCH more apparent here. There's little effort to conceal a structure that has the heroes running in a circle to the climactic fight.Is it just me? I hope I'm not being obsessively picky about a summer blockbuster. But I don't think it *is* just me, because the director's commentary obsesses over logistical detail. Whedon explains that the Iron Man / Thor battle was a contractual requirement, and that having them fight over possession of the captive Loki was an improvement over Marvel's "brainwash" concept. It just didn't play that way to me. Thor has no credible motive for fighting after learning that keeping Loki on earth could save humanity. In each watch-through this comes across as a flimsy excuse for a battle, especially after Thor drops the matter (without a word) after a dust-up.I could go on with the disappointing scenes (e.g. a *trickster god* being fooled by a ruse *that every audience member saw through* into blabbing his unnecessarily complex scheme) but maybe a blockbusters shouldn't be judged on those terms. And if you like this type of movie then you'll already have seen it and will have thrilled to its many cool details. I was hoping for more, so I can't recommend this to anyone who doesn't already know they like it. Ruffalo's Hulk is a major advance in the maturation of the screen superhero, but if you aren't interested in comic book worlds for their own sake then that won't matter to you & you should wait for the next movie in the hopes that it becomes what this one promised to be.

reviewText: Unlike so many movies coming out of Hollywood these days this one delivers.  We have a story that follows Joseph Campbell’s ‘Hero’s Journey’ which makes the storyline enjoyable.  They took their time to build up the story line and get us to care about characters in it.  We get to see Captain America in a modern city alone with Stark whom I think is the child of the girl Captain America liked in his first movie.  No, I haven’t read the comics.  We get to see Thor come back, yet it’s not explained how with the rainbow bridge destroyed.  The Hulk returns with a new guy playing him.  I like the other guy better from the last Hulk movie.  He played a David Banner closer to the TV series than anyone else as of yet.  Yet, the new guy will do.  We also get introduced to other new characters whose storyline was considered too ‘lame’ to be put into a movie.  Which is why we're missing ‘Ant-man’ and ‘Wasp’ movies.  There wasn’t even a mention of them anywhere.  This is a great movie if you want action, storyline, and depth meaning.  It draws on all the previous movies and paves the way for future ones.
summary: Well, it was worth the wait

reviewText: I really do enjoy this movie. So much so that my wife and I saw it twice in theater and I liked it so much that I then took other people to see the movie. So yes, I really do enjoy the movie.That said I'm rather let down by the packaging. From what I can only assume to be a way to make even more money off this release Marvel decided to stack the discs on top of each other. So you have on the left side the DVD and Digital Copy and on the right side the Blu Ray and the 3D Blu Ray. I'm OK with this style of packing for games likeGuild Wars 2  [Download],Star Wars: The Old Republicwhere you only really need the discs once or even DVD's likeBatman: Triple Featurewhere you know for the low price they will stack the DVDs.However, for a brand new release on Blu Ray i really do expect more. For examples seeThe Big Bang Theory: The Complete Fifth Season [Blu-ray] orUp (Four-Disc Blu-ray/DVD Combo + BD Live) [Blu-ray] for each of these and many other releases each disc gets its own slot. So hopefully your discs will hold up better with less chance to scratch or get damaged as you have to pull out one disc to get to the one below.I do really like the movie and I won't return it based on this, however I'm now stuck spending a few more dollars to get a proper blu ray case that can hold 4 discs1 Empty 22mm Thick QUAD Replacement Boxes/Cases for Blu-Ray DVD Movies - Holds 4 Discs - Blue (DV4R22BR)Thanks a lot Marvel.

reviewText: Had high hopes for this movie. Iron man I&II and Thor were quite good with Thor being a little better probably because of Anthony Hopkins playing Thor's Dad. Anyway, expected more of a story buildup and better interaction between the characters. Expected demonstrational reasoning for most of the super heroes for going from disliking each other to working together but didn't see any of that. One minute they hate each other next they are getting along like life-long pals. Heck the Hulk goes from being uncontrollable to becoming almost intellectual in a split second. Bottom line expected more but got another "Transformers" style movie of smash and smash some more....should be offered free with Prime membership like Thor and Transformers: dark side of moon. Either a lot of "story" is lying on the cutting room floor or today's audiences don't need much to be wowed.

reviewText: I'm pretty sure most people who might watch this movie already are aware that it's pretty awesome. If you've seen and liked the (first two) Iron Man movies, Thor, or Captain America, odds are good you will like this one. I have not personally seen the Hulk movie that ties in, but I heard it was also good. I highly recommend watching those movies first though; while it's not necessary to enjoy The Avengers, viewers will understand more of the events in the background. My sister had not seen the other movies first and so she didn't understand everything the first time she saw The Avengers. After we watched them though, and then watched this again, she had a deeper appreciation for the various plots.As for this blu-ray version, it is excellent. I got it on release day so it was on sale, and for $20 at the time, it was a lucky deal. We have a 55" Samsung LED/LCD and the movie looks great on it. This also included the DVD which is nice if you want to take it somewhere or watch it on a device that doesn't have blu-ray. I haven't used the digital download but it's probably the most likely candidate for if I were going to go ahead and download a movie to keep on a laptop or whatever.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The Avengers is the culmination of five previous movies and they could've easily screwed it up in so many different ways. Putting five disparate heroic characters from such different genres should've been a recipe for disaster. But somehow they manage to pull it off. And a large credit for that goes to Joss Whedon - an uber-comic fan who knew exactly what we wanted to see in the very first Superhero team-up film. All the predictable tropes of the comic books are here, but this is the first time we've ever seen them portrayed on film. The hero-on-hero fight, the team finally assembling and kicking superheroic butt all over New York. Great stuff.What makes The Avengers so different from recent blockbusters like Transfomers is that the emphasis is just as much on fleshing out the characters as on the entertaining action sequences. I can't recall any of Michael Bay's efforts having as much quotable dialogue as this film does ("Dost mother know, thoust wearest her drapes?", "Puny God"). Joss Whedon knows how to entertain an audience without insulting their intelligence, which is a tough act to pull off in most modern blockbuster films.I only have two minor criticisms - the 3D conversion and the lackluster soundtrack from Alan Silvestri. I believe the 3D was more the fault of the cinema - it looked muddy and flat, and I had a headache a few hours after watching it. The music sounded to me like sonic wallpaper for most of the film, but finally lifted at the end with a pretty rousing theme tune. It didn't doesn't sound like music from the same composer that did Captain America.I wish that I could recall one favourite moment, but the truth is that this entire film is one giant favourite moment. This is the ultimate superhero film I've been waiting to see since I was 12 years old and cracked open my first comic book. Joss Whedon, and the cast and crew, deserve credit for making one of the most entertaining blockbuster films I have seen in a long, long time.I look forward to the Avengers assembling for the next film!
summary: The Superhero film I've been anticipating since I was 12

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I knew from the outset that this film would be nothing short of great. Especially after I heard that Joss Whedon was co-writing and directing the film. This is the man that has created some of the best television ever (Buffy the Vampire Slayer - The Complete Series (Seasons 1-7) (2010) 39 Disc,Angel: Complete Series,Firefly - The Complete Series,Dollhouse: The Complete Seasons 1 & 2) as well as some great cinema (Serenity (Collector's Edition), "Cabin in the Woods"). This comic book film adaptation is about as perfect as it comes; it's Marvel's equivalent to DC'sThe Dark Knight (Two-Disc Special Edition). However, it still has Marvel's trademark wham-bam sci-fi dazzle, unlike DC's more gritty realism (part of the reason I like DC more). Luckily, though, Whedon is able to pull it all off. His perfect talent of blending action, drama and humor pays off big-time! And, it doesn't hurt that he has a ridiculous knowledge and understanding of the Avengers and their mythology. Next to the Fantastic Four, the Avengers are the perfect dysfunctional family (that's one thing they *do* have over my favorite, the Justice League). I was especially happy to see that they finally got the Hulk's story right (third time's a charm). I'd still like to see a female Avenger other than Black Widow; but hope she might make an appearance in the new Daredevil reboot. All of the performances were solid, making the movie as enjoyable as can be. Favorite moment has to involve main baddie, Loki (Tom Hiddleston) and the Hulk (Mark Ruffalo). Every character has equal screen-time and their stories given some good light ... but not too much, leaving room for more revelation for sequels. One thing DC should do is take a cue from this film and if they EVER plan on making a Justice League film, they should try (and hope) to get the actors they've cast in other films -- i.e., Christian Bale as Batman, Henry Cavill as Superman, Ryan Reynolds as Green Lantern. However, unfortunately, seeing how Bale no longer wants to do Batman after this summer's film, and DC doesn't wish to connect their films, I doubt this will happen. However, there has been recent news that DC is in the process of making a Justice League film. Anyways, Whedon and company get it right! This very well might be the action flick to see this summer! There's no more to say other than this film is awesome!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I've loved about every Marvel movie in this franchise, but this has to be my hands down favorite. It's the best superhero movie ever in my opinion. The best of all the characters, everyone gets to shine a bit, good plot, great development, and edge of your seat action through it all. Plus the genius of Loki. What's not to love? Highly recommend it for comic book fans, superhero fans, action fans, and anyone who just wants a great movie.

reviewText: This is like taking a box of super hero toys and jamming your head repeatedly into the box with your eyes wide open until you are blind and bleeding.Another film where it's obvious nobody really cared about actual cinema craft. Good story telling, good photography, screw that let's make a bunch of really idiotic action sequences for people who are dressed for no sensible reason at all like 8 year olds on Halloween.At least there are some decent visual effects, that is the only reason I can see this film deserving the one star I am obliged to give it.This film is horrendous. If you think a guy wearing a red white and blue unitard and mask with a big A on it for "America" (plus little wings for ears) reading dramatic lines of dialogue sounds like good cinema, then maybe this is the film for you. Clearly, most of America actually bought it. But to me this is as low as it gets.

reviewText: Where do I begin, what a great movie. It was pure genius to put in the banter between all the stars, it added that human quality. Dr Bruce Banner/Hulk, outstanding role by Mark Ruffalo, Hawkeye by Jeremy Renner, handsome Thor by Chris Hemsworth, good looking Captain America by Chris Evans, beautiful Black Widow by Scarlett Johansson, deadly charmer Loki by Tom Hiddleston, and all around good guy Agent Phil Coulson by Clark Gregg. You have Samuel Jackson as Nick Fury, over S.H.I.E.L.D, a great cast all around. I notice that at times you could not hear the dialog, other than that, a great movie. Have your pop corn ready, sit back and enjoy.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is the mega superhero popcorn flick that everyone was anticipating on seeing, and it turned out GREAT! Joss Wheldon did a great job of wrangling together all these characters, giving them exposition, and then having an awesome blow-off at the end. While Robert Downey Jr.'s portrayal of Tony Stark/Iron Man is always charming and charismatic, the show-stealer here is Mark Ruffalo as The Hulk. It's the guy's first attempt at the big green monster, and pulls it off effortlessly. The movie closes in on 2.5 hours, but it never truly slows down in pace. On Blu-ray, this movie comes across about as colorful and flashy as anything to hit the format! Highly recommended, and a must for the shelf!

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewerName: A.P. Fuchs, author of The Axiom-man Saga "www...
reviewText: When Thor's mischievous brother, Loki, makes a deal with the alien race Chitauri to help them secure the Tesseract Cube so they can conquer the galaxy, the Earth suddenly falls into great peril. With even the powerful top secret agency S.H.I.E.L.D. having difficulty containing Loki, there is only one call S.H.I.E.L.D. Director Nick Fury can make: Avengers Assemble!The team is gathered--Captain America, Iron Man, Thor, Hulk, Black Widow, Hawkeye--set out to do battle with Loki and his alien cohorts. If they don't overcome their differences and learn to work together as a team, the Earth will fall and Loki will rule the planet.The Avengers brings together Earth's mightiest heroes to combat a force of evil so great they either stand together or fall together, with the fate of the planet--even the galaxy--hanging in the balance.The Avengers is a difficult movie to review, more so, give a proper rating to because this movie is very much black and white between its story and its presentation, so that said, I'm going to quickly go over both and you'll see where I'm coming from at the end.The story: This is a single-plot movie, very much an A-to-B narrative and incredibly simple--too simple. Aliens are coming, we need to stop them so we'll get the Avengers to do it. That's it. From a storytelling perspective, it's too simple and too predictable. Big bad guy, big good guy(s), let's fight, good guys win. The end.However, if you view The Avengers as an end cap/final act to all the movies leading up to it: Iron Man, Incredible Hulk, Iron Man II, Thor, Captain America--then you have something that definitely serves its purpose and more or less let's each character shine for the same amount of time. In this case, a simple story works despite, um, the many continuity flaws from the previous movies (i.e. Thor somehow now able to come to Earth, which renders the ending of Thor's movie moot, Tony Stark called upon to be Iron Man in the Avengers despite being banned from doing so in Iron Man II, the characters communicating to each other without earpieces or any communication devices. Maybe they're telepathic?).The presentation: This movie is a nerd's dream come true from start to finish. Assemble your favorite superheroes--of which each were spotlighted in their own movies, almost--put them together and have them go toe-to-toe with a larger-than-life threat that will squash the planet if they don't come through.From an eye candy perspective, this movie nailed it. Huge battles, lots of explosions, combat action, hammer throwing, Hulk smashing, shield boomeranging, repulsors firing, arrows shooting, girl fists punching--yeah, it has it all.It's also very important to point out that the casting of Mark Ruffalo as Bruce Banner/Hulk was an amazing choice. I honestly wasn't too thrilled with the news when I first heard it, with Ruffalo being more a chick-flick romance guy, but he got the role done so well that if there's a spin-off, I hope he gets the job. He's definitely earned it.Chris Evans as Captain America--a Superman performance, which is good and brought a traditional superhero element to the team. As the running joke was throughout the movie, a little "old-fashioned" was what was needed.Robert Downey Jr. as Iron Man--do I really need to talk about this? He's the same Tony Stark from the first two movies, the only difference being he's mellowed out a bit because, despite his arrogance, he understands life isn't all about him and there's other people out there, too. This bit really comes through in this movie.Chris Helmsworth as Thor--bold, poetic, commanding, everything his character is supposed to be so kudos to him for carrying on with a great performance from the stand-alone movie.Jeremy Renner as Hawkeye--I don't know much about the comic character other than he's like Green Arrow, but perhaps with a more military-mind-set, so I can't comment. Renner did sell me on Hawkeye though, but why couldn't they give him that awesome mask? Maybe in the sequel.Scarlett Johansson as Black Widow--she really comes into her own in this flick because in Iron Man II, it was more a back-up appearance so we didn't know much about her. I'm glad she got the screen time she deserved and, come on, her fight scenes were fantastic.Tom Hiddleston as Loki--he's the bad guy you love to hate, the one that, even just looking at him, you want to punch in the face. I appreciated how Loki, to a degree, was a villain to sympathize with because of his exile, but you also get mad at him for being such a jerk about it.Samuel L. Jackson as Nick Fury--an excellent portrayal of Samuel L. Jackson being Samuel L. Jasckon--but under a fictitious alias. Yeah.The Avengers is a solid good-times-turn-your-brain-off-action-fest that is great for escape and is recommended for that reason. As a spoiler warning, if you want just the action parts, start the movie around 30 minutes in.Honest assessment is 3.5 out of 5, but because it's the first movie of its kind and because of all the building up to it that has been going on since 2008, I'll give it a 4.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I really, really liked the movie Thor ... and I did like the entire cast of this movie, but the movie itself was really boring and dull. It took a LONG time for the story to get going, but even when it did I still found it hard to keep watching. There was a lot of bickering, but not much fun or humor, though towards the end there were some fun lines.I didn't like how I couldn't hear what anybody was saying unless I turned up the volume almost all the way, but then any shouting or music or noise was SO LOUD. The story line was dull. I didn't care about any of the fighting. I usually like actions scenes like that, but this time I just kept thinking PLEASE END and get onto something else. Maybe they just went on too long. The fight scene in the forest seemed pointless and ended with them just suddenly back on the ship with the bad guy. How did that happen? Did my video skip over something? Or maybe I missed something because I couldn't hear it. They also talk to each other by speaking into the air. I never saw a microphone or anything. There was too much computer generated stuff so it seemed very cartoony at times. And too much Hollywood physics. (I don't mind either of those things, but this was too much of both.) I really wish the hulk could have been played by a real person though. I never liked computer hulk. The incredible hulk was one of my favorite TV shows, but some of my least favorites movies.Overall I thought the acting was great and the cast was great. I really thought I'd enjoy this and I know most people love it, but I don't.

reviewText: This is another case of over-hype.  When it was out in the theaters and then later when it was released on DVD people were clamoring and slobbering with praise over this thing.  I waited a while before watching it.  What a disappointment for me!Nothing really new here.  A few clever quips, a lot of boring filler dialog, and overkill on the effects and everything else.  I'm glad I saw it, but I was yawning and antsy for the whole mess to end.  Weren't some of the same effects and scenes in other bad movies like TRANSFORMERS: DARK SIDE OF THE MOON?  It all looked familiar.Robert Downey Jr carries this film.  The dumb haughty-speaking Asgards, Loki and Thor, were rather annoying.  "Shakespeare in the park" is what Ironman refers to them as--yes, apt description.Effect-laden, rambling-speeched, blah-blah-blah.  This film could have had an hour or so trimmed from it and it would have been more tolerable.  Sometimes more is not better, it's just more.

reviewText: The quality of DISC 1(the 3D Blu-Ray Video Disc),is superb,with 7.1 channels of surround HD sound to match.I also enjoyed the bonus features on DISC 2(the regular 2D Blu-Ray Disc),and DISC 3(regular DVD disc),also includes a bonus extra.The set also includes The DISC 4(Digital Copy), of the film and the "Avengers Assemble" Digital Album.all in all a nice package(the outer sleeve has a lenticular motion effect front cover),but for the expensive price for this set I expected, wanted,and would have liked a few more bonus extra features on the discs themselves.I recommend it anyway but with certain reservations of course.

reviewText: I've been avoiding the whole Marvel thing--big, stupid, and loud. Well it is big, and it's often loud, but this movie was not stupid. In fact, it was often witty. Really, the only thing I actively disliked was the sound mixing. The levels were so low in the dialogue scenes, I could barely hear them, but if I turned up the volume, the inevitable action that followed was so loud it hurt my ears.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Data from the Starship Enterprise has been transformed into Loki, the Norse god who, for some reason, decides to conquer Earth, using an alien race, in exchange for Rubik's Cube, which is now monochromatic. For some reason he cannot come to Earth, like his brother Thor, so he has been waiting for mortals to tinker with Rubik's Cube, which transports him to the planet. He does so, takes the Cube and bends a number of people to his will in order to play with the Cube so that a portal car be opened to allow the aliens to come in.For some reason, he then goes to Stuttgart to rip out an eye from an individual (apparently it has to be a German eye) to give to an archer that he has converted. An archer, you see, is crucial in the forthcoming battle employing spaceships, jet planes, tanks, and ray guns. At that point, for some reason, he lets himself get captured by Thor and Iron Man. He is taken to an enormous aircraft carrier the size of a small city that nobody in the world knows about or has somehow overlooked. At that point, for some reason, it is decided that the aircraft carrier must go up in the air, at which point, gigantic fans (yes, fans! Why didn't they use gigantic wings) lift it up. Then, while going aimlessly in the air, the now collected Avengers, brought together by a black Nick Fury (who was actually supposed to be white, but we might as well be Politically Correct), for some reason, now become hostile to one another. At this point, mega-archer appears, supposedly with his third eye implanted somewhere (maybe his rear end), and with his bow and ONE ARROW brings down the supercarrier whereupon Loki, who wanted to be captured for some reason, now for some reason, escapes.Shortly thereafter, Loki, having seen the Transformer films, goes on top of a building and has his machine turn on, at which point, the invasion begins. The invasion even has huge transformers leveling buildings (the aliens saw the same movies). The Avengers, for some reason having forgotten their previous hostility, band together and predictably fight off the invasion, helped tremendously by a 98-lb girl with a pop gun in each hand firing at mechanical leviathans.The special effects are standard, in that they are excellent, and that always brings in the crowds. A lot of the bantering between the characters, particularly coming from Iron Man, is great and that makes up a little bit for some of the drawbacks. Don't misunderstand me: the movie is as entertaining as it is stupid.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: When I was a pre-teen I picked up my first comic book and I remember thinking to myself, won't it be a great day when these great, escapist stories can be made into films. For the most part until the 90's I was pretty disappointed in the effort. However, going to see the Avengers was like a cathartic moment. It was if all the previous work on comic books films were all a preamble to this film. Don't get me wrong there are some great comic films out there now, like Sin City, Watchmen and many others. But for the most part these films felt like I was watching a film about a comic book instead of a film sprung forth from a comic book. Films and comic books are different media and I think until this film, although it has been close, there has never really been a film like this. This is no longer a comic book film BUT a really good film that just happens to use concepts first created for comic books.And in the same train of thought although this film is not a copy of a comic book, it has almost perfectly held true to the comic book ethos and should not, for the most part, disappoint the hardcore comic book fan. However, one of my few criticisms of the film deals with a difference between how one particular character is portrayed.I am not going to go into the plot of the story as you should go see/buy it for yourself! Just stay watching after ALL the credits. There are TWO bits after the credits.Now below I am just listing a few criticisms of the film, but over all I give it a sold A. It would have been an A+ expect for the following.In the comic books, Thor is clearly a Norse god and is unquestionably Marvel's "Superman". Between his own film and this film there seems to be a effort to take him down a few notches. I don't really know why but I have a feeling that somewhere there is an old, childhood prejudice against this character. I am sure somewhere along the line, some power that is, didn't like that Thor was the best of the best and is using his/her influence to knock him down a few pegs. I find it silly and very disappointing because if he was portrayed honestly, it would severely add to not only the escapism but bring a real since of order and justice to counter the Hulk's raw terror.I also was a bit disappointed in the Captain America's line that proclaimed that Thor was not a real god and only the Christian god was. For that reason alone, I can't give this film five stars. There are people out there that still worship the Norse pantheon and making that swipe is no more different than saying the same thing about Allah or Buddha. The only reason this part hasn't received any bad press is that few pagans that still worship Thor (et all)have a really good sense of humour and are very few in numbers. If they picket the film who cares right?Another criticism I had about this film was a wee bit of dialogue by Loki when he was in Berlin. It was just too "hokey" and could have been written much better.And my last very, very, very, tiny criticism is that this film was in New York. There should have been at least a mention or shout out to the Fantastic Four. NYC is their stomping ground and by all rights someone at SHIELD should have at least mentioned them. And come on, let's all admit it, wouldn't it have been awesome to see the Hulk turn around and come face to face with The Thing?
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Saw Marvel's The Avengers when it was first released in the theaters, three times. Thought it was marvelous then and still do now. The individual movies were great and the collective was fantastic. The original actors returned to the signature roles; Robert Downey Jr., as Iron Man, Chris Hemsworth as Thor, Chris Evans as Captain America were their usual best. Add to the cast newcomers: Mark Ruffalo, as The Hulk, Scarlett Johansson and Jeremy Renner and you have one of the best super hero movies in years. And let's not forget Samuel L. Jackson as Nick Fury and you've got a masterpiece.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This movie dragged on for a little while from the beginning.  I started to get a little bored, but soon overcame it.  My favorite part was what the, "Hulk" did to the bad guy Loki.  I think I spelled his name right.  I kept rewinding it, which made me laugh more every time.Iron Man got a lot more camera time, while I feel, "Thor" was a little slighted.  Robert Downey Jr. provided some comedy as usual.  The costumes were awesome and every actor was suited for their character role in my opinion.  The fight scenes were terrific.  The Hulk commanded attention all over the place, and definitely got it.  Over all, the movie is entertaining, a little long, super charged, and fun to watch.The blu-ray shows great.  However, they did place some of the dics on top of one another.  I had to place two in separate cases, which was a let down.  I am happy that I bought this four movie combo when Amazon sold it for $19.99.  A pretty good deal indeed, compared to the prices right now.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The Avengers is a truely excellent movie, even under it's own merits, and may just be my new favorite comic book/superhero movie to date. I'm not going to give too detailed a review, but as much as I liked it, and feel most fans of this genre will as well, doesn't mean it's perfect in story and plot. Although the movie's story was actually fairly close to the original Avengers's first mission Loki is still a weak antagonist and the 'puppet army' was a bit of a let down. However, I am willing to overlook most of the shortcomings I have perceived from this movie because I thoroughly enjoyed it! I rated the DVD four stars not because of the movie but the product as a whole because it doesn't have any deleted scenes, which I feel is just a ploy to get people to buy a BR player. Sorry, but I hate it when companies do stuff like that, especially Disney who doesn't need the money. I hope the success of this one doesn't cause a rush to make the sequel; I would be disappointed if it turned out bad.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Seeing all the superheroes come together was excellent, however, the pace could have been quicker. I expected to see some non- stop action after knowing they would all bring different talents to the table. Iron Man added humor to the movie and Thor (who was very easy on the eyes:)was excellent as he showed brotherly love toward his villain brother. The Hulk was better here than he was in The Hulk movie but his "hulk" scenes were not plentiful(although Iron Man just to provoke him to turn with his antics). The story plot could have been better but they made you forget that as they all battled in the end. There were some terrific action scenes in the end which makes you wonder why didn't they throw some of this in the beginning. Would have been nice to see Thor stretch his muscles early on.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I feel as if I got a great deal on this product and shipping was very quick (2 days).  I could not wait to watch this on my plasma TV with my kids.  The video played through with no errors, the quality on my TV was amazing.  The sound, I feel could be better, but this I would blame on my TV (I am looking to add a surround sound system to upgrade the entertainment experience for when we get a chance to experience a movie to wind down).I do not want to play spoiler for this movie if you have not seen it, but I will say that there are a few super-heroes: Black Widow, Hawkeye, Captain America, Iron Man, Thor, Nick Fury and The Hulk.  Black Widow (played by Scarlett Johansson) was great, I like that she had the look and nailed the moves.  Hawkeye (played by Jeremy Renner) was pretty good, there were a few really cool parts in this movie that Hawkeye had.  Captain America (played by Chris Evans) Captain is the first Avenger and even if the Captain is overmatched he will not back down and does what he must.  I really liked the humanistic approach of Widow, Hawkeye and Captain America as being more believable in the story because they cannot fly, do not have hulkish strength or able to command thunder.  They brought a sense of reality to the story.Iron Man (played by Robert Downey Jr.) was downright AWESOME!  I think Downey is meant to be Iron Man.  He captivated this role; his personality and character are very convincing for this role.  Iron Man is criticized as not being a team player but then.... happens (again do not want to play spoiler).  Thor (played by Chris Hemsworth) was pretty cool; I personally think The Avengers could have had more Thor due to who the villain was.  Nick Fury (played by Samuel L. Jackson) was very cool, as Jackson is cool in what seems to be every other movie in existence do to the amount of movies he is in!  Fury does what has to be done to assemble the Avengers to defend earth.  Lastly, my favorite character was the Hulk (played by Mark Ruffalo).  I feel as if Marvel finally got what the audience wants out of the "real Hulk".  Not to blame Edward Norton, I personally think that he played an aspect of who the Hulk really should be (during last hulk movie) when not angry better.  But unfortunately, it took Marvel up to this point with the Computer Graphics Imaging to get what we really care about down.  In my opinion, the Hulk had the coolest and most awesome moments in the movie!  I cannot wait for another Hulk movie!I do have some points to criticize about this movie- The fact that there are seven Marvel characters (hero’s) used and only one is female is a little underrepresented by females.  Also, Fury is a Marvel character but does little real fighting or real action, I feel as if the African American hero population is also underrepresented.  In the next film it would be nice to have another female hero and an African American hero.  The end result is entertainment and appeal.  I feel that a super hero should not just appeal to little boys, but little girls too.  I have two little girls and I personally think there is nothing wrong with them wanting to be like a hero that they have seen (goals, great virtues, etc...).Picture quality-5/5Sound quality-3.5/5 *(see above)Story-line- 4.5/5Cast-5/5Super heroes on team-5/5 *(although from my readings the Hulk is not a typical Avenger)Value-5/5 $25 free shipping for Blue-Ray 3D, Blue-Ray, DVD, Digital Copy and Digital Music copy for a newly released movie.Anxiety for Avengers 2-5/5!  lolHope I helped; this movie is now among my top five favorites of all-time now!  What are you doing reading?  Go out and get your copy today!  Do it now!

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Everything about this movie works and works well. The acting, the character design, the plot, the action scenes, and the soundtrack are some of the best I've ever seen for a summer blockbuster. All of the actors sold their characters and made us not only believe that they were who they were portraying, but also showed us why these characters were part of the Avengers in the first place. Loki is a great villain. Mark Ruffalo's take on Bruce Banner turned out to be one of the best decisions Marvel Studios has made with these movies so far. The fights are action-packed, funny, and full of tension and thrills. What few complaints I do have are minor: Captain America's costume looks odd, I'm not sure why the shadowy organization of people hiding in shadows was there, and I don't think Colbie Smulders as Maria Hill got enough screen time. Other than that, loved this movie and loved this release. It's got all kinds of cool bonus features and the picture quality is amazing. Definitely one to put in everyone's collection ASAP.
summary: Comic book giants come to life in one of the greatest action movies ever made

It is a great standalone movie but it does make references to the respective movie characters being portrayed in this film.  I have a 13 year old son. He loved this so much he was climbing the walls and no the edge of the couch.  So if it can keep a kid entertained for two hours, then it's worth the money. Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: What can I say, as Iv'e just left The Avengers movie? It's a comic book straight from the pages and onto the screen. What Marvel fans have been waiting for for years, and it all began with the success of Raimi's "Spider-Man" and Singer's "X-Men", Marvel Studios green lit the Avengers project that started off in 2008 with Iron Man, along with Captain American, Thor, Incredible Hulk and a second Iron Man. This all takes us to this film, which I cannot describe other than a perfect adaptation and feeling of a superGROUP movie. Which is harder to do than a solo film. There is no filler in this, every moment is eyes wide open and moves along at a perfect pace.  It's a perfect translation from comics to film, wonderfully casted and no Avenger is lackluster, everyone shines and all have great screen time, even Sgt.Fury kick arse. Hulk is epic, effects and sound are great. I'll probably see this again.Director Joss Whedon ("Buffy the Vampire Slayer", "Angel", "Firefly");as well as writing comic books, was the perfect director for this project. His vision was epic.Here's my one word for this movie: AWESTRUCK, or SMASH!!!Can't wait for the blu-ray transfer and watch it several more times.  GO SEE THIS!!!! "The Dark Knight Rises" is going to have some fierce competition.DECIDED TO KNOCK THIS FILM DOWN TO 4 STARS. SORRY, BATMAN: TDKR IS THE BEST COMIC BASED FILM.And don't forget to stay through the credits, if your a geek like me, you'll know the villain in the sequel. Genius. And one does not simply leave a Marvel movie without staying till the end.
summary: Years of origin films which leads us to this Super Hero masterpiece

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Nick Fury, director of the peacekeeping organization S.H.I.E.L.D., recruits Iron Man, Captain America, the Hulk, Black Widow, Hawkeye and Thor to form a team that must stop Thor's adoptive brother Loki from subjugating Earth. You see, Loki makes a deal with the leader of the Chitauri. In exchange for getting the Tesseract(an energy source with unlimited potential) for them, the leader of the Chitauri promises Loki a Chitauri army with which he can enslave the Earth with.I was wildly skeptical about this movie, truth be known. Despite the fact the movie received rave reviews and made billions at the box office, I didn't think Joss Whedon could pull off a convincing Avengers movie, regardless of what people thought. There was too many variables there with which, to tie together, to make a good movie without someone getting the short end of the stick on screentime. I figured this movie would be like The Transformers, Battleship or something of the like and have tons of explosions and pointless action sequences, making it not amount to much. Although it did have both, it was never pointless. Whedon actually pulled off a cohesive & convincing Avengers movie. It was, definitely, no Dark Knight movie but it wasn't intended to be. I was quite impressed with it because it turned out to be nothing like I expected The Avengers movie to be. I was given something completely different and I really liked that.I only have two gripes with the movie and they're small gripes. First, the movie started off a bit slow. When I expected it to pick up its' pace a little bit, it just lulled there yet, by the second hour, it started its' gallop into an all-out running up to the end. If I had of blinked, I would've missed some great parts in the movie. Second, I was somewhat disapointed at how they changed everyones' outfits. Especially, Captain America and Thor's outfits.  Change is constant, I know, but why mess with something that-previously- was nearly perfect for them. I really liked the Kevlar look of Cap's previous outfit. Oh well- you can't have everything you want, I guess.Marvel's The Avengers is, without a doubt, a great piece of cinematic history. It makes me wonder, now, just how Warner Brothers plans on pulling off its' Justice League movie. I enjoyed The Avengers movie and really really look forward to next chapter in their ongoing saga. Was that really <Spoiler Alert> Thanos I saw grinning an evil grin at th end of the movie? Whether you're a comic book fan, or an action fan; you'll find lots to love about this movie. <Thumbs up>

reviewText: Exactly that. All his characters in everything he's penned have a very strong sense of self. It has a 3D Blu-Ray, Blu-Ray, DVD, and Digital Copy along with a code that unlocks an Avengers Comic on Comixology's website as well as the Official Soundtrack and some extra artwork for download on your PC. reviewText: OK - I am finally writing a review of a Marvel film!  After reading a lot of Avengers, Fantastic Four, Iron Man, X-Men, when I was young - I felt this Film version hit all the right notes (pitch perfect) - and made each character memorable, distinctive, and extremely charismatic!Iron Man, Captain America, and Thor already had tremendously successful eponymous films of their own.But the truly inspired full 'Break-out' character introduction in this Avengers movie was of course the 'Black Widow'!!!  She was also featured in Iron Man II, but really came into her own, as a 'vital' and most intriguing & Essential character in this film!  This was an inspired choice, because the Black Widow (former Top Soviet Spy named Natasha Romanoff, later International 'Jet setter' and eventual 'SHIELD' agent) = was actually, in her early comic days, sort of a second-tier character (though popular enough to have a short-lived series in the early Marvel 1970's 'Amazing Adventures' then as 'Daredevil's' beloved side-kick, for about 30+ issues (before Elektra, came on the scene).But it is really Scarlett Johansson's mesmerizing portrayal in this film ==> who completely epitomizes the famous definition of the true/ real Black Widow spider (i.e. the enchanting creature for which the male spider will gladly/ and most willingly sacrifice its own Life, in order to couple with ==> having absolutely no regrets whatsoever, about his fateful decision!) - darn, now I completely Lost my train of thought!Anyway, yes now I remember = the second inspired burst of creativity, was to 're-invent' the characterization of the Hulk ==> Mark Ruffalo finally brings, what has been sadly lacking in the earlier Hulk films:  the 'pathos' in the character of Bruce Banner, of the brilliant, but 'lost'/ bewildered mild-mannered scientist, who knows that he really can't control that raging beast within him (but does his best to 'stay calm' nonetheless) - Ruffalo imbues the character with the perfect mix of uneasiness, even vulnerability against that just-under the surface Explosiveness!  Keeping the audience, constantly on edge, anticipating the next 'transformation' - ingenious!And Tom Hiddleston, makes the character of 'Loki' the epitomy and definition of 'Mischievous' = even in the midst of endless death & destruction, Loki has the  wry, wide-eyed smile/ constant grin of the proverbial 'kid in the Candy store'!Much kudos must also go to writer/Director Joss Whedon, who has a brilliant track record with fantasy/adventure & SciFi entertainment (and even wrote a brilliant 're-imagined' X-Men comics series, to boot!)Even the great (Marvel father) Stan Lee, must have been pleased (beyond his wildest Dreams) - with this truly Epic Film!Speaking as a nearly Life-Long Marvel Comics fan (although I have not kept up with all the modern mythology) - Excelsior!!!PS:  a special THANKS!! to Black Widow, and the rest of Avengers for keeping the Sochi, Russia = Winter Olympic Games Safe, and free from 'incident' (except for that 'slushy' Snow - I guess they forgot to include 'Iceman' from that other Marvel super-team, the Uncanny X-men!)Amazing closing ceremony, by the way - especially Chagall, Chekov, and Mischa the now (apparently) friendly Bear?!  Das-vidanya! and especially:  PEACE be with You, Mr. Bear!!  Or else, we might need to call-in the Silver Surfer, to bring forth some positively 'cosmic' good vibes!!!note especially for comic-book fans: another highlight from the Late 1970's = Black Widow actually became the 'Leader' of her own short-lived Super-team (from Marvel, of course), called the 'Champions' which also featured Hercules, Ghost-Rider, the Angel, and our much needed in 'slushy' Sochi => the 'Iceman'!  It was an  interesting concept (and this team was rather 'offbeat'/diverse), but unfortunately only lasted a mere 17 issues (from 1975-1977) - and featured some great/ early John Byrne artwork!
summary: Make mine Marvel Movies = Excelsior x 1000!!!  As Stan Lee might say!!

reviewText: It's the usual smash-em-up nonsense here, with lots of loud banging and crashing for most of the more than 2-hour running time: too long, incidentally. Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: What's it about?When the evil Loki threatens Earth; Nick Fury of S.H.I.E.L.D, must assemble a team of extraordinary individuals known as `The Avengers' to stop the coming alien invasion.Is it any good?Believe the hype, Marvel fans will not be disappointed. Written and directed by Joss Whedon was there ever any doubt that this movie would be awesome; after all he is the King of geekdom. `The Avengers' packs plenty of pulse pounding action, sharp humor and some of the most incredible special effects you will ever see. The real highlight of this movie isn't just in the action, it is Whedon's amazing script. The razor sharp wit is thrown in with perfect comic timing and our heroes are given enough depth to show their vulnerable human sides; they all clash well together as they battle egos and brawn. Mark Ruffalo is the only new guy and does an excellent job as Bruce `Hulk' Banner, Scarlett Johansson brings sexy back as `Black Widow' but it is Robert Downey Jr. who steals the show as egotistical Tony `Iron Man' Stark. If you haven't seen `The Avengers' yet, then I suggest you strap your undies on the outside of your pants and join Captain America, Thor, Iron Man, Hulk, Black Widow and Hawkeye in this super hero slog-fest!Best bit?Thor and Hulk punch on while on board the `Helicarrier'; S.H.I.E.L.D.S. headquarters.Did you know?Edward Norton was set to reprise his role as the Hulk but negotiations between him and Marvel Studios severed.

reviewText: We watched this at the theater in IMAX 3D, so watching a Blu ray of this film at home had a lot to measure up to. I would say that it was quite acceptable. We watched it on a 55" LG with passive 3D. The image was crisp and the 3D added, in my opinion, to the viewing experience over watching a standard Blu ray ... and I think that standard Blu rays normally look pretty good.I doubt I have to fill anyone in about the subject of this movie. It takes several Marvel super-heroes who have all had their own films leading up to this and puts them in one epic package. True to the Marvel taste, for most of the film they do not get along well with each other, but come together when it counts to fight an exhausting and dangerous battle against seemingly impossible odds. But what else are super-heroes supposed to do? LOLThe acting is convincing, and there are quite a few moments of humor to give you a break from the more serious tone of the movie (a defect in the otherwise brilliant movies in the new Batman series).The sound in this presentation is simply outstanding. I don't remember another film which has driven my subwoofer more powerfully or effectively. The rest of the sound comes through powerfully and crisply too. There is no problem with level balancing between the score, the sound effects and the dialogue.If you like super-hero movies, this very well may be the best one ever released.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: First, the story is complete silliness, even for a superhero movie, but its so fun that I didn't care.  The Hulk is a great addition to the modern Marvel movie line up.  Captain America makes much more sense as a character now that he is surrounded by much stronger heroes; it is now clear that being brave despite a lack of special powers that makes him the leader. I really disliked his solo movie, so this was a nice surprise.From a technical standpoint, the 3d is great and the sound is amazing. The 3d adds depth without that in your face style that can cause headaches.  Plus you get the 2d regular blu ray, a DVD, and a digital copy. I was surprised to find that I received a code for the movie soundtrack as well.My only complaint beyond the silly bad guys was that the Hulk should have come out to play sooner in the movie!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The Avengers is about a dysfunctional superhero team that comes together with some guidance to face an alien who wants to take over the earth as king and wants to bring forth an army of aliens to help him. Great concept, a lot of superheroes, and I wondered how the creators were going to pull this off. They more than pulled it off. I was so impressed, and the movie was excellent!I love to watch movies that takes me away from normal. This movie had the flying worms, the alien armies, all kinds of fight scenes, and mind tricks, and the great part for me is that MOST of it made sense. It wasn't crazy by your pants, lets do anything under the sun.It flowed well and I followed the story easily. The one issue I had was when the hulk first appeared, and he was trying to kill Black Widow after the explosion on the ship. Why try to kill her? I watched the hulk as a kid, and he was always kind towards kids and women. So, for him to go after Black Widow was confusing. Other than that, I had a full understanding of the movie.All of the superheroes were fun to watch. The Hulk was scary sometimes, funny, and amazing [loved how he took down that worm]. I really liked Black Widow. I like a woman who doesn't need a man to save her. Damsel in distress does not exist for this lady. Iron Man was awesome, like always. Hawkeye was sexy! I was cheering for him when he came back to the good side. Captain America seemed a little more dark, more serious, but I enjoyed the character still. And Thor was cool. I dug the lingo that he spoke, and it was a great change to Stark's quick speech and wit. I was even impressed with Fury. He held his own, and he wasn't a slouch. Solid, great characters.So, overall the movie was very good to me. I can see why people loved it so much. I know I did.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: At this writing I have the "honor" of being the 100th person to place a review for "The Avengers," an as yet unreleased DVD.  I shall attempt to write with all due aplomb."The Avengers" is exactly what escapist movie fiction is supposed to be.  When real life contains as many terrors as Hollywood can dream up we need to laugh and cry and jump and shout at the screen to relieve those tensions.  To refer to this as "war porn," as I saw one reviewer did, is to underestimate the powerful purgative and emotional effect that purely enjoyable movies like this do.This is a clever movie--it begins by introducing the villain, Loki, then two of the least well-known superheroes in the "Avenger" stable: Hawkeye and the Black Widow.  Only quick clues about them are given, but they're enough for the movie to progress.  (To tell you the truth I've seen the movie twice and I still don't have any real idea what the Black Widow does.)Regardless, one by one the superheroes and their supporters are brought to light--the Hulk, Iron Man, Thor, and Captain America.  Eventually, all make it to S.H.I.E.L.D.'s home base (and occasionally flying aircraft carrier) the Helicarrier.  It isn't long before they all begin to fight among themselves, and, as we all know from lots of film viewing we're going to need a reason to bind together.  That reason comes in the form of the death of someone very close to the circle of heroes, and unite they do.All of this isn't terribly important...I'm very sure some similar components would have occurred regardless of who wrote the film.  It isn't hard to figure that you have a bunch of superheroes and they all have egos the size of their talents, so you know it would be difficult for them to bind together.Apparently some similar plot was being put together for its original date of release in the summer of 2011.  But various factors required that the movie be pushed back a year, and along came Joss Whedon, who took the script in hand, rewrote it, and became its director.  And thus was birthed this version.For those who don't know, Joss Whedon has put together hit TV shows, yet has had little respect among the powers that be, nor a really successful show in a decade.  Once a writer on Roseanne's TV show, he wrote the original movie "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," then convinced the studio to allow him to re-create it as a television show.  He went on to win an Emmy for writing, and the show lasted five years on two networks.In 2002 Whedon went on to create the cult classic and oft called space western "Firefly" which, despite its strong core fan base (nicknamed the Brownshirts), was cancelled after 11 episodes even though they had shot 14.  Later this strong fan base encouraged Universal Studios to wrap up the series in a two-hour movie called "Serenity," which again underwhelmed...despite the Browncoats.The same went for "Dollhouse," a show that only ran two years...a victim, again, of low ratings.  Other than a couple of fan favorites like "Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog," a short starring Neil Patrick Harris shot during the writers' strike, Joss Whedon had done little else that wowed anyone.  How he was able to land the directing post of "The Avengers" I simply don't know, but thank God he did.For instance, talk to anyone who enjoyed this film and ask them their favorite scene, and you'll be hard pressed to find anyone who doesn't tell you right off the bat it's one that involves humor...and, not coincidentally, the Hulk, whom I'll get to later.  And that, in a nutshell, is what Joss Whedon brought to this movie.Whedon's humor is ever present in his work, whether it is billed as a drama or not, and it is this humor that is at the heart of "The Avengers."  It is through Whedon's jaundiced eye that we see these six superheroes interact, and it is through him that the story gains its humanity.  Think of it: the very fact that such oversized and super-powerful beings exist, even with the blessing of Hollywood, is funny.  And that they must CO-exist for any of this to work...well, that's hilarious.And it is this that lies at the heart of this extremely entertaining movie: what characterization that exists does so not to make our heroes SUPER, but HUMAN.  It is Whedon's genius to set his eye upon the all-too-normal traits that lie at the heart of all of us: vanity, pride, fear of failure, competitiveness, and even the desire to erase that part of us that we wish others not to see.  It is not that the characters can fly that wows us; it is that even he (or she) fears falling.I have heard some minor complaints about the drag at the middle of the film, when our heroes are weakest, when they fight among themselves. But I think it is this scene that makes the movie believable...that speaks to a deeper dread.  The crisis in this movie began when we sought to make bigger weapons, and making bigger weapons drew the eyes of bigger enemies.  If one thinks of it, the worst criminals never show up until there is a superhero worthy of them: there was no madman named Joker until there was Batman, no evil Lex Luthor until Superman.On a more well, human, scale, perhaps the greatest beneficiary of Whedon's careful eye is the Incredible Hulk, who has been regarded far too seriously in each of his two big movie outings thus far.  As portrayed by both Ed Norton and Eric Bana--and, hey, even going back to Bill Bixby's TV Hulk--the Big Guy has just been too serious.  It is only under Whedon's watch that he has blossomed, and in such a way as to provide many of the movie's best moments.  We even get to hear "Hulk, SMASH!" and it is so good to hear the audience laughing ALONG with the character rather than AT him.But as long as we're on the subject, some credit must go to Mark Ruffalo, who has humanized the Hulk as well with his gentle but knowing performance as the Hulk's better half, Dr. Bruce Banner.  His dark, rumpled face is perfect for the man whose monster lies within, a man who knows all too well what it is to walk around with a terrible secret.Who cares if the movie goes a little awry in the end, having politicians decry our heroes for the damage caused to the city?  (And who else is getting tired of EVERY movie that depicts NYC as the perennial victim?)  Not when we've had such a wonderful joyride getting there.This movie is a pleasure from start to finish, Speaking of which, stick around for the credits, and a little beyond.  There are two little fun snippets of film left as Easter Eggs for the fans who care enough to stick around.
summary: What can I say?  Joss Whedon's a SUPERHERO at last!

reviewText: Great movie, great action from start to finish, a real mans movie if you know what I mean.But one BIG complaint about it. I rented this on Amazon Instant video, so I don't know if this goes for any other media, but I think it must happen in any media of this movie.The sound quality. When the people are just talking to each other even at highest volume on my computer I can barely make out their words, but when someone is shooting or screaming or something blows up the sound is almost deafeaning.To me this is a huge screw-up. I'm straining my ears to hear human dialogue with no background noise at all, turning up the volume to the highest level just to hear normal speak.A sound effect comes along and I have to cover my ears it's so damn loud.I loved the movie but the sound quality really really pissed me off.

reviewText: Marvel went a smart route and built up an audience bit by bit and movie by movie culminating in this film and dump trucks full of money. As far as Oscar winning film making?
