Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is like a children's story:  Spoilers Alert!Once upon a time there was a master who had 4 superheros under his wing.  One was a long-haired knight from galaxy far far away who weilded a hammer.  One had a round metal shield and dressed in American flag.  One put on his armor and  he could fly.  Last but not least was a man who turned into a green giant when he got angry.  In addition, there were two naughty ones, a man used bow and arrow and a young lady who could fight off a bunch of bad guys.  The long hair knight had a bad brother who wanted to destroy the world with a space ship filled with mean metal dragons.  To save the world, the master called upon the superheros to fight off the attack of metal dragons with the help of the naughty ones.  And the superheros won!Seriously, Joss Wheldon made a smart and entertaining blockbuster with the help of a group of engaging film superstars.  The film sags a bit in the first hour.  The spaceship and the metal dragons are nothing new.  The action sequences are okayly executed.After the dust settled, it is just another movie about superheros.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I bought this for a friend who loves comic books, and he definitely appreciates it. Made me become a superhero fan!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is a well made, well acted and enjoyable film. . .but it certainly isn't the greatest thing ever to hit the screen, nor (in my opinion) even the best superhero film.  The Dark Knight, the first Iron Man, the 1978 Superman and perhaps even the 1989 Batman are all arguably superior films. . .but with that said, this is still a highly entertaining film.Predictably, Robert Downey Jr. steals virtually every scene he is in.  The guy has blossomed into an amazing actor and, while the cast as a whole is very capable, he tends to dwarf their performances. . .with one exception. . .Mark Ruffalo.  I am a fan of Edward Norton's work and was disappointed when his contract to play Marvel's green behemoth (probably my favorite superhero when I was growing up), fell apart.  However, it worked out for the best, I think, in terms of fans of this genre.  Ruffalo is simply a superb Bruce Banner - in one film arguably becoming as definitive as Bill Bixby was for the hokey 1970s TV series.  This film is worth seeing for his perfomrance alone. . .throw in the rest of the cast and you have quite an engaging mix!The film is loaded with CGI, but we've reached the technological point in filmmaking where that really doesn't matter anymore.  It all looks very good, even during the very challenging and difficult to execute scenes during the climax.  I'm not, I'm afraid, much of a fan of the Thor storyline nor its cast of characters, so when I realized Loki was going to be the principle villain, I was disappointed, but again - it is incorporated well. . .and that's not really the focus of the film anyway.  The central focus is the interactions of the Avengers themselves, and the great cast makes those interactions an entertaining pleasure to watch.  Highly recommended.Incidentally, I do not feel that viewing this movie in the 3D format is necessary.
summary: A very good - but not quite great - film. . .
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: While I really like the "Iron Man" franchise, I am not a fan of the genre per se.  I tried to watch "Thor" and wasn't very impressed.  And the "Hulk" films have been - at times - more than dismal.  So, it is surely a good thing if I give a movie such as this a four-star rating.The first half hour seems to move at a snail's pace, and I was thinking, "This is really going to be a disappointment."  I believe that Samuel L. Jackson is heavily featured in that timeframe, and I am still not much of a fan of his for ripping A. O. Scott.  Personally, I think that Mr. Jackson was off-base at best and unwise at worst.  "Hey, Mr. Scott didn't like your film.  Who cares?" would be my rebuttal.  So yes, I am a little biased against Mr. Jackson because of this.  (I've always thought that Mr. Jackson is somewhat overrated as well.  Decent actor but surely not in the "great" category.  But it could be argued that Mr. Scott may be the best film critic out there.)But then, Robert Downey Jr. enters the picture.  Ah, you know the film will be fun then, and it is.  He is not only a very good actor - perhaps excellent at times (watch "Chaplin" if you disagree with me, one of the best performances ever), but he's also very funny.  And then Mark Ruffalo adds to the fun.  I really liked his work in "Zodiac" and he does, in my opinion, the best Hulk ever.  And it's not even close.This film seems to be about sticking together as a team, and having a leader who's willing to lead and followers who are willing to follow.  Sometimes, if you have the right team, you can do some pretty amazing things.  Should be a film for Fortune 500 companies to watch, and try to remember what it was like when people - and companies - actually cared about doing great work.  Well, good luck with that now in the US.  Even Captain America may not be able to save you.Pretty big recommendation by me.  If you're not a fan of the genre, just wait until the second act and you might become a fan.
summary: Robert Downey Jr. Saves the Day - and the film
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I've finally got it! The modern epic movie...4 years and 5 movies in the making and I loved how they manage to make it all "fall into place"!The PQ and AQ are tremendous!!! I drool over the crisp video and audio quality everytime I watch it!!! The Extras in this version of Avengers release is quite good mostly due to the Deleted & Extended Scenes. Loved the contents in here! There's also the interesting Commentary Track & Featurettes, the cool Soundgarden Music Video, the funny Gag-Reel and the weird one on Item 47...but truthfully, I was expecting more! Maybe it's on the Disney Second Screen but I haven't had the chance to load it yet. I find it quite inconvenient. Why can't they just have the damned thing on the disc instead of having to fiddle with another device while watching the movie?! Anyways, since this release comes with the Digital Soundtrack and Digital Copy of the movie in the extra DVD disc I'm gonna give it quite high marks still.I can't comment much about the 3D version of the film coz I don't have a 3D capable TV & blu-ray player set but since it was going for USD0.04 more than the 2D version why miss the chance, right?!I didn't quite like the way the packaging though...since the blu-ray and 3D blu-ray and kept back-to back on one leaf and the DVDs are kept back-to-back on the other leaf. I'm afraid that it would be prone to scratches! :(All-in-all it's still worth to buy and proudly kept in your collection...and it's one of those rare movie which I believe comic book and non-comic book fans will enjoy!

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I saw this a couple years ago, and thought it was OK. I like the Iron Man movies, but the others are just OK. For some reason I wanted to see something about this the other day, and found that I could watch it for free now as a Prime bennie. So I did last night, and I was blown away. I didn't know Joss Whedon wrote and directed this, or I would have paid better attention the first time. That was a brilliant move, he's the best there is. Of course the acting was excellent, and I really appreciated the characters' interactions with each other. The tension was palpable, and believeable. It set up the climax perfectly. One thing that was incongruous was the flying aircraft carrier. Still don't get why Fury would want something like that, no benefit and (obviously) many risks.The key to this film's greatness is that it relies the most on the interactions of the characters rather than the battles. And the key to the interactions is the brilliant casting, which of course was taken care of far in advance by Marvel when they assigned these folks to their separate movies before this payoff blockbuster. But again, with anyone but Whedon at the helm, it may not have been this great.Now I see there is a sequel in the works, might even be done filming by this time. Everyone, but most especially Whedon, is back. Watch for Avatar box office records to be broken.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Captain America: "And Hulk...smash."Full of humor, drama, and loads of Avenging action makes it one of the most brilliant superhero feature films to date. It even gives "Batman Begins [Blu-ray]" a run for it's money. There is honestly nothing negative I can say about this film, except for one thing but that's a spoiler for those who haven't seen it yet. Iron Man is still Iron Man, Hulk is the best he's been yet, and there's no team quite like the Avengers. Who at LEGO would disagree to them making a series about this film? (I recommend "LEGO Hulk Helicarrier Breakout 6868" and for you Avengers collectors, "LEGO Quinjet Aerial Battle 6869" is a must have). The casting is brilliant, the action is great, and the villains are threatening and self-absorbed. For the last one, mainly Loki. These lines sum up the film for you:Loki: "I have an army."Tony Stark: "We have a Hulk."All of you out there, in short, go see this movie. Five out of five.Iron Man: "If we can't save the world, we can darn well avenge it."
summary: Marvel + Disney + Joss Whedon = The Avengers

reviewText: This is the one that ties it all together!  Not only does it tie to Marvel characters but to WWII as well.  All are quite "camp" and great fun for adults as well as the kiddos.  The actors work well together even when they aren't.  Ain't it funny how we have always relied on our "heroes" that come in all shapes, sizes and worlds.  My favorite scene is (not a spoiler), but when the "beast" makes a rag-doll out of Loki and how Loki responds later in the movie.  I think Hiddleston plays his lines to the hilt.  Great comic relief which is in balance with the violent scenes.  All the peripheral movies, Iron Man, Hulk and the like are all tied in together and give purpose to the Avengers movie and although I do not personally collect comic books, I feel as though I have gotten a rounded Marvel Comic book education, if you will, without turning a page.  Collecting Marvel movies to me are as exciting as collecting the books themselves.  Fun for everyone!

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This has to be one of the greatest films I have ever seen. After having the pleasure of seeing this movie eight times in theaters, I'm literally counting down the hours until I can snag this DVD!Having seen all of the previous films leading up to this one, I can say my expectations wer extremely high. Now all I can say is that I wish I could go back and see it for the first time all over again. This film sprung me into a new world of comic books and all that Marvel has to offer, and I love it.But more about the actual movie: Joss Whedon's direction was magnificent in every way. He really captured that Marvel film quality that all the previous movies had with that enticing combination of witty one-liners and bold action that you just won't see anywhere else. All of the characters really meshed together in a funny, shaky start that lead up to a fantastic blend of amazing heroes in the end. All of the actors did a phenomenal job in grasping their characters and taking them deeper than just what you saw. And might I say, Mark Ruffalo did a great job as Bruce Banner. He played the part of the closed off and awkward scientist well.If you didn't see this in theaters, you missed out. Not only was the film amazing on the big screen, but the audience  full of die-hards made it a real experience. I'd recommend this movie to anyone looking for a laugh, action, and and just plain fun. There also wasn't much language, which I thought was great for the younger audiences who will undoubtedly see this game changer if they haven't already.
summary: Most Fun I've Ever had at the Movies!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The Avengers was quite possibly the best movie of the summer it came out. Great characters, fun story, fun action scenes, lots of humor, and a despicable villain.

reviewText: Don't believe your friends who will tell you that this is some pinnacle of achievement in comic book film adaptations.  It isn't.  The super villain, Loki, is a bore that couldn't even make 'Thor' all that interesting.  And the machinations of locating and assembling the Avengers packs all the interest of mailing invites to a high school reunion.All that written, the action sequences are pretty cool, and the casting of the right guy for Banner/Hulk (Ruffalo) gives the rather formulaic business on screen a shot of energy.  Downey Jr. Is very good.Recommended at five bucks.
summary: Overrated - But Worth it For the Upfront Investment in the Story.

reviewerName: Chitina M. Schatz "Been there, Read that"
reviewText: This movie is so much more than a super hero action film, although there's plenty of that! I don't want to give any spoilers, so ill just sum up. This is my husbands type of movie. Last night he talked me into watching it with him, I am so glad. It is unexpectedly a great story, not just a bunch of fighting, and crashing, and senseless violence. The special effects dazzle me, how do they make it look so real??? I am a fan of Thor, Ironman, Captain America, and the Hulk now. I can't wait to see what I've been missing! I figured(as did everyone else) that Loki would be returning for more mayhem in something, without giving thing away, he returns here with his vengeful glory seeking temper pitting hero against hero, friend against friend and brother against brother. I was on the edge of my seat shouting at the tv for half the movie the rest was spent in " omg!!!" And laughter. Yes laughter. So unexpected at the time with hilarious antics. The hulk really does a number on Loki. I just can't say enough good. So I'll end with it is a must see!!! Before I give too much away.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I just didn't find this movie all that entertaining. There was little back story or character development. I could follow along since I'd seen most of the individual hero movies, but if you have not yet seen Iron Man, Hulk, Captain America, etc...you will be scratching your head. This is a movie for comic fans only.Anyway, these random B-list superheroes come together to battle an alien invasion. A basic enough premise, but there was a lot of forced elements. The heroes all disliked each other for no particular reason. When they become a "team", it falls flat, because there isn't really any conflict between any of them. The selection of "Avengers" seems random. The Hulk, who inexplicably halfway through the movie can suddenly control his beast mode. Iron Man and Captain America, who seem reasonably paired. Thor (um, who?) who at least has a connection to the bad guy. And some guy and girl who can shoot arrows well and do a good round kick. Those two should have reasonably died within the first 5 minutes of the battle. If the hammer wielding God, an invincible giant monster, and a super robot suit that flies and shoots lasers is having a hard time with the alien invaders, I doubt a guy with 20 grenade tipped arrows and a girl with a 9mm is going to put up much of a fight.One of the "agents" is killed by the antagonist, and they all seem to be very upset about it, although the movie never establishes why this person is important to any of them. Then they fight a bunch of bad guys in a final act pulled straight from Transformers: Dark Moon. And then they split up. The end.All in all, a reasonable popcorn flick if you just want to see some mindless action.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: "The Avengers" has been a movie in the works for a long time, merging four superhero movies into one. First of all, you have Robert Downey Jr. who brought Iron Man to life with two films, the second had some major scripting problems in my opinion. Then you have Chris Evans reprising his role as Captain America, a movie that had its moments, but was plagued with too many montages in the middle of the movie and a villain that was never fleshed out. Mark Ruffalo stepped in to play the Hulk and Chris Hemsworth (Cabin in the Woods, Snow White and the Huntsmen) returns as Thor, after his movie was much better than many expected.I love the big blockbuster movie just like anybody else, but over the past few years, I've been extremely disappointed with many of the offerings. Most of that was because too many directors (Bay, Wiseman & Anderson) and studios treat their audiences as if they only want explosions and gunfire to be satisfied with their purchase of a movie ticket. Many of the sequels, like "Iron Man 2" seemed to misplace all the money they made from the first "Iron Man" movie and gave us little to no action, more specifically a scene in the beginning and a grand finale. Finally, many of the superhero movies included too many characters instead of fleshing out just one and writing a good script. Three of the four original "Batman" series are included in this along with "Spiderman 3", which was just awful.Keeping that in mind, "The Avengers" on the surface, looks like it could quite possibly meet all of the above criteria for a bad superhero movie, but that just isn't the case. The trailer is a collage of special effects and explosive action. The movie is full of characters like the ones I listed above as well as Samuel L. Jackson's Nick Fury and two other superheroes who didn't get their own movie, Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) and Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner). Yet, much credit needs to be given to writer/director Joss Whedon (Cabin in the Woods, Buffy the Vampire Slayer) who managed to keep a lot of things in check and despite never being handed anything this big, delivered a spectacular superhero movie and the best movie so far this year.The movie certainly isn't perfect. I've wished for a long time that superhero movies could deliver an emotion connection like Christopher Nolan's "Dark Knight" did in 2008, but that movie continues to be the exception. Although what you did get is time at the movie theatre well worth your money. The script is well written and the action isn't sparse. The movie is frequently funny and surprising. There are times in the middle of the film that are very slow but it all comes together with well-timed events and an ending that is exactly what you expect from a band of superheroes that includes the Hulk, defending the earth from destruction.
summary: Not without flaws, but the best SUPERHERO film (other than Dark Knight)
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I ordered this a year ago, but only had a 2.1 sound system. reviewText: The Avengers was awesome and much like the X-Men  with the Wolverine spin off, the movie has improved all the way...... Similar to Batman the Dark Night with Christian Bale, all it takes is the right stars and directing and the Dark Knight sequel has improved the whole Batman series a thousand times. Well, to not spoil the movie for anyone, they had a great choice for the incredible Hulk ( Mark Ruffalo), which was more like the original character versus the ones in the previous Incredible Hulk movies. There was constant action and supporting stars like Samuel L.Jackson added to the movies overall story line. I look forward to seeing the next Avengers but this one is really a keeper. reviewText: Okay, I admit it. I am an action movie junkie. And I read all of the action hero comic books growing up. So, I have eagerly awaited each new installment (movie) of my favorite heroes. Iron Man, Thor, Captain America. Marvel has done a "marvelous" job of putting together a series of movies that culminate in The Avengers.I love the characters in this movie and the dialogue is pithy and funny and entertaining. Plus some of the action takes you by surprise (wait until you see the confrontation between the Hulk and Loki). I saw this in the movie theater with my son and determined right then and there that this movie would be added to my collection at home. And the Blu-ray version is fantastic. The soundtrack and the sound effects are nothing short of amazing and the quality is pristine. It is a real treat to watch and will bring our family great enjoyment again and again.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I rarely bother seeing movies in the theaters, but this is one I choose to go do it. It was great. I could not wait until I got it home to watch, and now that I did, I am still thrilled with it.The movie has a lot of action, an interesting story line, and the characters all have a backstory which even if you did not see the individual titles leading up to this release, I think you could follow. Yes, there were references back to things that happened in the other films, but I think any one would enjoy it as a stand alone.I, on the other hand, intend to take a weekend soon and watch both Ironman movies, both Hulk movies, Captain America and Thor again before once again watching this movie.I look forward to seeing all the extras included in the next couple weekends.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: From the technical perspective, it is outstanding.  The merger of CGI with digital green screen and motion capture is superb!I wish the movie were longer but perhaps that's the signature of a great movie; it leaves you wanting more.It's well structured, although a bit shallow and muddlesome in places.  I still would not detract from it.I cannot speak to how well it adheres to the comic storyline.  I hope someone will.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is actually a pretty good movie.  I tend to like somewhat serious movies that provoke thought.  And this one is certainly no such thing.  But it is pretty entertaining.  The great Stan Lee finally realized his dream and got all of his superheroes together in one movie.In my view, Mark Ruffalo gave the best performance in the movie, as Dr. Banner/Hulk.  His character was well-written and he had an opportunity to show a wider set of acting skills than the others.  Robert Downey Jr. plays his usual cocky, cynical, smartass-genius character.  He's got that down pat.  He plays Ironman the same way he plays Sherlock Holmes.  Tom Hiddleston continues his role as Loki and does just as good a job here as he did in "Thor".  Chris Hemsworth, Chris Evan, Stellan Skarsgaard, Scarlett Johannson, Jeremy Renner, and Samuel Jackson round out the all-star cast.The ambitious Loki and his allies want to get their hands on the Tesserac.  If you saw Captain America, then you are already familiar with this item.  Using the power of the cube, Loki summons his army from far way to conquer the earth, enslave the humans, etc.  Our heroes battle it out with the aliens and saves the day.  The End.I rented this movie through my XBox.  You do need a Gold Membership in order to do that.  You can also rent via your PS3.  And lastly, through Amazon.  Ofcourse, if you want subtitles, you can always just buy or rent the DVD.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This film is not only for those who grew up reading comic books. The stellar cast, clever and intelligent dialogue, and interesting back stories revealed in this movie are worth experiencing more than once. The special effects are great, and the entire premise is treated with such skill and respect by the actors that it becomes easy to believe in the existence of this Marvel Universe. Definitely a 'keeper' for anyone's video library.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I wanted entertainment and I was given entertainment. Even though Joss Whedon touched this flick with his shiny presence, I didn't expect to like it, much. I'm not a comic book fan.This assumption was wrong. I really enjoyed the entire thing!Yes, there are a few plot holes. Yes, there are a few bits that simply don't work (not giving spoilers). And yes, you really need to watch the companion films for this thing to make sense. But if you just sit back and let it flow you'll be carried away.One big apprehension was Mark Ruffalo's replacement as The Hulk. He works, makes the character better and more believable (if you can believe in big green angry men).Special effects? Well, if they'd sucked I'd have blamed Robert Downy Jr.'s salary. They did not suck!Writing? A whole lot of territory was remapped and filled here. Motivations were built well, personalities meshed and clashed. One-liners delivered flawlessly and some of the best scenes I've watched flashed past. There were many times where I damn near shed tears laughing. There are even two scenes that caught me so hard I had to pause the movie until my vision cleared...this hasn't happened since Pulp Fiction.Drop your pennies into the maw and enjoy yourself.
summary: Drop your pennies into the maw and enjoy yourself
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I really like Robert Downey JR.  Even back when he was a watery eyed druggie I thought he was gifted.  He is just great as Iron Man and I liked those movies too.  Loaded with talented actors and actresses this movie has star power but it would be a dud for sure if the writing was bad.  The story is almost unimportant with all the glitzy action scenes and great costumes but it is, in fact, pretty good.  The dialogue is better than most super hero movies, too.  I saw that a lot of other viewers gave it 4 and 5 stars too.  If you like action / adventure or even fantasy type movies, you should check this out.  You won't be sorry.

reviewText: After five origin movies (Iron Man,Iron Man 2,The Incredible Hulk,Captain America: The First Avenger,Thor), The Avengers ares finally assembled in an action-packed film directed by Joss Whedon. Putting all these superheroes into one movie couldn't have been easy, but Joss managed to give all the characters screen time, some more than others. The movie is a little slow at the beginning, but it picks up about forty-five minutes into it. I never cared for Loki in last year's Thor, but the character has grown in The Avengers. I was skeptical about Mark Ruffalo playing Bruce Dr. Banner/Hulk, but he played the character wonderfully. Finally, we get a Hulk that actually resembles the comic Hulk! The alien invading plot has been done to death (most recently inTransformers: Dark of the Moon), but it worked out well in The Avengers. Overall, I loved the DVD and I though the movie was great thanks to Joss's quirky dialogue.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: What a ridiculous year for movies 2012 has already been and we still have eight months of it left to look forward to. Just look at some of this year's big releases: a new Pixar film with a female lead, Christopher Nolan's final trip to Gotham City, Ridley Scott's return to the sci-fi genre, Peter Jackson's return to Middle Earth, and reboots of our friendly neighborhood web slinger and one of the better Philip K. Dick adaptations. And that's just scratching the surface.Marvel has had something up their sleeve for quite some time though. A gargantuan superhero project they've been teasing since 2008 in five different movies that fan boys and comic book geeks have been foaming at the mouth for featuring one of the most star-studded casts the likes of any movie has ever seen before. That's right, boys and girls; The Avengers is finally upon us.I was riding high on everything Joss Whedon since I'm still feeling the after-effects of the jaw-dropping greatness that is The Cabin in the Woods. However, I refused to get excited for The Avengers. I had doubts that mostly resided in every character getting the appropriate amount of screen time. That and every ounce of anticipation in my body is currently invested in both Prometheus and The Dark Knight Rises. The Avengers wasted little time taking full advantage of that.The movie is explosive right from the very first scene and throughout its entirety. The special effects are incredible. With its rather massive budget ($220 million, a number they nearly made back in international ticket sales alone before it even had the chance to hit the states), it's fantastic to see that they've spared no expense making The Avengers look and sound absolutely phenomenal. The technology used in the film is insane, as well. The tesseract and everything otherworldly will probably be the first thing that comes to mind, but SHIELD has some really amazing devices as does Tony Stark. All of it is just dripping with style.You couldn't ask for better performances from the cast. The Avengers thrives on these clashing personalities and you can't help but get sucked into it. Much of the action is these well-known superheroes fighting amongst themselves and beating the snot out of each other in the process. These are some of the best scenes in the movie, especially when Thor (Chris Hemsworth) first shows up. It's only topped by when Bruce Banner (Mark Ruffalo) first turns into The Hulk.I'm not the biggest Hulk fan, although I did enjoy The Incredible Hulk from 2008. I can say with confidence that he has never been this glorious. He is arguably the highlight of The Avengers. He does some pretty innovative things with the destruction he leaves behind and one scene in particular that he shares with Loki (Tom Hiddleston) will leave you with the urge to stand up and cheer.Everybody is going to be drawn to somebody different in the action packed extravaganza. Aside from The Hulk, Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr) is freaking great. He steals nearly every scene he's a part of by basically just being himself and everything that comes out of his mouth is hilarious. Joss Whedon is able to squeeze in these little bits of humor when you're least expecting it that helps makes things endlessly entertaining at all times. Like the guy playing Galaga, Captain America trying to convince two cops to give him a perimeter, or Thor mentioning Loki was adopted. Tom Hiddleston continues to be impressive, as well. I thought he did a fine job in Thor, but upped his game in The Deep Blue Sea. His return to the Loki character is almost majestic in this evil super villain sense. Loki is downright ferocious at times. His scene with Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) is magnificently menacing.It is downright ridiculous that a superhero movie is not only this good, but is pretty much already in the books. The summer movie season has officially started and it feels like nothing will ever be able to measure up to this. That means that this year is going to be downright marvelous for movies or studios are going to pull the trigger a little too early. The truth is that you can't scream enough praise for this movie. Its two hours and twenty minute runtime goes by in the blink of an eye, its cast is astounding, its special effects are beautiful, and there are a few really dynamic camera angles thrown in for good measure. The Avengers is easily the best and most action packed movie in Marvel's arsenal.Be sure you stay through the credits; ALL the way through the credits. There are a few surprises to enjoy hidden in there. Earth's mightiest heroes have been given the exceptional treatment they truly deserve that will demand repeat viewings. All that's really left to be said is that The Dark Knight Rises and The Amazing Spider-Man certainly have their work cut out for them.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: In the 1960s, Marvel Comics pioneered mature storylines for its super heroes, of whom many have been successfully adapted into blockbuster films (Spiderman).  The Avengers were a group with individual icons like Iron Man who had already established identities contrary to The Fantastic Four and X Men.  Marvel began to feature stand alone films that methodically built this core of characters, and several years later, it has culminated in The Avengers, a thoroughly entertaining adventure that never fails to engage and `marvel' its intended audience.  As orchestrated by versatile writer/director and comic book fan Joss Whedon (Buffy the Vampire Slayer), the results set a high standard in filmic super heroics; it's nirvana, a comic lover's dream come true.The Tesseract is a cube with unknown powers and coveted by the fiendish Loki, Thor's half brother.  Kept for study by SHIELD, the elite security agency, (and once possessed by The Red Skull in Captain America: The First Avenger), the cube can open a doorway to another dimension.  When Loki steals the cube to unleash a demon army and conquer the earth, the SHIELD agents are no match for his supernatural powers.  What to do?  Who ya gonna call?Well, there's nothing like `puttin' the band together' for the first time.  Assembled by SHIELD director Nick Fury (Samuel Jackson) and aided by Agent Coulson (Clark Gregg), the Avengers Initiative sought to collect special operatives in the event of an insurmountable threat that was beyond human response.  These Avengers comprise of six extraordinary individuals: an otherworldly warrior, Thor (Chris Hemsworth), a genetically enhanced superhuman from the past, Steve Rogers AKA Captain America (Chris Evans), a meek scientist, Dr. Bruce Banner (Mark Ruffalo) and his anger induced, gamma radiated monster, The Hulk; inventor Tony Stark, in super armor as Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), and two SHIELD agents, master archer Hawkeye, Clint Barton (Jeremy Renner), and top assassin Black Widow, Natasha Romanoff (Scarlett Johansson).When Loki's legion of soldiers descend on Manhattan, it's `Avengers Assemble' time.  Drawn by remarkable circumstances and led by Captain America, it's teamwork at its finest as The Avengers battle these nasty hordes to save the earth.After initially bickering and fighting each other, it is fascinating to witness such disparate personalities coalesce into a fighting unit as they flow from self to selflessness.  This film can stand on its own for newbies not familiar with the previous films, but it certainly does not hurt to have seen Captain America: The First Avenger, Thor, Iron Man, and The Incredible Hulk.  Whedon and company neatly tie the threads of those films together with sufficient focus given to each hero's personal life.We learn some interesting background on Romanoff and Barton, who you think would be outmatched by their superhuman colleagues, but they more than hold their own and figure prominently in the explosive climax.  Rogers, the honorable, idyllic soldier, has to adjust to a world like a modern day Rip Van Winkle.  Dr. Banner keeps his anger at bay, but what will that mean for the Avengers if it can't be controlled?  Whedon also cleverly includes familiar supporting characters e.g. Stark's assistant, Pepper (Gwyneth Paltrow), from other the films.All the stars perform ably including Tom Hiddleston who is appropriately devious as Loki.  Downey, who clearly improvised much of his dialogue, has a rousing, good time. Jackson embodies Fury as the manipulative leader who does whatever it takes to safeguard humanity.This is the third movie version of The Hulk, and while Ruffalo does a very good job as the sensitive and haunted Banner, his alter ego beast actually behaves so unpredictably that some of his actions become comedic and the results are a riot.  To say more would spoil some hilarious moments.  The filmmakers got this Hulk right.A couple things don't quite add up like how does The Hulk decide to be a do-gooder at a critical moment?  Who is the mysterious Council (resembling the Syndicate from The X Files) that SHIELD answers to, and what are their intentions?  There are, however, nice touches like the Stark building in the finale and what is left of its logo as an obvious tribute to the Avengers.  When the grand showdown is imminent, there is a marvelous circular shot of the Avengers that is iconic.When the evil army attacks, one is reminded of Ghostbusters and the apocalyptic scenes of Superman II and any Transformers film.  Whedon, though, never forgets to include intimate moments and details.  Although each Avenger gets a heroic moment to shine, the film never loses sight of personal loss amid the spectacle.  The film is also about self sacrifice, and people do perish in this film including a major character.Despite a 143 minute running time, the film is full of subplots and well-paced action, and every bit of the enormous, effects laden budget is on the big screen. The Avengers is perhaps not the best super hero film ever made, The Dark Knight being the apex, but it is the most complete, entertaining, multi-hero film to date.  The question now is what do you do for an encore, and how can anyone hope to top let alone match this achievement?  It would require the abilities of a James Cameron or Peter Jackson, or maybe studio executives can plead for Whedon's return.  Let's hope so. (Do stay for the end credits for a double dose treat.)

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I'm not really into Marvel so I was really surprised that I really did enjoy this movie. Though, I was a tinsy bit confused about what was going on, then I watched Thor, maybe this was just me, but after watching Thor the Avengers made a lot more sense to me. The story really didn't get intresting till Thor came, and no it's not because Chris plays him, but after watching Thor he grew on me. Anyways, this movie really is a great movie and I'm a girl so.., if you don't like this movie then something is wrong with you and you don't know what a great, action packed movie is.SpoilersS.H.I.E.L.D. Director Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson) arrives at one of his agency's facilities during an evacuation. The Tesseract, an energy source of unknown potential, has activated. It opens a portal through space and the exiled Norse god Loki (Tom Hiddleston) steps through. Loki takes the Tesseract and also takes control of the minds of several SHIELD personnel, including Dr. Erik Selvig (Stellan Skarsgrd) and Agent Clint "Hawkeye" Barton (Jeremy Renner), to aid him in his getaway. As SHIELD personnel pull out of their base, some pursuing Loki and others merely fleeing, the ground beneath the base collapses and it's destroyed. In response to the attack, Fury re-activates the Avengers Initiative. First he pulls Agent Natasha Romanoff (Scarlett Johansson), a.k.a. the Black Widow, out of an interrogation (tied to a chair, she seems to be the victim rather than the interrogator, but appearances are deceiving). Fury sends her to India to find and recruit Dr. Bruce Banner (Mark Ruffalo), a.k.a. the Hulk. At the same time Agent Phil Coulson (Clark Gregg) approaches "Iron Man" Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr.) and requests that he review Dr. Selvig's research. Fury himself approaches Steve Rogers (Chris Evans), a.k.a. Captain America, with an assignment to retrieve the Tesseract from Loki. During his exile, Loki encountered the Chitauri, an alien race seeking to conquer the galaxy. In exchange for the Tesseract, the Chitauri agree to help Loki subjugate Earth. Suiting up, Captain America and Iron Man travel to Germany to apprehend Loki, who is recovering iridium needed to stabilize the Tesseract's power, and demanding that the civilians kneel before him. Loki quickly surrenders when the two heroes arrive, and he is escorted to a SHIELD helicarrier, a high-tech, flying aircraft carrier. However, Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Loki's half-brother and the Norse God of thunder, arrives and attempts to free Loki so he can reason with him on his own, but he gets into a fight with Iron Man and Captain America. The fight ends in a stalemate. Eventually, Loki is taken to the helicarrier and placed in a glass cell designed to hold the Hulk. Fury explains that if Loki attempts to escape, even by merely cracking the glass, a shaft will open below him and he'll plummet to Earth and possibly be killed. The Avengers, now brought together, argue and deliberate over how to approach Loki and the revelation that SHIELD plans to harness the Tesseract's power to develop weapons, a discovery made by Rogers. Fury admits that the events in New Mexico a year before (recounted in "Thor") made SHIELD aware of other races on other worlds, some of whom may see Earth as an easy target. The decision was made to produce weapons with the Tesseract as a means of deterrence. As the group argues, Clint Barton and Loki's possessed agents attack the helicarrier, disabling one of its engines in flight. While Stark and Rogers attempt to restart the damaged engine, Romanoff tries to prevent Dr. Banner from turning into the Hulk and destroying the ship from inside. Her attempt fails and she's chased through the ship until Thor takes up the battle to pacify the beast and manages to fell him briefly with a hit from his hammer, Mjolnir. While fighting Barton, Romanoff slams him into a guard rail, and the blow to the head breaks Loki's mind control. After the Hulk falls from the ship, Thor is tricked into Loki's holding cell by Loki himself, who has recovered his scepter and releases the cell and allows Thor to plummet. Loki is held at bay briefly by Agent Coulson who is also tricked by one of Loki's holographic projections - Coulson is stabbed in the back by the real Loki. Coulson later shoots Loki with a blast from an unidentified weapon, one that harnesses the power of the Destroyer. Coulson dies while Fury tries to save his life. Thor escapes from the cell a split second before it hits the ground. Banner wakes up in his human form after crashing into an abandoned factory. Fury uses Coulson's death to motivate the Avengers to work as a team. Stark and Rogers realize that simply defeating them will not be enough for Loki. He needs to overpower them in a very public way so as to validate himself as ruler of Earth. Using a device built by Dr. Selvig, Loki opens a portal to the Chitauri home world over Manhattan, summoning a Chitauri invasion. The Avengers rally in defense of New York, but quickly come to the conclusion that they will be overwhelmed as wave after wave of Chitauri descend upon Earth. With help from the reformed Barton, Captain America and Thor evacuate civilians while Dr. Banner transforms into the Hulk and goes after Loki, beating him into submission in Tony Stark's penthouse. Romanoff makes her way, with a little help from the Chitauri, to the device that holds the portal open (conveniently located on the roof of the Stark Building) and hits Dr. Selvig over the head, freeing him of Loki's control. Dr. Selvig reveals that Loki's staff can be used to close the portal. Meanwhile, the council overrides Fury and scrambles a jet that fires a nuclear missile at Manhattan to end the invasion. Iron Man intercepts the missile and directs it at the portal and the Chitauri base before running out of oxygen and plummeting back to Earth, but the Hulk catches him as he falls. A dazed Stark, awakened by the Hulk's roar, offers to take the team out for shawarma, but they decide to apprehend Loki first. Thor escorts Loki and the Tesseract back to Asgard, while Fury notes that the Avengers will go their separate ways until a new world-threatening menace emerges. In a mid-credits scene, the Chitauri leader the Other tells his master that it is futile to attack Earth, as fighting the Avengers is like courting death. His master turns, revealing himself to be Thanos. After further credits, the Avengers are shown eating together in a shawarma joint; the team looks worn out and no one speaks.

reviewText: I felt this movie ended up cheating the Captain America and the Hawkeye/Black Widow storylines. Mark Ruffalo wasn't my favorite choice for the Bruce Banner/Hulk character - I'd much rather have seen Edward Norton reprise this role.  The movie overall was okay, but I really think they could have done the other characters more justice by decreasing the RDJ scenes and increasing the others (particularly with bringing CA forward into the present time).But I still love Loki as the bad guy.  Keep bringing back the mischief-maker!

reviewText: It's been called the greatest superhero movie of all time.  Whether you believe the hype or not, you have to admit: there is something undeniably charming about THE AVENGERS.  In the hands of writer/director Joss Whedon, this film is a rollicking good time--not serious in the sense of Chris Nolan's Batman films, yet not campy like the Joel Schumacher Batman films.  Fans of Whedon's work will immediately know what to expect: nonstop action blended with a strong (and quick) sense of humor, under-laced with nuanced character development.The film pits some of our earlier favorites--Downey Jr.s' Ironman, Helmsworth's Thor, Evans's Captain America--against Loki.  This isn't the Lokia from THOR, however; here, Tom Hiddleston's villain is transformed into, simply, a bad***.  He kicks butt and doesn't bother with names.  Oh yeah, and he's bringing an invading interdimensional army of nasties.  Can our crew, rallied by Samuel L. Jackson's stalwart Nick Fury, stand up to the onslaught?Of course they can.  There's no doubt about that, ever.  This is an utterly optimistic film--and therein lies its charm.  Don't get me wrong--I'm a Nolan fan, I love his Batman films, their flaws and all.  But there's a lot to be said about a film that revels in the utter majesty of the superhero, with a childlike wonder: these guys can do no wrong.  And they don't.  This is a fun, quick, fanciful film in the grand tradition, anchored by a superb script (Whedon's known for that, in case you weren't aware) and stellar acting.  Rejoining us are Scarlett Johannson (with a lot more to do than in IRON MAN 2, where she was basically eye candy); Clark Gregg (wholly ingrained in this universe as Agent Coulson); Gwyneth Paltrow, Stellan Skarsgaard, and others.  THE AVENGERS welcomes Jeremy Renner as Hawkeye, Cobie Smulders as Agent Hiller, and particularly Mark Ruffalo as Bruce Banner/The Hulk.  Some of the film's most memorable scenes revolve around the latter character, and his innate desire for destruction vs. his inner conflict (Ruffalo is partially responsible for the former and entirely responsible for the latter, and perhaps deserves an Oscar nom, though he won't get one).Here is the true strength of THE AVENGERS, aside from its pure joy factor: not one single character/actor carries the show.  You may think that, with a superstar like Robert Downey Jr. onboard, that he film will follow Ironman and the others will be supporting roles.  Not so.  This is an ensemble film, plain and simple.  Ironman, Loki, and the Hulk may have some of the more memorable scenes, but this film belongs to the entire cast and crew.  It is, indeed, a film in which everyone contributes--and the end product shows the effort.  Whether or not you believe THE AVENGERS is the best superhero movie yet made (personally, I don't, but that's one man's opinion), you cannot deny that it is certainly among the top tier.  It is delightful, hilarious, thrilling, and plainly fun.  You can ask for more, yes, but you probably won't get it.  THE AVENGERS delivers.  Plain and simple.

reviewText: Unlike some comic book/graphic novel devotees, I have always enjoyed both Marvel and DC productions.  This film is a great trilogy with both Thor and Captain America, and am definitely looking forward to more installments in this franchise.  Mark Ruffalo and Tom Hiddleston were superb in this one.  Would really liked to have seen Laurence Fishburne as Dr Fury, though!  Some great lines in this film.  Particularly liked the comparisons of Thor and Loki as demigods with the others who are super humans.  Lots of great special effects.  My only complaint is that the opening sequence is too obscure and shot too closely.  Would really have liked this opening sequence to be a little longer and with a little more clarity in the framing of The Other and his/its Chitauri.  Othewise, superb film.

reviewText: Storytelling as an art? What's that? And, who cares anyway? When Hollywood makes tons of money off of bad movies, then where's the financial incentive to make decent films? 2012 is turning out to the worst year in decades - and I have been going to the movies for over 40 years, so that's saying something - for really bad blockbusters: first, Hunger Games; next, Dark Shadows; and now The Avengers! (WANT TO SEE WHAT GOOD FILM MAKING LOOKS LIKE? I'VE PRAISED EVERY ONE OF THESE FILMS WITH A 5-STAR REVIEW:The Informant!andNever Back Down (Single-Disc Edition)andX-Men: First Class (+ Digital Copy) [Blu-ray] andFarewellandThe Social Network (Two-Disc Collector's Edition)and(Father) Damien (de Veuster of Hawaii) [VHS] andBattle For TerraandThe Secret of My SuccessandCommon Ground [VHS])I am so sick and tired of New York City, specifically the island of Manhattan, being attacked in the movies. Hello! It was attacked in real life only a little over 10 years ago costing the lives of over 3,000+ real people, including my brother's co-worker, co-worker's wife and unborn child! But what is really despicable is that at the very end of the The Avengers you briefly get to see a real-life news photo from 9/11 mourning the dead. That's just plain, disgusting exploitation!But lets not stop there! At the end of the film we get to briefly hear a local New York State Senator rant about how our Avenger heroes "wrecked Manhattan." That our heroes who just risked their lives in a 1,000+ ways are to "blame" for all the destruction! Fine! I agree many politicians are real jerks, but to put the letter "D" for Democrat next to this Senator's name speaks volumes about the films real message: Democrats holding elective office are nothing more than ungrateful, winy creeps! That's real cute! I thought Hollywood was sooooooo liberal! If you going to interject politics into a film then why not put a "R" for Republicans after the Senator's name? After all, the Republicans in Congress fought tooth and nail to prevent the establishment of a Federally funded medical fund for First Responders whose health was permanently impaired by breathing in all the toxic debris that was released into the air!The Avengers is also plain boring with the most two-dimensional characters in the history of film making! Sure I wanted the good guys to win! Sure the guys have cute muscles and the gals are all pretty! But, really now, who cares when there is zero character development and the storyline is about as exciting as watching Frosty The Snowman for the tenth time!The last third of the Avengers is nothing more than war porn! I will never watch another super hero movie that has a character from The Avengers as long as I live! Even for free, or if Hollywood offers me a million dollars! Overall,  Hollywood has done a decent job with the X-men and the Fanatic Four, but for some reason the right-wing kooks who control the Avenger characters have turned them into nothing more than an exploitative moneymaking machine. No wonder why Stan Lee was so happy in his cameo appearance at the end of the film! It's just too bad he and the rest of Hollywood has to stoop so low to make a buck!For those of you who have never taken a film class in college before: A GOOD FILM HAS AN INTERESTING STORY AND ACTORS THAT INTERACT WELL WITH EACH OTHER! It really is not too hard to imagine! You could even write it on the back of a matchbook cover!See:Hollywood Left and Right: How Movie Stars Shaped American Politicsand The State of the American Mind: Stupor and Pathetic Docility: Volume One and City of Dust: Illness, Arrogance, and 9/11 (FT Press Science)and The Toxic Clouds Of 9/11: A Looming Health Disaster and A Teachable Moment: A Facilitator's Guide to Activities for Processing, Debriefing, Reviewing and Reflection and Grow Up!: How Taking Responsibility Can Make You a Happy AdultFootnote 1: By the way, Frosty, The Snowman is a much more entertaining story than The Avengers. It has stood the test of time! Unlike The Avengers, which will be quickly forgotten! But I certainly wouldn't want to watch Frosty for the 10th time!Footnote 2: Why do so many people commenting on my review hate the Fantastic Four? It has zero war porn, has a sense of humor and is totally enjoyable without exploiting anyone! All I can say is: I'm so incredibly glad I see the world very differently than my critics!
summary: About as Exciting as Watching 'Frosty The Snowman' for the Tenth Time!

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I enjoyed The Avengers, mostly. It was nice to see all of the Marvel characters get their due onscreen, and only Hawkeye felt short-shrifted by the plot (he's the only one we really know nothing about heading into the film, and we don't actually get "him" as a character until the third act). A lot could (and probably should) have gone wrong putting all these larger than life superheroes into one movie, but it is to the credit of writer/director Joss Whedon that, for the most part, the film holds together quite well.That being said, taken on its own, this is a good film, not a great one. With so many characters to re-introduce and have share in the spotlight, there is no true protagonist who's arc we follow. As a result, with the exception of some really good set pieces, the first two thirds of the film can tend to drag. And the final battle, while well-choreographed and filled with really smart, funny moments (Hulk truly shines in this third act) goes on for too long, and has no rise in tension from the start to the finish. The villains in the movie are complete pushovers, and the endless armada that attacks Manhattan is comprised of the same disposable foot soldiers ad nauseum, with none of them posing any kind of threat to any of our heroes. Loki himself was defeated in Thor by the God of Thunder solo, so now with Cap, Hulk, Tony Stark and S.H.I.E.L.D. also arrayed against him, it's no surprise that we never worry about the outcome.The whole film in essence feels like a re-introduction to all the characters we've already established in the previous movies, which, obviously, was necessary, and because there's so much set-up involved it's understandable that the plot would be extremely bare-bones and generic so that focus is given to these characters. Joss Whedon is an expert storyteller, and he leaps the hurdles that this project came entrenched with deftly. Honestly, no one could do a better job with the material than the man who turned $39 million and demand from a small rabid fanbase into the best sci-fi film since Aliens (Serenity, go watch it now if you haven't already). The stage is set for an explosively fun Avengers 2.So I expect to get a fair amount of slams for not gushing more over the movie. I did enjoy it (on second viewing I enjoyed it slightly more than the first time) but this is not a film that I, as a big super-hero/fantasy/sci-fi fan, am ever going to go ga-ga over. I think it did what it needed to do, which was effectively set up the franchise that is to follow, and do so with humor and heart. As the prologue to what is to follow, I think it's top notch. As a standalone film, I think it comes in several ticks below the Nolan Batman flicks (that have their own issues) and the Donner Superman films. However, this is sooo much better than any of the recent X-Men or Fantastic Four movies that it shouldn't even be mentioned along side those lame-duck series.I look forward to the next Avengers movie, and hope that Joss Whedon is still at the helm when it comes.
summary: The Avengers is a Success! But that's different from being a Great Movie...
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: There's really nothing to complain about with The Avengers. The acting, script, action, comedy, special effects...it all works. Flawlessly. reviewText: If you like basic, willful suspension of disbelief, fun, fast-paced action movies, then the Marvel universe movies are for you. The banter between the characters in this particular film is fun, and it offers a chance to teach kids about the importance of humility and teamwork if you want to. Or, you can just laugh at the silliness of it all.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Earth's mightiest heroes--Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), the Hulk (Mark Ruffalo), Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Captain America (Chris Evans), the Black Widow (Scarlett Johansen), and Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner)--assemble to confront Loki (Tom Hiddleston) and his army of extraterrestrials.When I read that Joss Whedon had taken the helm of this production, I felt optimistic that it was in good hands, given his solid work with super-powered characters on TV (Buffy The Vampire Slayer and Angel) and in comics (The X-Men).  I was not disappointed.  "The Avengers" is the big, action-packed film it needed to be, but it also features sparkling dialogue and the efficient characterization required in such an ensemble piece.  This strength is demonstrated in a scene in which the heroes' differences emerge in a heated debate about tactics and motivations; everyone becomes alarmed over how agitated Bruce Banner is becoming, since they know what may result.  This dialogue-driven sequence stands out even among the various face-offs between heroes and the huge battle at the end.I have loved all the movies out of Marvel Studios because, whatever the individual merits of each film, they have stayed true to the characters.  "The Avengers" marks the culmination of Phase I.  Now that all the origin stories are out of the way, I'm excited to see what comes next.

reviewText: I went to this movie hoping it would be at least ok.BOY WAS I WRONG!!!This movie balanced all the characters and was highly entertaining!!!This might have been the BEST superhero movie I've even seen. And I think I've seen all of them so that's saying a lot! My wife and I are looking forward to seeing Avengers II in a year or so.The plot and character development was exceptional! Writing and acting was superb. CGI was very well done and was, for the most part, necessary for the story. This was the rare movie that I would have preferred to have been a little longer. The Blu-ray picture was great as was the sound. It will be most interesting to see if they can even match this production on the next outing.HIGHLY recommended! I would rate this, at the very least, 9.5 to 9.75 out of 10 - it was very nearly a perfect movie.

reviewText: 3D version -Didn't see the movie in the theater since I am on the road quite a bit and have a bit of money invested in our home theater over the years.We loved the action and how the movie is starting to integrate all the characters who to this time have been singles.having just watched Avatar 3D only two days before my wife and friends were a bit jaded on how this looked in 3D. They make good use of the 3D but not of the same character or capabilities (shouldn't be a big surprise). But when you watch something designed and filmed like Avatar in 3D you do feel a bit cheated in the 3D effects. Especially during the fight scenes.The sound track matched the graphics and enhanced the interaction between the viewer and 3D movie.we'll continue to grow our 3D library but will be critical. At least this one was not as dark (as in night) viewing in 3D as Thor was.Thor seemed like it was a night movie most of the time. I know part is due to the LG glasses but when you watch Avenger in 3D we didn't pick up on the same dark feeling.

reviewText: There's only a few things that I saw wrong with this film after viewing it a second time after I saw it at the theatre after it came out and the one scene where Mark Ruffallo playing the part of the Hulk when he was in the New York Scene getting ready to go after the giant metal creature thing in the middle of the street as it was coming at him changed into the Hulk within a split few seconds after he told Captain America that that was his secret "that he was always angry", the Hulk is supposed to have a transition period as to where he turns into the Hulk as the transition takes some time and he turned too quick as there is another scene where they show him fighting against the Black Widow on the helicarrier and that transition took some time, if he's capable of turning so quickly then why do they show him turning into the Hulk within a few seconds of being angry (?) - (but I could never understand as to why he wants to destroy everything if he's a superhero and is supposed to be helping his fellow man and friends that are also superheros? - the rivalry is nice to see sometimes amongst them but it just doesn't make a whole lot of sense), but I understand that it's just escapest entertainment but I often wonder how they make it look so real.Also in the movie Thor that has some transition stuff in it to this film - How did the rainbow bridge get rebuilt after it was destroyed in that movie? I guess there is going to be a sequel to that movie as well?I still dig that scene where Loki (Thor's brother) when battling the Hulk in Stark Tower tells Hulk he's a God and won't tolerate humans telling him what to do gets picked up and slammed around like a rag doll and then after the attack he looks as if he just got hit by a freight train and is thinking to himself as to what the hell just hit him, and then Hulk says 'foolish god' as he walks off.

reviewText: As fantastically great as Marvel's The Avengers is (and that is *very*!), I am seeing this product priced far higher than it has any right to be.  No one should ever pay more than about fifty bucks for a limited edition copy of a single movie.  I am seeing this priced almost forty dollars *higher* than that (or more!)!  If you want a truly collectible copy of this movie, look for the Marvel Cinematic Universe: Phase One set.  It will be released April 2, 2013 and has ALL the Marvel movies that lead up to Avengers, and Avengers itself, with tons of extras, and an awesome suitcase with a glowing Tesseract!Marvel Cinematic Universe Assembled CollectorsAvoid the Avengers this review is attached to if it is still overpriced.EDIT: 5/4/2013 - I have been informed in the comments that you can get this for $20 at Best Buy.  That is very much worth getting, and the movie is still amazing.  Please understand that my rating on this movie is only to serve as a warning for people not to spend too much on an otherwise phenomenally good movie.EDIT: 1/12/2014 - The price has dropped to a more reasonable (but still too-high) seventy dollars, so I'm upping the stars to 3.

reviewText: I like the Avengers, but it is not one of my favorite Marvel movies.  I guess because there are too many heroes taking up space in this movie.  It's hard (for me) to decide which one I admire.  But the plot is decent.  It takes a little while for the action to kick off, but when it does , it is good.  TOO MANY SCENES WERE GIVEN TO IRON MAN in this movie.  That's really my only complaint.  It seemed as if Iron Man was the major star, and all of the other characters were secondary.  I would have given this DVD five stars, were it not for too many scenes focusing on Iron Man. But it is decent, so I give it four.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This movie was so good, I had to go back and watch all the movies for the individual characters again!  Plus, I ordered all  the DVD's from Amazon for my collection.  It was just pure entertainment, with fun characters, action and fantastic graphics.  I had never read the comic books, but I didn't feel I had to in order to follow the story.  Joss Whedon was the perfect choice to direct this movie and to help develop the story.  His other ventures, especially with Serenity and Firefly, are good examples of his style and he brought that feel to this movie too.  You cannot beat the cast of the movie; Robert Downey, Jr., Chris Evans, Mark Ruffalo, Chris Hemsworth, Jeremy Renner, Scarlett Johannson and of course, Samuel L. Jackson.  Each and every one of this cast portrayed their characters so well that I almost believe there is a Captain America and Iron Man out there somewhere!The story flows so smoothly that I didn't even think about the premise of good guys vs bad guys.  There just wasn't time for that because the dialogue was engrossing and the fights were exciting.  I also liked the humor, even if some of it was a little too obvious.  This is just a good movie and if you don't see it somewhere, you will be missing out on some fun.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Good movie I enjoyed the humor an action. I will not review if I have to add words to satisfy a friggin computer.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This was a great movie. There was a great balance between acting, action, and storyline that will make this enjoyable for older comic book fans, and new moviegoers. I was happy with Banner's character, even though it wasn't Norton, Ruffallo did a great job; oh, and Hulk looked his best this time around. Captain America was the same guy from the comic book, which I appreciated that they didn't change him. The tension was there, and so was the camaraderie from the comics. Now I'm just waiting to see what's next!

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: --------------------------------------------------------------"Marvel's The Avengers"(2012)--------------------------------------------------------------This is without question the best live-action superhero film made to date -- it hits all the right marks and leaves audiences eager for more. It's thrilling, it's funny, the special effects look great, and the action feels real (no stiff, overly-armored Batman here!) and it reflects the appeal of comicbooks and comicbook culture better than any other adaptation I've seen.All praise is due to director Joss Whedon, who also co-wrote the script and (miraculously!) kept this from being one of those blechhy, top-heavy, written-by-Hollywood-committee monoliths that we've seen so far. The exposition is kept to a minimum, the lulls are lightened by classic Whedon humor, and the actors are treated like actors, not sort sort of squishy furniture you drape special effects around. Whedon, a guy that actors love, coaxes superior performances from Mark Ruffalo, Robert Downey Jr. and Scarlet Johansson, while Chris Evans' and Chris Hemsworth's presences are greatly enhanced from their solo debuts in "Captain America" and "Thor"; ditto for Thom Hiddleston as their nemesis, Loki, who was sort of okay in "Thor," but great here. Samuel Jackson, intoning and pretentious in his role as Machiavellian uber-spy Nick Fury, drains the life out of every scene he's in, but that's sort of to be expected, and I'm willing to overlook it since the rest of the film is so awesome.I'm 1000% serious when I say Joss Whedon should be appointed the head of a studio: his time has come. He has almost single-handedly taken a genre that has been limping and misshapen for years, grievously misunderstood and poorly realized by the Hollywood machers, and made it into something magical and thrilling.He. Gets. It.Of course, if Whedon were put in charge, that might impede his ability to write and direct, but good god it would be great to have someone who can make something this good be in charge for a while. Warner should just appoint him the head of their superhero movie division for the next five-to-ten years and let him whip the genre into shape. All they need to do is make movies that are fun, and not so packed with dense exposition, and make 'em look good with strong, intelligent scripts. Whedon has done it here: this is the template. (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue film reviews)
summary: Put Joss Whedon in charge of the studio!!!!!

reviewText: OK. I kind of liked this movie. I'm a Tony Stark fan. Maybe I'd like it more if they had called it Iron Man 4. But I digressThis movie is a train wreck. First, not only is a flying aircraft carrier stupid and implausible, but it was lifted directly from a 2009 episode of Dr. Who (Google "Dr. Who the Valiant").During the attack, where was the US Air Force? The leviathans were big, slow, and obviously vulnerable, and there were just a few of them. A couple F18's could have mopped them up in no time.Where was the US Military period? After about 20 minutes a couple of tanks that I think were actually National Guard showed up. What, were the entire US Armed Forces on break?And when one jet finally does show up, it is to nuke the city. What for? The cube is invulnerable, the portal is on free flow bad dude mode, so all the nuke would do is wipe out the townsfolk. But I guess that is exactly why SHIELD was against it.Hawkeye and Black Window. These guys have no super powers. None. Zip. They don't even wear armor. Yet Hawkeye spends nearly the entire battle totally exposed on a rooftop and never gets shot. Or even shot at. And where do all his arrows come from? Must have got the Bottomless Quiver from Olive Garden. Black Widow at least hides behind things occasionally, but seriously, she's a chick with a couple small pistols. Not exactly save the world material. Why are they even there?Loki. Ah Loki. A god, but like Thor not impervious to injury. Yet he survives everything the Avengers throw at him UNTIL the Hulk just delivers a good old fashioned ass whupin'. If that's all it really took, Thor, or for that matter Iron Man could have subdued him long ago.The old "shoot the mothership and they all die" plot twist. Independence Day anyone?Finally, the ultimate shame. Joss Whedon directed and even wrote part of this mess. Not shiny Joss, definitely not shiny. Apparently no power in the 'verse could save this mess, not even you.
summary: Way too many plot holes, sink holes, and a-holes

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The culmination of Marvel's four-year, five-picture master plan is, puzzlingly, both as good as I'd hoped and a mild disappointment. It excels at playing up the larger-than-life aspects of the story, from the testy initial relationship between heroes and the looming magnitude of the threat they're called together to face. Such moments are dispersed liberally, perhaps once every five minutes, and they're an effective method of keeping the audience on the hook for the duration. What's missing, at least from where I sit, is a measure of substance or depth behind those fireworks. Robert Downey Jr. is again excellent in his nuanced interpretation of the paradoxical Tony Stark, and Mark Ruffalo might just be the best Hulk to grace the silver screen, but by comparison the rest of the cast feels quite thin, shallow and (for lack of a better word) cartoonish. Captain America, for example, wears a completely different personality than he did in his solo picture, and never feels quite right as the commanding field general he's presented to be. The most intriguing aspect of his character, an emotional detachment from modern culture, is barely even mentioned. He, and the rest of the team, feels like a suit of armor with a few good one-liners, not a living, breathing human being. It's a trap that was mostly evaded in the stars' preceding solo shots, so it's a shame to see it tripped here, especially given the amount of time and effort that was expended to define each individual's motivations. Those nitpicks certainly aren't enough to stop me from enjoying the closest thing we'll ever get to an all-splash-page crossover mega-event on the big screen, but they're also irritating enough to keep tickling the back of my mind while the next set of fuses are lit. It's a herculean effort with some truly great rewards, but not the picture-perfect ensemble masterpiece it would have you believe.
summary: Cinematic Cotton Candy, For Better or Worse
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Well it's finally here! The day all Marvel freaks have been waiting for...a decade has passed since we heard rumors that this titan team movie was in the works. The Avengers is without a doubt a complete success and for once lives up to the overwhelming hype.Not ignoring character development, The Avengers manages a pretty tough feat! The story is long, but never boring and even though it takes time to develop, it's like a simmering pot that we all know is going to explode at some point!..and when the pot does explode, it explodes like no other superhero movie has ever done!First off having Captain America, Iron Man, Thor, The Hulk, Hawkeye, The Black Widow and Nick Fury in one movie seemed impossible to give each character their due, but The Avengers does just that,(Fury could have been better utilized and I can't get used to Jackson playing the part.) I grew up with the scruffy cigar chomping BADA$$ white guy version from the 60's), but this film pulls off the impossible! I never once looked at my watch in it's two hour and twenty five minute length. Besides having a very ambitious story the action sequences are the best I've ever seen in a film of this nature.The film has many comic moments which had the entire audience roaring with laughter with the Hulk (who is properly sized for once) delivering in spades this time around ( I guess they owed the character that much after two sub-par feature films). He and Robert Downey Jr. steal the show and give us those classic moments a popcorn film of this magnitude needs to keep everyone focused in on the fact that this is a film about comic book characters. Each character is given time to shine and having origin films for the main quadrant helps a great deal. I can't imagine how they're going to top this one?!The Avengers rivals the very best of all comic book films including Spider Man 2 and Batman Begins and the 3D (which I usually find distracting) is the best I've ever seen. Trailers for the new Spider Man reboot and Batman films were also presented in 3D. Even if you're not really into superhero films, this is the summer's must see movie. Get a tub of popcorn and prepare for an incredible movie experience!.... and you WILL want to stay ALL the way to the end of the film as there is a false ending showing one of Marvel's Heavy Weight Villains before a funny ending scene a few minutes later. I hope Marvel reboots the Fantastic Four with a CGI Thing that could at least give the Hulk a fair battle.The four disc Blu Ray edition is very nice, but one small gripe, they stacked two of the disk top of each other, which I find really cheap for a set that cost this much. I mean really?, how much does a swinging hinge cost? I bought the tin collector's set at Best Buy and quickly gave them a new home in the superior case. Though the new case didn't have room for the digital copy, which  don't use any way. The transfer looks and sounds fantastic with bonus material a plenty.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: For ensemble superhero movies, "The Avengers" is about as good as it gets.  It offers good acting, good dialogue, good direction and great production values.  Hats off to Joss Wheldon for getting all his superheroes enough screen time for character development, while honoring the Marvel universe created by recent movies.  Props to Scarlett Johansson for developing the back story of Black Widow and for holding her own with the guys in the action department.  Props also to Mark Ruffalo for his nuanced interpretation of hapless scientist Bruce Banner and his raging alter-ego the Hulk.The plot is straight-forward.  Banished Asgard demi-god Loki finds a way back to Earth courtesy of the Tesseract power source and an alien civilization looking to invade.  The first casualty is Nick Fury's (Samuel L. Jackson) SHIELD headquarters, leveled in a savage attack.  Fury summons the Avengers (Ironman, Captain America, Thor, the Hulk, Hawkeye, and the Black Widow), who will be forced to build some teamwork on the fly as Fury's floating aircraft carrier (wow!) also comes under attack.  The climatic sequence will be the defense of New York City by the Avengers against a seemingly unstoppable horde of aliens pouring through a wormhole in space.The movie leaves plenty of room for a nice sequel if the current cast can be kept intact (watch through the credits for a hint of what might be next).  The movie is fairly long at two and a half hours, but the fight scenes are good and the movie is highly recommended to fans of the Marvel superhero comics and movies.

reviewText: First and foremost, the movie is incredible.Without a doubt, probably the best comic book movie adaptation.That is saying a lot considering the Dark Knight's success.But I see the Dark Knight as a very well done crime drama that happensto have a popular super hero.In Marvel Avengers, you get all the super hero trappings from beginning to end.I enjoyed it very much so for that, I give it all the stars that I could give.What I was disappointed in was the process involved with downloading the sound track as pointed out by fellow reviewers. That's really uncalled for. I also don't like how weak the featurette was. It's just a few interviews with some cast members and very few behind the scenes footage. I can only compare this to other films from the same core franchise when they released their home video units.Bottom line, if all you want is the film, by all means for the price, it's well worth it. Just don't expect a whole lot more.
