reviewText: I received the 4-disc 3D Blu-ray of the Avengers.  I'm not reviewing the film.  There's Metacritic for that.  I'm reviewing the product itself.  This is the first of two Disney titles (the other being the 4-Disc 3D Blu-ray of Frankenweenie) where the case itself only holds two discs, so the discs are stacked on top of one another.I'm sorry for complaining, but Disney is a billion dollar company.  I'm paying more for the version with more discs, and there's been past entries by Disney where they've included a plastic piece to attach more discs to.  It's a petty way to cut corners.Rant over.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I am glad I only paid $20 for this otherwise I would have been angry at the discovery that Disney/Marvel severely crippled your ability to watch special features.For starters, the 90 minute special feature Building the Marvel Cinematic Universe is missing. I don't know what Disney was thinking when they decided the only way you can have all the special features was if you buy it from a certain store. That is just wrong on their part to do such a thing.Secondly, I hate how you can't access certain features unless you download the Marvel Second Experience App. Even after downloading the app, it still wouldn't work.This is a great example where design took priority over functionality and practicality and its the consumer that suffers in the end. I am extremely disappointed.As an added insult to injury, when I downloaded the movie from iTunes with my digital download code, it wouldn't include any of the iTunes Extras.I also don't like the packaging of the movie either. The cover makes me dizzy and while you can tear it off there is nothing behind it so it becomes an ugly yellow box. I also don't like how the discs are placed on top of each other rather than receive their own slot.I also am upset that the 30 minutes of deleted Captain America scenes from The Avengers was not included either.The only thing that is keeping me from giving this review anything less than 3 stars is that the 3D is good and for $20 instead of $30, it was totally worth it. But had I bought this when the price had shot up to $37, I would be demanding my money back. Too much money for such major design flaw on Disney's part.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Great effects and amazing dialogue and chemistry between the cast. If you are a fan of comics and all lovey-dovey for Joss Whedon then this will put the starch in your trousers.I felt the story was a bit slipshod. They shouldn't require you to watch 10 hours or other films just to have the proper investment in the characters of this one. I am still impressed with it though because I never thought Hollywood would be make a film that would capture the scale of the 1990s Marvel comics Mega cross-overs.Watched via Amazon Instant Video; Excellent Quality, I will use the service again for sure.

reviewText: I personally don't think I understand the attraction. I think for me, I enjoy much more character development than what this film had to offer. The emotional struggle of each character didn't seem real and if anything it seemed like a joke. It was very unrealistic (granted it is a superhero flick) but to the point where I lost interest. I never felt like "okay this could happen" which i suppose is something I have to feel in order to be invested in a movie. this is why I like the dc universe's films much more than this marvel universe (not including the amazing spiderman by marc webb). The sense of humor wasn't my style either. I've read some of the avengers comics and I do enjoy them but this is just so .... to me it feels like such a hollywood predictable flick and I have a hard time understanding why everyone loves it.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The Avengers is the most awesome movie of a year boasting the finally oh the Dark Knight Trilogy, and Beginning of The Hunger Games Trilogy. Earths Mightiest Heroes fend off an interstellar attack by Loci, which after decades of not looking very good in the comic books are finally well rendered on film. In fact almost everything gets a near perfect screen rendering, including giving Captain America a Very Golden Age makeover by building his armor around double breasted SWAT armor,The plot is great, and the action is just the right mix of spy thriller and Hulk Bash. The movie also has the best oneliners of the century and a feeling of we will win because we're the good guys that has been missing for decades.

reviewText: Like many scientists, I have been a fan of Sci-Fi/Fantasy since I was three years old. I have a Doctorate in Physics from Oxford, and am extremely jealous of his fertile brain. I slowly became an admirer from Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Angel, the ill-fated Firefly series, on to his many movie credits. While I think his talents are misdirected as a producer or director, his part in the creation of the S.H.E.I.L.D. projects is undeniable. Joss, please get back to the creative craft and let others be the back stabbing executive suits that I grew up knowing in L.A.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Although not usually a fan of comic-book themed movies, however this one was exceptionally well done. I finally got it here in June, after seeing Joss Whedon was the director and scriptwriter; he's one of my alltime favorite directors (thanks for Firefly, Buffy, and Dollhouse), Joss you're a brilliant visionary who genuinely 'gets it', thanks for overdelivering with this visually stunning movie. It's a genuine thrill to see the teamwork, visual fx and excitement of the battle in NYC.Story arcs and character development are actually engaging, unlike most comic-themed movies; I like the human touches in the Hulk character (reminds me of the original character and thx Lou for the v/o). Samuel Jackson is great as Nick Fury; always a strong leading character, one of the best actors in modern film, it's always great to see you in action.  Samuel 'brings it'... as always.  Scarlett's Natasha character was outstanding, she was one of the best characters of the film, what I especially liked was her backstory.  Great ensemble cast, they worked well together, following Joss' exceptional directing and scriptwriting.To the story,Ken
summary: Action-packed visual stunner, thanks Joss and team
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of Marvel, but this movie just didn't cut it.The Hulk just hanging out with everyone at the end, but earlier he wants to rip Black Widow's head off???Why the change in character?Captain America getting into a pi..ing contest with Tony Stark???Loki with no real chance of reigning over humanity - so what's the point?He's not stupid so why make a deal with the Chitauri to begin with?Robert Downey Jr. is awesome as Iron Man. that dude is probably one of THE most gifted/talented actors of our day.Chris Evans was great as Johnny Storm, stinks as Capt. America.  Cap is my favorite hero, so it stinks to see him do such a lame job in this one.He was decent in the Capt. America stand alone, but in The Avengers...  lame-o.Overall a big disappointment in the story.  The cartoon/animated Avengers movie is a better story, characters are true to form, and I can watch it over & over.A gazillion $$$ in production costs and the CGI & special effects were cool, but didn't blow me away.  You've got the coolest heroes ever assembled and this is the best you can do???The HULK is the most unrelenting force of rage in the universe and they show him punching one Chitauri ship and then punching a few individuals around.He pounds Loki into the ground (very cool!) but why did he stop?  No Betty Ross to slow him down or distract him, no Super Soldier Serum to help Bruce wrestle for control...Waaaay too many holes and lapses in character/story development for me to really enjoy it.Hey MARVEL, if you're going to build up to a story over 4-5 years...  seriously, this is all you've got?  Lame.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Rating:+4 The dust still hasn't settled on the excitement of the release of The Avengers.  Joss Whedon was handed over the combined stories of four of Marvel's most iconic characters (and a few others tossed in for good measure) and asked to create a film (co-written with Zak Penn) that brought all of them together on a scale that has, at least up until this point, never been achieved.  For the most part, Whedon and company do a pretty darned good job of things.I've seen the film three times so far and I might actually go check it out one more time before it leaves theaters.  I saw it in 2D the first and last time and in 3D the second time.  While the 3D looks decent enough, it's only necessary for a couple of "epic" looking moments in the film.  Otherwise, the 3D adds nothing to the story.....not that it needs to add anything.The story itself moves at a pretty fast pace and is an excellent collection of action and plot.  While Whedon could have easily taken a ride on the Michael Bay train of excessive 'splosions and computer-generated "awesome," he instead scattered the action throughout a very solid plot that builds on the unique personalities of the four main players (Captain America, Thor, Iron Man, and Hulk) and how they eventually come together to take on Thor's lil' adopted brother, Loki, in a war to save the planet.The story begins with Loki coming to Earth to acquire the Tesseract (which you are familiar with if you've seen some of the other films leading up to this, specifically Thor and Captain America).  Once it is in his control, he plans to use an army (I'll remain a bit vague here for the two people who haven't seen this film) to take over Earth and then any other world he sees fit to conquer after that.  In his way, however, is Nick Fury and S.H.I.E.L.D.  Fury sets out to gather three of Earth's mightiest heroes.  He sends Agent Coulson to find Tony Stark (Iron Man), Agent Romanoff/Black Widow to fetch Dr. Banner (Hulk), and he calls upon Captain America himself.  A fourth hero, Thor, is considered a wild card and there is no way to know if he'll even show up to help battle his little brother.When Loki shows up, he "compromises" Agent Barton/Hawkeye and Dr. Selvig, making them his servants.  He takes the Tesseract and sets out on his plan of world domination.Can Fury convince Cap, Iron Man, and Hulk to join forces against Loki?  Will Thor show up?  Can Scarlett Johansson look any hotter in this film?  You'll have to see The Avengers to find out.The cast is brilliant from top to bottom.  I was always fond of Tom Hiddleston's performance as Loki in Thor, and he amps it up just a bit for this film.  He's a bit more psychotic and a lot more egotistical in this go round.  Chris Evans IS Captain America.  I believed every single word that came out of his mouth as he not only took the point during the fight, but let his true blue all American ways come through.  He was a man lost in time who injected just the right amount of old fashioned American patriotism to save the day.  Robert Downey Jr. could have played the role of Iron Man in his sleep in this third outing as Tony Stark, but instead he played the funny man to Evans' straight man in this film.  All of the characters had their funny moments, but Downey seemed to be written into the film primarily for humor.  Don't get me wrong, Iron Man has plenty of epic moments in this film, but most of the laughs come from him, except for the big green guy......Hulk.  Mark Ruffalo stepped into the much maligned role of Bruce Banner, and made it his own.  He's meek, desperate to remain calm, and always warning others not to cross him.  He and Stark have a few funny moments together, but let's be honest here, we all came to see the Hulk do what he does best, which is SMASH, and he does just that to perfection once he's unleashed in the film.  Not only does Hulk have some of the most brutal moments in this film, he has two of the funniest ones as well.  I won't spoil them for you here, but don't be surprised when you laugh out loud during a tense confrontation between the Hulk and another character.  Chris Hemsworth, much like Evans, was made for the role of Thor.  He has some of the top action moments in this film, but also handles the emotional struggle of fighting against or saving his brother quite well.Samuel Jackson does a solid job as Nick Fury, although his character is delegated more to a background role as he does most of his fighting against S.H.I.E.L.D. itself.  Cobie Smulders, while nice on the eyes, was pretty much vanilla as Agent Maria Hill.  Scarlett Johansson was very good as Black Widow and handled her action sequences quite well.  Jeremy Renner did a good job in the role of Clint Barton/Hawkeye.  His role was a bit limited, but he owns every minute he's on the screen.The real gem in this film was Clark Gregg as Agent Coulson.  His giddy fanboy reaction to Captain America was classic, and despite being a relatively small player in all of the other films, he takes center stage this time around.The action was very good.  It was also very loud and very fast.  Whedon loved to zoom in a lot, which led up to a number of blurry fight sequences, especially involving Hulk, Thor, and Iron Man.  He made sure that there were plenty of iconic scenes during the film, one of the best involving Captain America and Thor.  He also did a fair job of pacing with the film.The only knock that I really have with this movie is that some of the editing was choppy.  One particularly epic sequence involving three heroes ended with a thud, and took me out of the film for just a split second.  There were also a few scenes involving Loki's army that reminded me of the old television series V from the 1980's, and amped up the cheese a tad bit.Still, the fanboy in me wants to give this film five stars for the simple fact that it was pulled off.  It was fun, epic, and brilliant.  However, the amateur critic within begs me to take off one star for the fact that the editing did really bother me a couple of times.So is it worth multiple viewings?  Considering the fact that it's the only film I've ever paid full price to see more than once at the theater, yes, it's definitely worth multiple viewings.  I plan to own it on DVD when it comes out (September 25 is the announced date).  It's popcorn fodder with a plot, and that's a rare treat, especially during the "blockbuster" summer season for Hollywood.Go see this film.  Go see this film.  Go see this film!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The entire cast really delivered. You needed more than just action actors or stunt doubles to play all these parts. The pathos is there but so are the timing and true deep performances. Look, I was missing Ed Norton as much as anyone on that hype train I talked about but I'm so happy to say that Mark Ruffalo won me over. I hope he's locked up for the long haul because we don't need any more changes. Three was the lucky number for movie Banners. Every other actor in Avnegers that we've seen before is BETTER than their previous incarnation (EVERY single one) with the possible exception of RDJ as Stark. He's great but it's hard to top his take on the character from the original Iron Man in an ensemble movie. I also have to fully disclose that I'm insanely attracted to Scarlett Johansson. I thought her Widow character was amazing but I'm definitely judging that through rose colored glasses. The character arcs that run there course during this film will surprise a lot of general audiences expecting nothing more than a Transformers type popcorn scarfdown.

reviewText: Just saw it on DVD for the first time. Don't believe the hype. It is an ok movie and definetly worth a singleviewing, but I'm not going to be watching it again any time soon. The pros: the special effects are out of this world,really push the envelope; the action sequences (the few that there are -- thats one of my gripes about the movie, fartoo much chatting and not enough action) are excellent; Robert Downey Jr is superb as Iron Man -- really one of the greatactors of his generation; and Tom Hiddleston is excellent as Loki. Everything else about this movie is just terrible --from a confusing, mess of a story, a forgettable script, and worst of all, other than Loki, generic, boring villains who youdon't care about and present zero challenge to the superheros in the story. "Wow, look at what Captain America can do with hisshield" "OMG Black Widow is such an amazing martial artist" it doesnt mean anything if you are going up against an army ofindistinguishable CGI drones. Honestly, if you're look for your Avengers fix go watch Marvel's excellent "Avengers: Earth'sMightiest Heroes" animated series, and save this one for a boring, rainy Sunday when there is absolutely nothing else to do.

reviewText: Possibly the best super hero movie Marvel has produced so far. I could just end the review right here, but I won't. Prime shipped on time on release day and came with 2 discs as described (BluRay & DVD). It also comes with a redeem code for a free Avengers poster and digital comic. However, there is a setback with that. S/H 3.95. Clearly optional, but I'm just glad I got the movie.Four years in the making that lead to this: Marvel's The Avengers. Six extraordinary people are called together to stop a global catastrophe. What's not to like about this already?Everyone has already said all the great stuff about it so I'm not going to continue beating a dead horse. Short break down.Overall, the film has a great story that's been built up for the last 4 years. It has an interesting plot, a great cast of heroes, even greater action, witty humor and it's just overall fun for everyone. Even those who have not read a comic book in their lives. This is Marvel's first step at showing how vast the universe really is. This is the first movie in a very long time that instantly became one of my all time favorites. Just sharing the love.
summary: What Can I Say That Hasn't Already Been Said?

reviewText: I'm gonna keep this short as everyone has said pretty much everything there is to say about this film. It is hands down one of THE BEST movies ever made, EVER!!! Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I love me my actiony summer blockbusters. I'm not partial to superheroes over any other kind of action adventure, but I have enjoyed the cross-training efforts of the various moviemakers and comic book companies as they collaborated on the lead-up movies, so how could I not watch The Avengers to see what it was all for?It was for me, that's what it was for.As long and enjoyable as the movie was, I wish there had been more of it. There just didn't seem to be enough time for all the giant personalities to fully establish themselves. Jeremy Renner's character seemed to get shafted (ahaha) particularly hard, which was no fun, as I looked forward to much more from him. And of course there were the obligatory plot holes here and there that you're not supposed to notice because of all the showy explosions and fight scenes. Ooh! Aah! Wow! Kapow! On the other hand, I loved everyone's snarky bickering. Adorable! I totally ship Captain America and Iron Man now.I'll continue to watch future movies in this collection of series, because they've all been enjoyable to date and I'm invested.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: "The Avengers" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: Iron Man, The Incredible Hulk, Thor, Captain America, Hawkeye and Black Widow answer the call to action when Nick Fury, director of the international peacekeeping agency known as S.H.I.E.L.D., initiates a daring, globe-spanning recruitment effort to assemble The Avengers team to defeat an unexpected enemy threatening global safety and security. Despite pulling together the ultimate dream team, Nick Fury and longtime confidant Agent Coulson must find a way to convince the Super Heroes to work with, not against each other, when the powerful and dangerous Loki gains access to the Cosmic Cube and its unlimited power.The cast led by Robert Downey Jr. (as Tony Stark / Iron Man), Chris Evans (as Steve Rogers / Captain America), Mark Ruffalo (as Bruce Banner / The Hulk), Chris Hemsworth (as Thor), Scarlett Johansson (as Natasha Romanoff / Black Widow), Jeremy Renner (as Clint Barton / Hawkeye), Tom Hiddleston (as Loki), Clark Gregg (as Agent Phil Coulson), Cobie Smulders (as Agent Maria Hill), Stellan Skarsgard (as Selvig) & Samuel L. Jackson (as Nick Fury) is excellent. The directing by Joss Whedon (who also wrote the screenplay & co-wrote the story) is brilliant. The story by Zak Penn & Whedon & the screenplay by Whedon is brilliant.The music by Alan Silvestri is brilliant. The cinematography by Seamus McGarvey is brilliant. The film editing by Jeffrey Ford & Lisa Lassek is brilliant. The casting by Sarah Finn & Randi Hiller is brilliant. The production design by James Chinlund is brilliant. The art direction by Benjamin Edelberg, Jann K. Engel, Gregory S. Hooper, Billy Hunter, Richard L. Johnson (supervising art director) & Randy Moore is brilliant. The set decoration by Victor J. Zolfo is brilliant. The costume design by Alexandra Byrne is brilliant. The stunts coordinated by R.A. Rondell, Chris O'Hara, Jonathan Eusebio & Hank Amos is brilliant. The special effects supervised by Chris Brenczewski & Daniel Sudick are brilliant. The visual effects supervised by Erik Nash, Janek Sirrs, Colin Strause, Greg Strause & Guy Williams are brilliant. The make-up effects supervised by Stephen Bettles, Thomas Floutz & Kevin Kirkpatrick are brilliant.This is a well-made and well-done film that is fun (sometimes, funny as well), entertaining and thrilling at the same time. This is also a well-designed film, as well. The cast is brilliant well-chosen and have terrific chemistry together. Joss Whedon has made a terrific and brilliant movie that is just as brilliant as its characters' origin story movies; maybe even, a little more. This is also a film that will keep your mind thinking, as well. This is also one of the best movies of the summer (also one of the best films of the year), possibly, the best, and it is also one of the best movies to start off the summer season, as well, too.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Wow. That's all I can really say about this movie, really. It was better than I expected and then some.Loki, Loki, Loki. A tortured soul and such a good villain. Man he really hates his brother, Thor! Damn talk about family issues. Loki opens the portal and goes to earth to destroy it of course and Thor appears to take him home. Thor runs into Iron Man and joins S.H.I.E.L.D. to help take down Loki. Of course there's Nick Fury who brings them all together to S.H.I.E.L.D. Black Widow goes to collect the Hulk (Bruce Banner aka Bruce Krenzler) to help S.H.I.E.L.D. Iron Man joins and Captain America.  Captain America, Thor, The Incredible Hulk, Black Widow, Hawkeye (who was previously Loki's drone in the first half of the film) and Iron Man all join together to bring down Loki and his alien drones from destroying earth. The humor was better in the movie (thanks to Joss Whedon), the action was awesome, and the story was better. A must see for all. The after credits spot sets it up for the future Marvel Sequels (I hope)- Captain America 2, Iron Man 3, and Thor 2. Nick Fury is rumored to have his own movie but we'll see. No plans as of yet to give the Incredible Hulk ANOTHER movie.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Let's cut to the chase.  We already know why you're here.  You want even more vindication that Joss Whedon's (Buffy: The Vampire Slayer, Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog) film, The Avengers, is worthy of your hard-earned dollars.I give it five out of five stars.If you keep up with my reviews, you know this is not a rating that I hand out lightly.  So I will give you some reasoning.  First, and most impressively, every single actor is given an equal amount of screen time in this film.  Did you love Samuel L. Jackson as Nick Fury in his brief cameos from the other films?  You'll see plenty of him.  Did you think Robert Downey, Jr. was the perfect fit for Iron Man (as I do)?  You'll get your fix.  Were you impressed by Chris Hemsworth as Thor, Scarlett Johansson as Black Widow, Jeremy Renner as Hawkeye or Chris Evans as Captain America in previous appearances?  You won't be disappointed.  Each character is also provided an ample introduction for you to become quickly acquainted with them, or to jog your memory of their powers and origin.  And if you are already familiar with both, then these scenes compose a pleasant "calm before the storm".Mark Ruffalo has been cited as the best Hulk yet, better even than Bill Bixby, according to radio personality and "Hollywood Babble-On" co-host Ralph Garman.  While I first found this to be sacrilegious, I knew I had to see this film on opening weekend to see if I would agree (in addition to my adoration for Tony Stark).  I would have never chosen Ruffalo for Bruce Banner, and yet he was impeccable.  I was just as wrong about him as I was about Heath Ledger being the Joker in The Dark Knight.  Ruffalo masters a nervous tic so well that you find yourself feeling bad for him.  You hope he doesn't become the Hulk (even though you still hope he does) just so he doesn't have to experience the anger and pain that come with the transformation.  Ruffalo truly is the best Hulk.Loki, the villain of the film, is played by Tom Hiddleston and is sexy probably, in part, because he is so evil.  He is a great counterpart to Thor as his brother.  Thor is someone I was never personally interested in and to this day, I have yet to see the film.  However, I must eat crow and say that Hemsworth possesses a much finer acting ability than I initially believed he would.  I took him for an airhead; he is not even close.  I am now interested in seeing Thor based on Hemsworth's performance in this film.There are almost as many scenes of comic relief in The Avengers as there are action-packed scenes.  Believe it or not, the Hulk provides some of this much appreciated wit.  Some have said that the last third of the film is one long-running action scene.  I found the entire film to be.  Very few scenes were slowed down.  This was a film where you either kept up or got left in the dust.  It is two hours and twenty minutes of non-stop action.  The dialogue is witty and the acting is so well honed that I found myself scoffing at the Academy as I watched the scene between Loki and Thor at Stark Tower.  How can they continue to dismiss comic-book movies for a chance at the Oscar when great ones such as this are continuously churned out?Even if you haven't seen Captain America, Thor, or either of the Iron Man films, even if you know nothing at all about comics but love action films, I strongly suggest you see this film.  And if you are a fan of all of the above, then there is no reason why you shouldn't see this film.  It's even great for kids, as there isn't much profanity and there are few scenes of graphic violence.  RottenTomatoes.com gave this film a 93% rating and they know their stuff.  I give it five out of five and I like to think I know mine.
summary: The answer is yes; you want to see The Avengers.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is my favorite movie of all time.  I've been a long time fan of the Incredible Hulk, and I love how they portrayed him in this movie. The only complaint I have is they missed a great opportunity for a real hulk moment when he is faced with all those hovering enemy spacecraft near the end, he should have done a mighty clap,and blown them all away like dandelion seeds from the force of the clap like the comic book Hulk.  I thought they did a magnificent job on the other characters as well. I hope the next one is as good or better in 2015.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This was a great movie. Tons of action. A lot of your favorite heroes in one place. The only thing I will say is that I wish it would have included Kevin Costner's character from the movie Waterworld. Granted, he is not a Marvel character... but surely Kevin Costner could have been easily convinced. What else does he have going on these days? I wish Waterworld 2... but sadly, nay. Anyhow, even with the lack of Kevin Costner (or any reference to the movie Waterworld for that matter) this was a great film!

reviewText: Disney and Marvel Studios together for the first time both marketed and distributed by themselves an mega-blockbuster hit with The Avengers. I've seen this on the first showing on opening day during the record breaking opening weekend, I loved every minute of it including the Hulk who steals the show while Robert Downey Jr as Tony Stark/ Iron Man continues to amaze while Loki is the ultimate supervillian better than his role in Thor! As time of typing this, the third highest grossing film of all time worldwide besting Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows part 2, domestic besting The Dark Knight, the highest grossing Disney movie of all time both domestic and worldwide, highest grossing film of 2012 domestic, overseas and worldwide, highest grossing comicbook movie of all time, and highest non James Cameron film of all time both domestic and worldwide. If you have seen it once or more than once or perhaps not seen it yet see it on the big screen before the blu-ray and dvd comes to stores soon! I love Hulk throwing down Loki and before that he hits Thor by mistake! As for people going on this movie against The Dark Knight Rises just who's going to make more money, please stop that, they both going to do well anyway like being the top two box office hits of the year so it's not no contest these movies are made for the people, by the people and it's the year for superhero movies, who knows The Dark Knight Rises could do a billion dollars but not as strong as The Avengers so it could happen. Anyway, enjoy The Avengers on the big screen and on dvd and blu-ray 2d and 3d soon with many extras like deleted scenes and much more! You won't be disappointed!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: this one is a great movie, from the stand point of super hero films that is. this is fun with all of the actors from their own films that came before it. all the Marvel Super Hero movies are full of cgi special effects and lots of action so it is the summer films of a few years that the Avengers fit into. not exactly like the comic books that they were originating from, and updated for the 2000s. it all come together now in a real good movie. with a lot of plot and personality in it. the best acting goes to Iron Man aka Robert Downing Jr, he acts the part of Tony Stark as a drunken genius egotist learning to get along with others. Nick Fury as Samuel L Jackson is in authority and commands respect. the Hulk is sympathetic with Mark Ruffalo in green skin, Captain America played by Chris Evans from his own movie the origin story, fills the part of inspiration and tactics leader and is cute too. a Norse god Thor as big as life in Chris Hemsworth's body with armor from Asgard to look like something out of mythology itself. the new guys the Black Widow and Hawkeye are both featured in this film, each hero gets his time in the spotlight. this is comic book readers dreams of super heros come to life. a wonderful movie.
summary: the big pay off of all those Marvel Super Hero movies before it

reviewText: Now NOBODY has to be dumb or completly brainless to know that this is the best movie yet! It's just weird and cool seeing the Avengers all together. So the plot may be a wee bit off, but other than that; the assamble is good, the action is good, and the movie itself is AWESOME. Oh, here's a heads up: Any of you readers liked the battle sequences of "Dark of the Moon?" Well step right up, the begining end of "The Avengers" is almost EXACTLY like that battle. So this is "The Avengers," slick, cool, action packed, and clearly the best movie ever!
summary: It's Transformers and Dark of the Moon... but WAY better!!!

reviewerName: Leiah "So, I Read This Book Today . . ."
reviewText: Had a two movie night last night - first Captain America, and then Avengers. I had a great time. Beautiful graphics, a true marvel feel, and Joss did his normal fantastic job with the whole shebang.Ruffalo is a great Hulk - very dry and understated in a very good way. Downey, Jr. does a bang up job as a self centered, self absorbed Iron Man. If you watched Eureka, you will remember Stark, the smug, smarmy ass that ran the think tank? Well, Downey is even named Stark - very appropriate.I smiled the whole time I watched both movies, and will watch both of them again.
summary: Joss does it again - total fun!

reviewText: We rented this through Amazon streaming and eagerly plunked down in the couch to watch the early summer blockbuster.  We were disappointed in the feature and it seemed really corny. I want to see a another flick designed around this version Hulk character.I like popcorn movies to forget about the job, the mortgage, the bills... and this had potential, but we found ourselves just finishing the movie because we felt we needed to.  We had just spent the money to rent it.

reviewerName: Lorenzo M. in the Hollywood CA Area "Movie Wa...
reviewText: MOVIE REVIEW #31 : " The Avengers "Wow! The best film of the year to date! Joss Whedon (Buffy The Vampire Slayer, Firefly, Toy Story) did what every screenwriter and director should do in all movies - make the audience care about the characters and as a result - we'll follow them anywhere and believe everything!.This movie has action, adventure, drama, mystery, intrigue, gadgets, technology and two extremely important aspects....heart and humor! Starting from droplets of all the other films before it (Iron Man. The Incredible Hulk, Iron Man 2, Thor and Captain America: The First Avenger) this film tells the story of the brother of Thor (and a mystery off-world villain) Loki -  played deliciously creative by Tom Hiddleston (Warhorse, Midnight In Paris, Thor)  plotting an evil destruction of the Planet Earth.Thanks to the incredibly funny and sharp performance of Samuel L. Jackson (Pulp Fiction, Star Wars: The Phantom Menace, The Incredibles) as the S.H.I.E.L.D. Nick Furry leader along with another character (like Jacksons') sprinkled though all the previous films, Agent Coulson played succinctly by Clark Greg (The Shield, Mr. Poppers Penguins, Thor) - who both got the Avengers Team together to battle this deadly enemy who obviously an egomaniacal madman!What great about this film is the believability of all the super heroes and their alter egos. Top of the performances were Robert Downey, Jr.(Chaplin, Sherlock Holmes, Due date) as Ironman and the hysterical ego drive alter ego Tony Stark and Chris Evens (Fantastic Four, The Losers, Push) as Captain America/Steve Rogers. Their chemistry and their electrifying  performances made for exciting drama and comedy every time they were on screen.And - Chris Hemsworth (Star Trek 2009, Thor, Cabin In the Woods) reprising his intensely innocent yet strong performance of the Demi-God - Thor. He wields his hammer like never before. In fact one of the more memorable scenes involves a fight of basically egos with Ironman and Thor only to be broken up by Captain America with some humorous results!The More subtle performance of Mark Ruffalo (Shutter Island, 13 Going On 30, Zodiac) as The Hulk was a great contrast and motivation to the Avengers Team! And who know The Hulk could be so so so funny! Real...but still funny. Another starlit moment can be given to the added intrigue of The Black Widow/Natassia and her dark past to the team as cleverly played by Scarlett Johansson (The Prestige, The Island, Iron man 2).For me there was one `throw-away' character The Hawkeye/Clint played by Jeremy Renner (The Hurt Locker, The Town, MI4:Ghost Protocol). Not really vital to the story or the team...but he was honestly performed and he did have a few cool gadgets. Other characters returned like Gwyneth Paltrow as Pepper Pots and Paul Betteny as JARVIS both the assistants of Billionaire Tony Stark (although one is a computer).The movie was edited extremely well...you can follow all the action and the Alan Silvestri (Back To the Future, Forest Gump, Night At The Museum) score gets you pumped up and going. Again this is a greta fun and funny film for the whole family. Technically up to speed that you'll be amazed at the gadgets and you'll never be taking your eyes of the screen! Over $200 million in its first weekend. I think it will be around for a while!
summary: Avengers - Blasts Everything Out Of It's Way!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I'm not a fan of comic book hero movies (possibly because I was never a fan of comic books!) So I was not very optimistic when my teenagers talked me into going to see it, even with Robert Downey Jr in it. Much to my surprise, I loved it. They pulled off the impossible and gave comic book heroes actual personalities with pasts and motives, who played off each other well. Excellent casting, a surprisingly good script, and excellent production made it one of the more enjoyable action films I've seen in a while.
summary: Comic book heroes that actually worked
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Thor and Loki from Asgard make the movie period.  Without them, even if they used other superheroes I think the movie would be boring for lacking an emotional component that is provided by the brother's fractured relationship.  I really felt very sorry for Thor having to deal with his insane brother and Loki was pure evil, entertaining for sure, but pure evil nonetheless.  I don't know how Loki can be redeemed (from evil to just wicked), but I hope somehow it's managed in Thor II which doesn't come out to next year of course.Everyone talks about Robert Downey Jr., and even the man who played the Hulk, but it is the Asgard brothers, Thor and Loki, that gives this movie its heart.UPDATE:The Bluray DVD is great, it's just like watching the movie in the theater (that is if you have a high definition, 1080p TV, which I imagine most people do by now).
summary: The Assgard Brothers are the Real Heros Here
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The Avengers is finally an action movie where adult material is not blindly and purposelessly included, well done. Waiting for the next few movies to come out.

reviewText: Many fans consider this the best Marvel movie ever. You get a Blu-ray 3D, Blu-ray, DVD and a digital copy (SD) disc in this release. The picture quality is terrific and the audio quality is superb (the 3D version is great while the 2D version is near perfect). The advantages of the 4-Disc combo pack are the 3D version of the film, digital copy (works with iTunes and Windows Media Player), the complete original motion picture soundtrack digital music download, a free digital comic book offer, and a free Marvel poster offer. Otherwise the special features are identical to the 2-disc release. The Target Exclusive bonus Blu-ray disc includes "Marvel: Building a Cinematic Universe (HD, 1:38:20)". reviewText: This isn't bad for a summer big action film. It has a good fast pace, a simple story and a sense of humor about itself. The action is very creative and, as expected, Robert Downey Jr steals the show. Mark Ruffalo does an excellent job in a rather subdued role. The Harry Dean Stanton cameo was very well done and shows that he still has it as a character actor.The bits with Scarlett Johansson were creative and fun. They turned the usual "weak hero getting lectured by the villian" bit on its head. That sort of thing is the best method for putting a heroic character over in a film. The villian gets his bluster lines, but then is shown to have been outsmarted and ends up looking foolish. Few films (for decades) have managed to get that simple thing right. The actors playing Thor and Captain America also did a good job. The bit with Loki in Europe established the Captain America character in a good way in a short amount of film time and avoided what could have been the annoying aspects of a lecturing patriotic character. Thor was all about the action as it should have been. They managed to figure out a way to make the Hawkeye character (an archer) actually work. The bits with the bow as a close-up weapon were a great idea.The things that don't work so well:Samuel L. Jackson as Nick Fury however doesn't work. There is too much of him and I dont know that using him to bring the group together in the story was necessary. It would have been better for him to be more incidental than constantly at the core of things. The whole the-government-can't-be-trusted subplot was a predictable waste of time.They spent too much time with followup characters from previous films. It didn't add much of anything really.The alien invasion characters were all rather bland and cookie cutter looking. Making everything grey chrome and mostly identical was a rather odd choice. It got to a point where it seemed like there were two CGI models that they just kept using over and over again. It might have been better to give some of the aliens more of a personality rather than having them be bugs squashed one after the other.Five stars within its genre. Its a well done example of this sort of film. Mindless entertainment has its place I guess.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Nearly everyone at one time or another has read a comic book. More often than not we associate those drawn color images with our childhood and leave it at that. The fact is that comics are no longer a source of entertainment for children for the most part, instead covering topics like drug addiction, alcoholism, homosexuality and more. Yes, there are comics made for children but not the majority. But at the core of these comics, beneath the surface issues of the day, is the basic fact that the core of them all involves heroes. And through the trials and tribulations various writers put their characters through that is always what we come back to.Marvel Comics nearly went under until the early sixties when they began telling stories that involved more the more realistic aspects of life. Because of that a new form of hero was born, one that had problems and lived in the real world when not wearing a cape. Fans loved these stories so when it came time to turn them into movies of course Hollywood messed it up, turning its back on what fans loved; until recently when fans flocked to see Robert Downey starring as Iron Man.But that was only the beginning of a long term plan at Marvel. Those that learned remained in their seats as the credits finished to catch a teaser for something coming down the line. It happened again and again after each Marvel character movie from the Hulk to Captain America. It was all leading to the first team up movie involving comic book characters. It was leading to THE AVENGERS.If you haven't seen this film by all means run out and buy a copy today. This is not just a rental movie, this is a film that can be enjoyed over and over again, allowing you to catch new things each time you watch as well as enjoy the things you loved the first time around. For me it is the best comic book movie ever made and the only bad part is having to wait until the next Avengers outing.The story revolves around the Tessaract, an energy source discovered at the end of the Captain America film. The top secret government agency S.H.I.E.L.D. (Strategic Hazard Intervention Espionage Logistics Directorate) has been trying to figure out how to harness the power of this object. That all changes when it suddenly opens a portal to another world allowing Loki (Tom Hiddleston), the Asgardian God of mischief and sworn enemy of his half brother Thor (Chris Hemsworth), to enter. Loki uses a staff to control the minds of scientist Selvig (Stellan Skarsgard) and top agent Clint "Hawkeye" Barton (Jeremy Renner). They escape with the Tessaract and force the hand of S.H.I.E.L.D. head Nick Fury (Samuel Jackson) to engage the Avengers Project.The project is an assemblage of various super heroes, people with abilities above the norm, to unite as a team to take on any problem considered too large for normal channels to handle. The first group that Fury assembles includes agent Natasha "Black Widow" Romanov (Scarlett Johannson) who recruits scientist Bruce Banner (Mark Ruffalo) who turns into the Hulk. Captain America (Chris Evans) has been kept with Fury in preparation for this moment. Lastly they ask Tony Stark (Robert Downey) aka Iron Man.Facing off against Loki he is captured but on the way back the team's airship is attacked by none other than Thor. A knock down drag out fight follows between Thor and Iron Man until Captain America breaks it up. With Thor on the team now, they take Loki back to the hellicarrier (an item that needs seen to be believed) for safe keeping. Unfortunately this doesn't end up being a good idea.Selvig in the meantime has found a way to harness the Tessaract and open the portal to a far off galaxy that allows their army to enter our world. This was Loki's plan all along. Trust me this is no spoiler as scenes of the final battle were in nearly every trailer for the film before it opened. With Hawkeye rescued and now a part of the team will these seven heroes be enough to prevent an all out invasion of the planet? And will each member of the team be able to face their own personal demons and become the hero that he/she is destined to be?This movie rocks like no other. The witty retorts, the campy lines when needed, the suspense of what will happen next fluctuate from scene to scene and keep you waiting to see what will happen next. Director Joss Whedon of BUFFY fame has put together a movie that brings a depth to the characters and story that mingle together to form a story movie that is filled with amazing special effects but effects that don't overshadow what is taking place.The acting by all involved is amazing and each actor takes their turn at making their character believable. You watch and never question if Evans is really Captain America or if Hawkeye can really shoot arrows this way. You just believe. If any one stands out in particular it's Downey. He just commands attention every time he comes into view. His quips are some of the best and suit his character. Having been the first of this group to star as his character it's only natural.The entertainment value of this movie is astronomical. From start to finish you'll sit at the edge of your seat waiting to see what happens next. Even side characters are given special moments here. There is never a dull moment in this film.One last note: as with all Marvel movies, even this movie has a secret ending to it. As a matter of fact it has two. The first comes early during the credits, the second after all the credits have finished. Stick around and watch both. Rumor has it that one of them will bleed over into the next Thor film. Iron Man 3 is nearly done filming. And the Avengers will return soon. One can only wait with anticipation until it arrives. .
summary: THE AVENGERS: THE STUFF HEROES ARE MADE OF
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I'm sure half the world has seen this and/or reviewed it by now so I'll just say that the best choice the studio made was putting Joss Whedon at the helm of this spectacle. Only Whedon could bring his patented 9 characters in one room conversational expertise to a scene and make it not only clear and informative but funny and poignant all at once. Lots of things blow up and super heroes fly and some of the action stuff annoyed me by being too typical (huge things fly out of the sky by the hundreds to destroy Manhattan and our heroes just stand there staring. Civilians are dumb cattle who hide inside, then go stare out huge glass windows like targets. Etc.)  but overall it's great because it's about the characters as flawed, real people who happen to have special skills that make them exceptional. That the skills don't make them less human or less flawed is Whedon's real triumph. That and the cast he got. Fantastic, everyone.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: If you haven't seen Iron Man, Iron Man 2, Thor, and Captain America... WHERE THE HELL HAVE YOU BEEN!?!?!?!?!?!Seriously... those movies are a MUST for you to understand the entire story of The Avengers.Now anyone who knows me knows I am a huge Marvel junkie... was from way back in the day when I collected comics. I am VERY PICKY about the way the Marvel superhero movies are done.I was extremely please with all the Iron Man movies, Thor, and even the 2nd Hulk movie... not a huge lover of the first Hulk movie or Captain America but at least Captain America was tolerable compared to that first Hulk movie (Eric Bana is bad Hulk!)I love Robert Downey Jr. as Tony Stark aka Iron Man. Every movie he plays this role in seems to me he's getting better at being Tony Stark. I love Chris Hemsworth as Thor. I can tolerate Scarlett Johansson as the Black Widow and Samuel L. Jackson as Nick Fury. I like Chris Evans... that's why I saw Captain America even though I am not a huge Captain America fan. I am extremely delighted in Jeremy Renner as Hawkeye cause he really looks the part and his acting is always spot on. Tom Hiddleston as Loki... flawless as always (I just wanna hug Loki for some reason).Where my major concern was ... was of course, where most fans concern was, THE HULK aka BRUCE BANNER. Mark Ruffalo plays this part... and he NAILS it. I mean, he reminded me of Bill Bixby in the original TV version of The Hulk. I was SO pleased that the Hulk finally got someone RIGHT to play his part. And then ... HULK SMASH... and The Hulk says some stuff... I was SO pleased that someone finally got The Hulk right on screen.Even if that someone was someone I am essentially mad at... by the name of JOSS WHEDON. Ah, Joss Whedon, he who killed BUFFY THE VAMPIRE SLAYER for me by season 4 of the series with all the story line BS of "the key" and Buffy going all psycho... yes... THAT Joss Whedon. So, he is behind one of the BEST Superhero movies I have ever seen. Gah. And I have to ADMIT THAT? Ok, Joss, you win this round. Still mad about some things from Buffy... but when it comes to Superhero movies... you did the Avengers some TRUE justice... so thank you.This movie is everything that a MARVEL/AVENGERS fan would want. And with the ending... a promise perhaps of a sequel?!?!? *crosses fingers*I saw The Avengers in 3D (it's my first EVER 3D movie since I was 3 and saw King Kong). I recommend seeing it this way because it was totally awesome from start to finish... a little hard to keep up with SOME of the action in some parts but it was WELL worth it for the effect of it all.Overall, I think this is the Superhero movie of the year... if not DECADE. We superhero fans have been waiting for this... and it's everything promised and then some (great awesome HULK funny moments too). I won't ruin the movie AT ALL for you... SEE IT... SEE IT NOW!!!!
summary: THE BEST OF THE BEST OF THE BEST OF THE... awww you get the point

reviewText: Saw this movie opening weekend... twice! The last time I walked out of a movie thinking I just HAD to go back to see it again was in 2005 when I saw Firefly, another Joss Whedon creation (only much more his own and catering to a much smaller audience) and before that in 1999 when I saw The Matrix.  The Avengers was just much so fun that built on the six movies that came before and led up to it.  Amazing to see all these characters juggled so well in a film that balanced action with wit and science as well as comic and mythological legend.  Thought about it so much during the week that I saw it again the following weekend and plan on going next weekend, too.  Such awesome fun!!

reviewText: I grew up reading the comics of each of these superheroes. At first I was a bit skeptical about it thinking that it would be too "childish" for me to watch, but I was definitely wrong! Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Frankly, I was disappointed by this film.  I expected it to be much better than all the superhero films from which it flowed, but it came up short.  The storyline was tediously protracted, with sparse heroic actions taking place, and too many scenes being shot in the dark.  The characters were okay, but the plot was rather banal.  The film's only strength, in my opinion, is when the Hulk picked up one of the villains like a fly swatter and smashed him repeatedly to the ground -- left and right -- in a "pissed off" response to the villain's arrogant assertion of God-like superiority over the Hulk and insulting the Hulk's intelligence.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: In a time of where comic book movies are constantly coming out, it was about time for this one to arrive.And everything here is done 100% flawlessly.That said, if you're enjoying the MCU [Marvel Cinematic Universe] so far, then this film should be right up your alley.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I must be one of the last people on Earth to finally get around to watching this movie.  Frankly, I found my attention wandering through large portions.  I was surprised by this because I love action movies and I think Joss Whedon is a God.  The constant snarky remarks by the various characters seemed forced rather than funny, and the plot was all over the place.  Although I love virtually every actor in the film, I found the performances of most to be somewhat bland and cardboard cutout-ish.  It was saved from being the most deadly dull action movie I've ever seen by Mark Ruffalo - an actor I've found, in the past, to be pleasant enough, but nothing spectacular.  His character has a few throw away lines that are done in the pithy, snarky manner I think the others were trying for throughout the film, but failed to achieve.  And  the Hulk vs. Loki  fight scene caused me to look up from the book I had started to read while I was watching the movie and burst out laughing.  And not just a slight chuckle either.  Loud, prolonged, spasmodic laughter.  Had the film had more arcane moments like this one, I would have never picked up something to read while it was on.  Thanks to that scene and a few of Ruffalo's other moments, I may actually watch more Avenger flicks when they come out.

reviewText: This is one of the more entertaining movies that I have seen in some time. Thor's brother(a nasty individual) invades a stronghold. He manages to put akey scientist and one of our heros Hawk under his spell with his staff. He escapes with his two prisoners destroying the complex. A source of energy comesup missing as well. This prompts a crisis. Nick Fury is forced to gather up the members of SHIELD(Avengers) to handle this situation. One by one they come in. Captain America,Black Widow,Iron Man,Thor,and finally Hulk. This is the beginning of some feirce battles. The Avengers fight with Thor's brothers all over the country. They finally wind up in a tremendous war in New York. The Hulk does a major job in the end of the movie. No questions asked this is atremendous movie. There will have to be a sequel.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I saw the Avengers movie in theaters and really enjoyed how it tied together the story lines from Hulk, Thor, Iron Man and Captain America.  Looking forward to the next movie.  Having a home theater system I typically only go to see movies that I think would look great on the big screen, and the rest I simply wait to watch on my big screen.  This movie looked even better on the plasma screen and the sound really popped on my surround sound system - and my system is a bit old.  I have a 5.1 Yamaha surround sound system and the movie sounded awesome so if you've got something like a modern 7.1 system you should feel it even more.I'm not a 3D movie fan, although I saw this movie in the theaters in 3D.  I didn't think the 3D really added anything to the movie.  There are few movies that I really appreciate for their 3D effects.  I thought Avatar was particularly good in 3D, but I don't think every movie is a good candidate for 3D.  That said, I enjoyed the movie as much on my T.V., as I did in the theater.  I recommend this.
summary: Good movie and great blu-ray conversion

Silly plot about aliens attacking the Earth with the help of the Evil Loki ( Thor's bad step brother). There is some nonsense about a "Tesseract" ( a cube that opens portals to other worlds and that sort of thing). reviewText: I have read most of the avengers comics , at least up to the 1980's. And they were great! The 3d is great and very few scenes have ghosting, like lets say 'dial m for murder does'.  It's a good comic book movie like most of the marvel comic movies. I would state though that the comics are actually better! If your kids aren't reading them that's a shame.  And alot of libraries have them in book form for you to read. The package comes with a unneeded digital copy and a dvd?, we don't need dvds with blu rays as it drives up the price. The blu ray has the extra features on it so you need that copy. This is a great adventure film and it was a monster hit and deservedly so.  It's too bad they gave up on the fantastic four and daredevil and others. Because Marvel comics  make good movies. This one though is probably the best of the lot.  It's  a must have for fans of comic movies and the most expensively made one to date.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: It's pretty clear that Marvel's entire film-making machine was leading up to this effort, a movie that nobody thought could be made because it involved Hollywood putting aside egos, directors joining forces, and intellectual property being leveraged in such a way that everyone plays nicely together behind the scenes, even if the characters don't play nicely together on screen.  Somehow, God bless them, Marvel actually pulled it off.Picking up where "Captain America," "Thor," and "Iron Man" left off, the Strategic Homeland, Intervention, Enforcement and Logistics Division (SHIELD) led by Nicky Fury (Samuel L. Jackson), commands a ragtag band of agents that just happen to work on a flying aircraft carrier: Maria Hill (Cobie Smulders, unfortunately miscast), Clint Barton (Jeremy Renner, not quite as sarcastic as he should be) as Hawkeye, and Natasha Romanoff (Scarlett Johnannson) as Black Widow. Their mission is to retrieve the Tesseract (AKA the Cosmic Cube) from Asgardian Loki (Tom Hiddleston) and his Predator-like race of alien soldiers known as the Chitauri.There are so many ways this film could have gone wrong, and part of "The Avengers"' success is that Marvel took its time building up to this moment with its previous releases. Asgardian god-hero Thor (Chris Hemsworth) could easily become a walking caricature, but he's such a tower presence that he demands to be taken seriously. Steve Rogers (Chris Evans) as Captain America is slightly diminished here, but he settles comfortably into his role as a brilliant tactician out of time but not out of his depth. All these serious characters are just banter-fodder for Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr.) as Iron Man, who shamelessly stirs things up when things goes down.  The one worrisome character was Bruce Banner (Mark Ruffalo) as the Hulk. With two tepid films under the character's belt, the Hulk was potentially "The Avengers" weakest link.No need to worry.  The Hulk is one of the best parts of the film.  Ruffalo plays Banner as a scruffy Doctor Without Borders, a brilliant man who gives off a zen vibe because you wouldn't like him when he's angry. Joss Whedon, master director of all things geeky, knows how to build up anticipation.  Whether it's the massive firepower that's never brought to bear against Banner or the trembling lip of the deadly Black Widow, we're always reminded that at any moment "The Big Guy" might show up. When the Hulk finally does arrive, he does not disappoint; the Hulk's rage is exhilarating and terrifying to behold, a green King Kong. Also, the Hulk's got a great sense of humor, embodied by his rivalry with the only guy who can stand up to him, Thor.Whedon does an excellent job of balancing the weaker characters, notably Black Widow and Hawkeye, against the superbeings who stride amongst them. Black Widow has two scenes that demonstrate how deadly she really is even against god-like beings, and Hawkeye's archery is unparalleled. There are not one but two tracking shots in which every character struts their stuff.  If you go to "The Avengers" film to see them duke it out, against each other and alien monsters, you've come to the right place. This is going to be hard to top.And oh yeah...shawarma is a real food.  Stay to the end of the credits.
summary: Yes Virginia, shawarma is a real food
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The only complaint I have about The Avengers (besides the endless Disney previews you can't simply bypass) is that it's too long, in my estimation, by about 15 or 20 minutes.  I realize that there are a lot of characters, plots, and sub-plots to juggle here, but by the time the team gets assembled, it's time for them to flex their muscles and kick the enemy into the next galaxy.  They, of course, do that; it just takes a long time to get the job done.  (Otherwise, I would have given this one five stars.)  Developing a believable plot line for this time of film with such a plethora of characters is not easy.  Kudos to the production crew for pulling it all together.  A fun ride!

reviewText: This movie is so far beyond what I thought was possible when I read comics as a kid that I almost still can't believe it! I've watched it, and the characters' own movies leading up to and since this film a great many times and still always enjoy them fully.  Marvel's The Avengers unites Captain America, Hawkeye, Iron Man, Thor, the Black Widow, and the Incredible Hulk (through the manipulations of Nick Fury and S.H.I.E.L.D.) in this rambunctious adventure that pits the heroes against Thor's half-brother Loki ("he's adopted", as Thor notes at one point), and his force of alien invaders, the Chitauri.  Of course, the characters' egos get in the way at the start of the movie, and it is only after a few dust-ups and unforeseen develops that they finally are able to see past their own powers and unite to fight the enemy - including neutralizing some unexpected antagonists.  The plot has multiple layers and subplots that also allows the revelation of each character's background story as it develops.  Just like the old Marvel comics I read as a boy events occurring in previous movies contribute to this story, and this story ends with hints of things to come, including an ominous revelation of one of Marvel's greatest bad guys involvement in possible a great deal more in the Avengers' and other characters' own storylines.  There is quite a bit of humor mixed in with Cosmic Drama - including no small amount of insider jokes, and some pokes at the heroes themselves. There are, of course, some differences in the Marvel Cinematic Universe as opposed to the reality as presented in the comics themselves, and even greater differences compared to the books from my youth, including some of the costuming and character origins, but there is no really significant loss. I am surprised that Disney and Marvel were able to pull this off, and I'm looking forward to the next installment, the Avengers Age of Ultron in 2015.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Chances are, if you are looking at this page you have probably already seen the movie.  For any who have not, here goes.  First, you have to be a fan of superhero movies.  If they do nothing for you in general, this one probably will not do anything for you either.  That part of it is totally subjective, and nothing I say will sway you either way.If you are a fan of them, especially Iron Man, you will love this.  This can almost be considered Iron Man 2.5, given that off all the characters Robert Downey Jr. is probably in the movie the most, either as Iron Man or Tony Stark.  Even so, I think a good job was done giving the other characters enough screen time that no single character was the focus of the movie.  It is like the cast an ensemble.  The movie also presumes that you know the back stories as told in Iron Man 1 and 2, Thor, Captain America, and to a lesser extent The Incredible Hulk.  Not that you have to see any of those movies to grasp the concept, but it will help in knowing who the bad guy is, and how all the characters came to be.I liked the addition of Mark Ruffalo as Bruce Banner.  Even though I thought Edward Norton did a good job with the character, and would not have minded seeing him come back, given what he was rumored to be like on his Hulk movie I am not surprised that he was replaced.  One thing I did like about Ruffalo, is you can buy him as a normal guy.  He is not physically imposing like Chris Evans (to some extent) and Chris Hemsworth are, yet you bought by the way he played the character that he was dangerous.  I admit that I was, as a fan of the Hulk TV series, skeptical of a CGI Hulk.  It was not done all that well in the first Hulk movie (the forgettable one with Eric Bana) but has got better over time. And since Hulk is supposed to be 9ft tall, the only way to pull that off is CGI.  Plus they can make him move like no real person can.The script was very well done, which as any Joss Whedon fans can tell you was no surprise.  He brought the same blend of action, drama and humor (mostly involving the Hulk in the last 1/3 of the movie) that he did on his TV shows. I think it was written assuming the audience is smart and wanted a good story and good acting, and did not just rely on action, explosions and eye candy.  As I said, if you like the genre, you are most likely going to love this movie.  It looks and sounds great on Blu Ray, and is definitely worth a spot in your collection.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Marvel Comics' "The Avengers" brings together 7 superheroes, 4 of whom have had their own films, to combat a global threat. Scientists with the S.H.I.E.L.D. organization are trying to find an unlimited source of energy locked within an alien Tesseract. But it is emitting unusual energy surges, and Loki (Tom Hiddleston), errant brother of the Asgardian Thor, comes through the Tesseract from "the other end of space". Using his scepter, Loki forcibly converts Dr. Selvig (Stellan Skarsgrd) and Agent Clint "Hawkeye" Barton (Jeremy Renner) to his cause and absconds with the Tesseract. Agent Phil Coulson (Clark Gregg) assembles the extraordinary individuals to form the Avengers, at Director Nick Fury's (Samuel L. Jackson) request. Iron Man (Robert Downey, Jr.), Captain America (Chris Evans), Black Widow (Scarlet Johansson), Dr. David "Hulk" Banner (Mark Ruffalo), and Thor (Chris Hemsworth) must prevent Loki from bringing an alien army to conquer Earth.It seems that, with so many superheroes in play, there must be a comparably grandiose enemy. Loki personifies foolish ambition, but he is being used by the otherworldly leader of the alien armies, who happens to look like the Grim Reaper. The fight is over Earth, in its entirety. "The Avengers" runs too long at 2 hours 23 minutes, but that is almost inevitable given the need to introduce so many characters to an audience who may not be familiar with them. I've only seen 4 of these characters in a movie before, but I could gather enough about the others over the course of "The Avengers" that I was not lost. It's a challenge for director Joss Whedon to get enough backstory, character development, and action into theatrical movie with 8 larger-than-life characters. And this was only his second feature film. Whedon is, or was, a television writer and director who became involved in the project through a long-standing friendship with producer Kevin Feige.The Avengers spend too much time fighting technical difficulties and fighting each other -for reasons which are, at best, weak- rather than fighting the enemy. When that giant aircraft carrier that S.H.I.E.L.D. uses as a base ascends into the sky, well, one could guess that it might have trouble staying there. Is this really something our superheroes should spend their energies on? Some of those action sequences were not integrated well enough into the story: action for the sake of action. "The Avengers" is not perfect. But Mark Ruffalo is the best Dr. David Banner yet. He is a man who has mastered the art of calm, reluctantly, because he holds passionate views. He copes well with the constant threat of Hulk but is always in conflict with himself. Clark Gregg as Agent Phil Coulson is a strong character but also brings an indispensable "everyman" perspective to the superhero show. Robert Downey, Jr. is always entertaining as Tony Stark. "The Avengers" has a lot of territory to cover with these characters, and it generally succeeds and entertains, with good humor.The DVD (Paramount 2012 single disc edition): There are 2 bonus features on the single disc edition. "Assembling the Ultimate Team" (8 min) interviews director Joss Whedon and the actors about characters and casting. There is an audio commentary by Joss Whedon which is constant and informative. He talks about locations, story structure, challenges of shooting, conveying the Marvel universe on film, what he put in versus what he left out, writing while shooting, his decisions, and scene-by scene commentary. Dubbing is available for the film in French, Spanish, and English Descriptive Video Service. Subtitles are available in French, Spanish, and English.
summary: A Whole Lot of Superheroes Battle Alien Evil and Each Other.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I haven't been as happy over an incredibly hyped movie as I was with Avengers. It delivers the goods that you expect to see from an action film. It's really the first of its kind in that after watching all the other superhero movies and having their subtle scenes to link each other together, that these (certain) Marvel movie heroes are brought together in one film. It's like getting all the superheroes under one roof for the same price.The reason I say its (so far) the best superhero movie, is simply because out of all the awesome superhero movies made... this one *feels* like a comic book come to life. Don't get me wrong, The Dark Knight trilogy is spectacular in its own right (and Batman is my favorite character), but we get something else with Avengers. Its action packed and filled with thrills, and each film connecting together pays off.Visuals are some of the best on blu-ray. The transfer is incredible and top notch with bright pops, nice color, and deep black (the beginning of the film however is a bit crushing in black detail). I normally like my movies to be presented with their original aspect ratio. In the theaters Avengers was shown as 1.85:1 and instead we get 1.78:1, but that just means the content fits a 16:9 hdtv without tiny black bars. Have a surround sound system? Make the neighbors think a movie theater, or the action is actually happening outside their doors. Experiencing the surround sound is worth a knock to turn it down at theater levels!Avengers is a must own in any movie watchers collections. It has to be my most re-watched movie in the entire bunch.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I actually read Mark Millar's "The Ultimates Omnibus" which had a very similar tale to the movie but changed some things which I felt made it more interesting than the film. That said, the film is still awesome enough per my grade below.Many of the Marvel superheroes who had their individual movies are now brought together when Nick Fury (played by Samuel Jackson) using the "Avenger's Initiative" to call them up during a crisis related to the Tesseract (an all powerful energy source among other things) which eventually leads to showing the Avengers going from disjointed to united and especially so in the last part as Earth has to deal with an invasion from aliens. Who else but the Avengers is going to save us?It's an all star ensemble playing various Marvel heroes and mortals (who all get their little personal scenes before they join the big story): Samuel Jackson as Nick Fury, Robert Downey Jr. as Iron Man, Chris Evans as Captain America, Mark Ruffalo as Hulk, Scarlett Johanssen as Black Widow, Jeremy Ranner as Hawkeye, Chris Hemsworth as Thor. Clarke Gregg as Phil Caulson, Tom Hiddleston as Loki, Paul Bettany as Jarvis and Gwyneth Paltrow as Pepper. Yes, that's the voice of the old Hulk, Lou Ferrigno, and look for the usual Stan Lee cameo.One of the greatest strengths is surprisingly in the characters and how they show their different views on getting the job done. Compare Iron Man (a la Tony Stark character) to Captain America (a la Steve Rogers character) when they begin their big argument. I'd say the best presentations were a tie between the "new" guy, Mark Ruffalo, and Robert Downey Jr., the "old" guy of the Marvel films. Also, as far as supporting cast go I was quite impressed with how they developed and presented the character of Phil Caulson (played by Clarke Gregg). Note that I am basing this on an action superhero movie, not character driven tales, so it's a bit of a curve you could argue.Action was over the top and flirted at the borderline of losing the audience to special effects but I felt they pulled it off well enough.Hardcore purists might argue that Hulk should be the only unstoppable force followed by Thor but I'm just getting into the Marvel comics so I can't fully comment. All of the heroes got to be awesome and that's what one would expect from the all star cast. They aren't going to agree to play a lame or non memorable character, right? Another viable criticism by said group is that the Avengers were not formed in the movie way but most people probably don't mind.The budget for this picture was $220M and it made over $1.5B at the Box Office. A sequel is naturally expected. Stay after the credits for the two teasers. That's pretty much something you need to do after every Marvel fan these days, I suppose.Trivia and spoilers below.STORY/PLOTTING/EDITING: B to B plus; CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE: B plus to A minus; CINEMATOGRAPHY: B plus to A minus; SOUND/MUSIC: B plus; ACTION SCENES: B plus to A minus; WHEN WATCHED: end of October 2012; OVERALL GRADE: B plus to A minus.TRIVIA (IMDB sources): Edward Norton was originally set to reprise his role from The Incredible Hulk but negotiations between him and Marvel Studios broke down. Norton was replaced with Mark Ruffalo.According to Joss Whedon, the film is strongly influenced by the early 1960s Avengers comics, which he was a fan of while growing up: "In those comics these people shouldn't be in the same room let alone on the same team - and that is the definition of family."This film holds an unusually high number of Academy Award nominees in the cast/crew for a comic book movie, or most movies for that matter: Robert Downey Jr., Gwyneth Paltrow, Samuel L. Jackson, Jeremy Renner, Mark Ruffalo, director Joss Whedon, and cinematographer Seamus McGarvey, possibly many others. This tops Iron Man 2, and Iron Man which each had four nominees a piece.According to director Joss Whedon, the original cut of the movie was over 3 hours long. About 30 minutes of the excised footage are included on the Blu-ray, most of which revolves around Steve Rogers (Captain America). Whedon revealed that one of these scenes involved Rogers struggling to adjust to the modern world in his Brooklyn apartment and another revealed Steve Rogers' reunion with Peggy Carter, his love interest from Captain America: The First Avenger. Chris Evans has since announced that the deleted scenes with Captain America will be used for Captain America: The Winter Soldier.To prepare for the role of Agent Clint Barton (Hawkeye), Jeremy Renner was trained by Olympic archers.After Thor takes Loki off the Quinjet down on the mountain side, two large ravens fly by them as they are talking. In Norse mythology, their father, Odin, had two ravens, Huginn and Muninn, who would bring Odin information from Midgard (Earth).The twelfth film to surpass the $1 billion mark worldwide, and the tenth to surpass the $400 million mark in the USA. It tied with Avatar and Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 for surpassing the $1 billion mark worldwide in the fastest time (19 days) and set the record of surpassing the $400 million mark in the USA (14 days).Amanda Peet was considered for the role of Agent Maria Hill.Loki's staff which has a glowing blue gem in the spear head that allows him to control the minds of others is a reference to the Mind Gem. One of the seven Infinity Gems used by Thanos, who is the character shown in the post-credits scene to be the leader of the Chitauri.SPOILERS: I thought Thor broke the portal between Earth and his homeland so how did he return? I know how Loki returned but it seemed as if Thor was already hanging out on Earth before that incident. BTW, what happened to the Natalie Portman character?Hulk had the funniest action scenes, especially when he picked Loki up and beat him to a pulp. Loved it!Thor is a God, not a demigod per the picture. Was that said to satisfy the religious types who don't want "pagan" Gods being called, well, God?Most fans wanted to see Thor go at it with Ironman and Captain America and then at a later point with Thor. You got it. I would recommend you also check out the graphic novel I mentioned above.I liked the Thanos teaser and I'm curious to see what they will do with him in Avengers 2.
summary: MY GRADE: B plus to A minus.

reviewText: Marvel's The Avengers is the best super hero movie that ever made in the history of Hollywood, it's simply the best because what you're seeing is not one superhero movie, but 4.I've always love the movies that goes trilogy or even Quadrilogy, because it follow up what's been left off, and imprement, it brings you to the new era in the same universe. In reality, 99% of the franchise flops at the end, to name a few, Rocky, Back to the Future in the past, even new series like Twilight, LOTR, in a way, they left you a taste decline on every new one that you see.But not this movie, The Avengers, it work as an pentalogy but you can't call it a Pentalogy because the first 4 weren't prequel but they holds the prequel effect, in reality you can't appreciate this movie unless you've seen the other 4 or at least a couple of them. That's how it work. So this movie actually is built on a new way to produce franchise movies. There were the setups, and there is the feast.I was surprise how they contain each element so good, from beginning to the end, every 5 minutes were break down to be a winner, I can't seem to even find a scene that I would feel sorry for the film makers, the lines are hilourious at times, with good taste. Action scene often bring me surprises, an example would be Thor slam his hammer on Captain America's shield, it was the second after I saw that scene I realized I've always been wondering what would be the result of the impact! And it was really really thrill.-www.mixacase.com
