reviewText: OK.  I already knew I loved the movie.  So, I was just happy to be able to watch it any time I wanted...but hey!  What a great combo pack!  All in one.  Gotta' Love IT!  But, the best surprise was the connection to the iTunes App.  I had my doubts that it would work, but they were totally unfounded.  I held my iPod Touch to my TV once the movie started, (and having started the app), and it synced to the movie!  I ended up watching the app instead of the movie.  Neat trivia and artwork.  I loved it.  It was as if I stepped through a time machine and was using technology not invented yet.  This was sooo cool.  If you have the combo pack and haven't tried this out yet - DO IT NOW!  Seriously, it was a blast.  It made it fun to watch the whole movie one more time.  I'm a slow reader, so the movie invariably got ahead of me...so I just used the resync "button" on the app and yup, I was back in sync.  Really fun app.  And I'm still fascinated with its ability to sync via audio from my non-fancy, non-special TV and Blu-Ray player.I guess I should also mention that you can take the "cover" to the case off (it's a "card") and sit in your house - my kids love it.  It's a 3-D picture.Like I said, you've Gotta' Love IT!

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Sitting in the theater during The Avengers (2012) was unlike many previous theater experiences I've had. I sat with a grin squeezing my wife's hand in joy. Pardon the cliché, but I felt like a kid in a candy store. If you read Cultural Transmogrifier`s Staff Discussion, you know the expectations I and the staff had. They were quite high to say the least. I was more than pleased with the results and my expectations were more than met.Joss Whedon felt like an inspired choice for director when it was announced a few years ago, and I stand by that. Whedon and Zak Penn's story, and Whedon's screenplay, translates to an Avengers comic come to life. Simply put, The Avengers  is one of the best comic book adaptations ever made.Building off the success of the previous character films, Whedon was able to jump right into things with this story. I will only briefly and vaguely touch base on the specifics because I don't want to spoil anything. If you haven't seen the previous character films you won't be totally lost, but there are a few things that will just gloss right over you. The basic story revolves around the tesseract--an extraterrestrial source of unlimited power. It's under the control of S.H.I.E.L.D. and they're running tests on it under the guidance of Selvig (Stellan Skarsgrd). Learning that the tesseract is a portal device, we witness the reentrance of Loki (Tom Hiddleston) to Earth.Loki is working with an extraterrestrial race hellbent on bringing Earth to its knees. It's hinted that Loki is not merely the powerful messenger, but the leader of this new army. The only ones who stand in his way are the Avengers, who are brought together through various circumstances and thrust together in the final act by one significant character . . . moment. (Anyone familiar with Whedon will understand this.)Every question I had about what our characters were doing between their own films and this one were answered in one way or another. The cast continues to be excellent. Most will give the nod to Robert Downey Jr., but I think a special spotlight should shine on Chris Evans. His portrayal of Captain America is ideal. He is still the super solider of the early 1940s, and despite being out of time and out of place, the leader within is clearly there.The struggle to establish the team mentality of The Avengers is a joy to watch. Each character is perfectly written, self-aware, and aware of each other's flaws--which they are quick to point out. FINALLY, I think the Hulk/ Bruce Banner have been written correctly and expertly. Watching Hulk smash is just so awesome! The Avengers is filled with just the right amount of exposition, action, story, and best yet, humor. Just when you need a breather, Whedon offers it up and tosses in a wonderfully written joke delivered by almost every single character in the film.Without detailing anything else, just know that when this movie ends, it doesn't really end. Most people know that Marvel likes to add a "stinger" at the end of the credits, an extra scene to tease about a future film. This is no different. In fact, The Avengers offers two such scenes. (The first one--I called it! See our Staff Discussion for proof). Make sure you stay in your seats until the theater lights go fully up and the screen turns off. Any sooner and you'll miss out. 30% of the audience left before the first tease, 95% were gone before the final one. Don't be that person! Trust me, after a somewhat exhausting 2 hours and 22 minutes, that final scene is just what the Captain ordered.
summary: `The Avengers' Knocks It Out Of The Park

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Who hasn't wanted there to be a well-done movie with several comic book heroes?  While we wait for a Justice League movie, this will do.  Storywise, it is not the greatest, but it has excellent entertainment value.  The one problem is how long it takes to get to the space invasion.  I put character development very high, but whenever you have a large cast all demanding their own time you won't get that much.But now that we have the assembling af the Avengers out of the way, I am curious to see what they do next time.I saw the film in 3D in a movie theater and I came away telling people they should only see it in 2D, that 3D added nothing to it.  So much of the first half of the film had indoor settings and there wan't that much light to make good 3D.  However, on Blu-ray, the 3D is a LOT better, and I would recommend people see it that way.  There are no shots of things coming out at you, but it provides good depth.Audio is excellent.The extras are on the 2D disc and are good: an original piece, a music video, and two behind-the-scenes pieces, as well as an audio commentary.  However, I still expected more from a title this big.A Blu-ray that is worth recommending whether you see it in 2D or 3D.
summary: A fun get-together of Marvel's greatest heroes
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Dark Energy is finally harnessed in a science fiction movie. Whoever gets his hands on such source of endless power would enslave the world.The greatest strength in the movie was the visual effects and animation that depicts dark energy as a contained medium is a cube of the size of a hand that emits powerful beams of radiation, which dissipate the atmosphere of the earth, opening a hole to the outerspace.  Through that hole, supernatural creatures send their army of monsters and soldiers to wreak havoc on New York City.The plot was shady. The moviemaker stretched the plot between America, Germany, Russia, and India for no good reason other than to fill empty time slots. Apparently, the movie's plot was intended for fast profit with little emphasis on leaving behind a legacy on how dark energy could benefit mankind beside being abused by deities bent on enslaving mankind.Few of the characters loved and believed in their roles such as Captain America (Chris Evans), Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson), Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson), and agent Coulson (Clark Gregg). Those characters eased the sloppiness in the movie plot and made most of the scenarios believably entertaining. Those talented actors/ actresses indulging into their characters leave unforgettable memories attached to the narration of the story.Among the artificially fake performances were: Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), which spewed the same nonsense by displaying imagery projections in the air, then grabbed those images as material objects, in addition to Downey mechanical attempts to display genius. A single actor who rises above the movie script in order to brag about his arrogance, in repeated movies, took away the innovation from the Avengers. Bruce Banner/Hulk (Mark Ruffalo) was also a misfit with his hunched upper back and unattractive facial expressions. Every time the focus shifted towards Dr. Hulk, annoying softness is felt in his role and the way he executes it.Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner) slipped far below his impressive role in the movie Charlestown. In the Avengers, Renner's performance was impulsive and stereotypical.Even in a science fiction movie, stepping out of reality requires diligence in transforming the mindset of the viewers of rational observation into fictitious realms. The sudden change of Bruce Banner/Hulk into a monster was inconvenient as it represent a desperate attempt to maintain the flow of events in a sloppy plot. In contrast, the impressive performances by Chris Hemsworth (Thor) and Tom Hiddleston (Loki) rendered their roles engaging.The most exciting part in the movie was the battle of Manhattan where monstrous creatures slammed into skyscrapers and busy streets of the most famous city in the world.Without the odd characters of the bodybuilder Hulk and the fake and imposing Iron Man, the battle of Manhattan would have been more memorable.Mohamed F. El-Hewie
summary: Best technical animation, sloppy plot, few compromising characters
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is a fun, well done movie with excellent special effects.  Interesting plot and I just love all of the "good guys and girl".
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Like most guys, I grew up with comic books, albeit before Marvel came along.  I loved most of the DC comics led by Superman and Batman but also a more obscure crew known as the "Blackhawks."  They were a group of mortals from various countries who came together to fight evil.  DC would often have collaborations as well, bringing Flash, The Green Lantern into the mix, eventually becoming the Justice League of America.  Marvel Comics came along in about 1967 to challenge DC with a new cast of characters, many of which are gathered in this movie.Guided by one of the great up-and-coming director/writers of the day, Joss Whedon ("Cabin in the Woods", "Serenity") is the perfect director for this sure to be blockbuster.  Admittedly I liked the previous Marvel films leading up to this big group hug, especially "Ironman."  Whedon and co-writer Zak Penn manage to inject plenty of humor to offset what could be the possible destruction of mankind.  Loki (Tom Hiddleston, "War Horse") returns as Thor's (Chris Hemsworth) adopted brother and drops in on Earth from their alternate world to capture a glowing energy source known as the Tesseract.  Naturally he and his ugly henchmen know as the Chitauri have evil intent but need the Tesseract and/or a fuel source known as iridium to fully open the portal to get them there.Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson) leads a group known as S.H.I.E.L.D which has been established to defend Earth from alien visitors including those like Loki's crew.  Over time (and several previous movies) Fury and his top agent Coulson (Clark Gregg) have co-opted Thor, Ironman (always good Robert Downey, Jr.), Steve Rogers, AKA Capt. America (Chris Evans), Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson), Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner) and now Bruce Banner, AKA The Hulk (Mark Ruffalo) into the fold.  Whedon manages to keep us on the edge of our seat with explosive confrontations between the super heroes as we wait patiently for The Hulk to get pissed off enough to show his destructive self.One of the big surprises was the appearance of Cobie Smulders who smolders as Agent Hill, Fury's top military aide.  Ms. Smulders, perhaps best known for TV's "How I Met Your Mother," looks great with a bloody face, packed into black leatherette and kicking bad guy ass.  I expect we'll be seeing more of her in the movies.  Even at 2 hours, 22 minutes the film moves along briskly for the most part.  The ultimate concluding battle is pretty much what we can expect.  The invading Chitaurians have quick moving space-sleds as well as huge metallic worm-like creatures/machines that far outnumber our heroes.  Still, we have The Hulk.  New York City takes another destructive CGI blow.  Marvel's "The Avengers" certainly ranks as one of the best films of the genre.  I saw this film in IMAX 3-D which was very very good.  Impressive enough to kick the rating up a 1/2 star.  Highly recommended.
summary: 4 1/2 stars (IMAX 3-D a worthy upgrade) for one of the best of the genre
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: While I'm looking forward to The Dark Knight Rises more than any other film this year, The Avengers was a complete blast. They combined elements from the different Marvel movies and made a complete story out of it. Iron Man, Thor, Captain America and the Hulk all get their moments to shine. You get your Iron Man vs. Thor and Hulk vs. Thor fights. That's just a taste of what is to come during the last thirty minutes of pure destruction. The CGI is top of the line and the action scenes are really great, but the movie never forgets that a good story and solid laughs are just as important as all the pretty explosions. The cast led by Robert Downey Jr. (full of snappy dialogue) is as good as it gets. The Hulk is finally done right. Not too big and just the right amount of scary. Funny that he gets the two biggest laughs in the movie. I even thought that the character Loki was a much better and more menacing villain here than in Thor. It's not perfect, but I think it is the best Marvel film to date.4 and 1/2 out of 5 stars
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Just when I'd thought I couldn't watch anything dumber, I found this gem.The positive reviews for this film have shaken my faith in humanity.  At the time of this review, there are only a bit over 100 1 star reviews, and it appears most of those are negative due to technical issues... many are not based on the actual filmWell... let's start with utterly worthless superheroes: The Black Widow, Hawkeye, and Captain America.The Black Widow - what good is she?  She does what?  We see an alien army coming out of a space portal and the best she can do is stand there with a couple pistols?  She is worthless.Hawkeye - just one step above The Black Widow.  The guy's superpower is what?  He is a good shot with a bow?  And he attempts to stop an alien invasion by shooting arrows at them?  He is worthless.Captain America - I guess he is a really good guy with a shield or something?  Heaven forbid the guy ever pick up a gun... can't have that I guess.  In order to make him seem useful, the Captain sort of takes a leadership role and gives out orders to the other Avengers.  Just one step less worthless than Hawkeye.Ok... on to the others...The Hulk - Uhhhh... someone explain to me why he can't control himself when he attacks The Black Widow but he is in perfect control during the alien invasion?  How does that work?  Also, wasn't there some suggestion that Loki wanted to get at the Hulk for some reason?  Was that ever explained?Thor - I guess being a demi-god qualifies as having some powers.  Of course, it also makes you wonder why The Black Widow and Hawkeye are so special.  Anyway - so why can't Thor break out of the prison container Loki traps him in?  Because it might fall?  That's the big trick?  Don't try to break out or it will fall?Iron Man - probably the only sensible superhero in the group.  You can explain his character and his powers.Question - the secret flying aircraft carrier engages a cloaking device when it takes off out of the water.  What happens to it?  Do they turn it off again right away?  The next time we see the ship it isn't working.  What's the deal?  Oh... and what exactly is the ship needed for in the first place?  The S.H.I.E.L.D. agency needed to recruit the superheroes to work for them, right?  So doesn't that imply that they really don't have any power themselves?  If they did, they wouldn't need to recruit superheroes.  Soooooo... what the heck do they need a giant, flying aircraft carrier for?Question - When Loki's henchmen come to rescue him off of the carrier, why do they blow up an engine first?  Wouldn't they try to sneak in quietly and get him out?  Was it supposed to be a distraction?  If so, why didn't anyone on the carrier send some extra guards to Loki's room?  Dumb.Question - where did Hawkeye get that usb plug arrow he uses to shoot into the computer and turn all of the carrier engines off?  For that matter, why turn all of the engines off in the first place... they are trying to get Loki, not kill themselves.Question - since Hawkeye's arrow accessed the computer and shut the engines down, how is it that Iron Man is able to get them started again?  He is working on the single engine that Hawkeye shot out with the explosive arrow.  So - why is it possible to get that engine started.... and all the other engines started, when the computer apparently shut them down?  Makes no sense.Question - Loki is so impressive why?  The dude is the most pathetic evil villain I've ever seen.Question - if the shield around the energy beam creating the space portal can't be penetrated, why not just knock out the floor around it... or a floor or two off of the building?  The energy generator is on the roof of the building... so knock out the floors beneath it.  It isn't hovering there.  Just knock it off.  What's the big deal?Question - what exactly is the relationship between Loki and the alien invaders?  What does each hope to gain and why?  What... are they just invading for the heck of it?  Does Loki want to rule Earth because he got kicked out of his home world?  How is that going to fly?  Does he think no one else will notice and that Thor and the others won't come after him regardless?  Does he think that the aliens will back him up?  They don't seem all that great if half of them can be beaten by a woman with two pistols, a guy with a bow, and another guy with a shield.Finally, can anyone think of a dumber plot?  Just imagine the production meeting where everyone is sitting around trying to come up with ideas for an Avengers movie.  I can see it now... someone at the end of the table says, "Wait a minute!  I've got it!  How about The Avengers have to save the world from an evil norse god who is trying to conquer the Earth with an army of aliens!"Again... as I say in almost every movie review I write... didn't a single person stand up and say, "Hmmmm... you know what?  That is freaking stupid!"  Not a single person?

reviewText: With Avengers Marvel had a tough row to hoe. Starting with Iron man, they cranked out a series of surprisingly watchable movies (including a remake of Ang Lee's disastrous Hulk) related by nothing more than a shared universe. Of course anybody who stayed through the credits of Iron Man knew an Avengers film was coming, but how would it blend the disparate themes and directorial styles of all the entries in the Marvel cinematic universe? Well, with Avengers, that uncertainty is over, and the results are fantastic.Avengers succeeds on three levels. Firstly, it allows every hero to behave as we expect them to. Iron Man is still a snarky always-knows-best alpha, Thor literally seems to have walked right out of his job in Asgard from his own film (and in the plot, he has) and Captain America is still reeling from his jaunt through time- but not enough to be scared of thousand-foot drops or flapped by Loki's supernatural mischief.Secondly, Avengers dumps all the characters we have come to know together in a big stew and Director Joss Whedon uses his flair for writing arguments (and comic books) to deliver every bit of the conflict and comradery you would expect. Heroes fight, team up, fight some more, then fight other stuff and every bit of it is punchy and fresh. Even Black Widow and Hawkeye, tragically underdeveloped characters who only visited in past films have good, well-rounded personae here.And finally, Avengers is fun. The plot (Loki, the Norse god of mischief, dupes a race of alien cyborgs into invading Earth because he is MAD AT EARTH) is pure comic book cheese, with a suitably over-the-top climax (where the Hulk really shines). the dialog is clever and humorous and dark when it needs to be. The effects are outstanding, and a surprising amount of what you will see here is in fact sets and actors, just as in Captain America.There are some problems. The post-production 3D, for instance, is horrible- not because it is badly implemented, but because this film makes use of a lot of creative camera perspectives that just look wrong with 3D applied to them- in the opening chase sequence, the helicopter following the convoy looks like an undersized toy due to the combination of a compressed perspective and a normal 3D field of depth. The film is also a bit inaccessible to viewers who haven't seen the preceding movies. After all, it wouldn't do to got through every hero's origin story whenever they show up. But these are minor quibbles, and shouldn't get in the way of enjoying what is one of the best, most satisfying comic book movies ever made, and a good omen of what's to come from this franchise.PROS:-Punchy writing-Great effects, great action, and tons of both-Good acting by principles and supporting cast alike-Tons of little nods to comic book fans throughout-Is almost three hours long, goes by like the world's best Saturday morning cartoonCONS:-What the 3D editors did doesn't always match what the camera crew did-CONSTANT Acura product placement that makes GM's endorsement of the Transformers films seem subtle-So dependent on seeing the past films and blink-and-you'll-miss-it plot turns that it almost totally defies casual viewing
summary: Earth's mightiest heroes, this year's nicest surprise
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I really really really wanted to LOVE this movie but in the end I think I set my expectations too high (just like with The Dark Knight Rises). It had many good action scenes but just because they introduced all the characters in the previous movies doesn't mean that they had to go lackluster on the story here. Don't get me wrong seeing all these characters together was awesome but I still felt like I didn't really know them completely. And I thought the whole bit with the aliens fell into been there done that territory. Oh well I'm sure Avengers 2 will be better. Overall this was a fun movie just not perfect. Enjoyable but not the best superhero movie ever.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: If you are reading this review I am sure you know by now what this movie is about, so I won't go into detail about the plot. First thing I want to talk about is the Aspect ratio. Alot of people seem to be upset that it does not have the black bars on the top and bottom of the screen. Me personally I would rather have the screen filled, I don't see the point of spending a thousand dollars on a big screen TV only to have the picture shrunk. Having it fill up the entire screen also makes the 3D more enjoyable, the black bars seem to be very distracting when you are trying to watch a 3D film, so for me this is a positive.Secondly, the 3D was awesome, especially toward the end of the movie when the battle takes place. The 3D gives this movie so much dimension. It is hard to believe this movie was a conversion, they did a fantastic job.Third is the action in this movie. There's never a dull moment. From the opening scene to the end this movie is filled with none stop action. My favorite scene is the fight between Iron Man and Thor. They did a wonderful job filming that scene.Fourth is the comedy. This movie had alot more funny moments than I expected. Hulk was my favorite. I think he even out did Tony Stark in this. The scene with him and Loki was great, "Puny God"! Also when he punches during the battle at the end, priceless!Fifth is the CGI. The VFX department took very good care of this film. They did a spectacular job on the hulk. This is three best looking hulk out of all the films. I think this us why Hulk seemed to become a fan favorite, because he looks great, and also had alot of funny parts in the movie. The Hulk really makes this movie worth watching.Last is the bonus features. Alot of people have complained about this also, but I was happy with everything. There are deleted scenes, features, commentary, digital copy, soundtrack, second screen. I though they did a good job with the bonus features, and I am satisfied.Overall, this is a must have, must see movie. Action/Superhero movies don't get no bigger our no better than this. Kudos to Joss Whedon, Disney, Marvel, and everyone else who worked hard to put this movie together. Can't wait for Phase 2! AVENGERS ASSEMBLE!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Theirs not much more that can be said about Disney/Marvels the avengers so I'm digging straight into a review of this film in 3D.The verdict.................... Absolutely amazing. The 3D conversion is worthy of much praise and looks noticeably better than the two times I saw it in the theater. The final fight scene in the middle of new york city is simply stunning. The film has a few great pop out scenes but the real highlights of the films 3D release is Iron Man flying high through the city and The Hulk lunging towards the screen before destroying a fighter jet. If you have the chance to experience this movie in the comforts of your own home in the 3D than I would say this film is a must have just to showcase how well a movie can look in home 3D.So you might be asking next,is their any cons to Avengers 3D?Very minimal. The biggest thing I noticed is that if I'm skipping between scenes than it will take the disc a second before readjusting to 3D. The only other 3D film I'v noticed to do this was Ghost of the Abyss 3D.The only of other point of contention I noticed was when Loki is looked in the small prison created for the Hulk. While talking to the Black Widow the spit from his mouth is very noticeable in 3D. Drooling down the the side of the screen. But once they cut back to him,the spits magically gone.Final verdict: Worth every dollar.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I went to see this movie in theaters and LOVED it. So when I heard that it was finally time to preorder it, I jumped immediately and preordered the "Marvel Cinematic Universe" box set. So it had to be pushed back to spring 2013 so that way the problem could get settled and they can think of something to replace the suitcase. reviewText: The Avengers is a fun movie.  I especially thought it was awesome that they took the characters (and main cast) from other movies and pulled them together.  That's quite a feat in itself.There are a few references to the separate movies, but it's not like you have to watch those movies to get this one.  The movie has enough action to keep it going.  Each superhero gets sufficient camera time both separately and as part of the Avengers team.  Overall, the movie was well done.
summary: Great movie if you're into superheroes
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Well it's finally here! The day all Marvel freaks have been waiting for...a decade has passed since we heard rumors that this titan team movie was in the works. The Avengers is without a doubt a complete success and for once lives up to the overwhelming hype.Not ignoring character development, The Avengers manages a pretty tough feat! The story is long, but never boring and even though it takes time to develop, it's like a simmering pot that we all know is going to explode at some point!..and when the pot does explode, it explodes like no other superhero movie has ever done!First off having Captain America, Iron Man, Thor, The Hulk, Hawkeye, The Black Widow and Nick Fury in one movie seemed impossible to give each character their due, but The Avengers does just that,(Fury could have been better utilized and I can't get used to Jackson playing the part.) I grew up with the scruffy cigar chomping BADA$$ white guy version from the 60's), but this film pulls off the impossible! I never once looked at my watch in it's two hour and twenty five minute length. Besides having a very ambitious story the action sequences are the best I've ever seen in a film of this nature.The film has many comic moments which had the entire audience roaring with laughter with the Hulk (who is properly sized for once) delivering in spades this time around ( I guess they owed the character that much after two sub-par feature films). He and Robert Downey Jr. steal the show and give us those classic moments a popcorn film of this magnitude needs to keep everyone focused in on the fact that this is a film about comic book characters. Each character is given time to shine and having origin films for the main quadrant helps a great deal. I can't imagine how they're going to top this one?!The Avengers rivals the very best of all comic book films including Spider Man 2 and Batman Begins and the 3D (which I usually find distracting) is the best I've ever seen. Trailers for the new Spider Man reboot and Batman films were also presented in 3D. Even if you're not really into superhero films, this is the summer's must see movie. Get a tub of popcorn and prepare for an incredible movie experience!.... and you WILL want to stay ALL the way to the end of the film as there is a false ending showing one of Marvel's Heavy Weight Villains before a funny ending scene a few minutes later. I hope Marvel reboots the Fantastic Four with a CGI Thing that could at least give the Hulk a fair battle.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Excellent story, really well done. We're looking forward to the next one! As far as family friendliness, we think it's appropriate for our 9 year-old boy and older. The scary parts aren't too scary, the violence isn't gory, and the lewdness is almost non-existent. Language is mild, with most of it coming from Robert Downy Jr.Some things that stick out in my mind for clarification:- There is an obvious relationship between Pepper and Tony Stark. They exchange flirtatious remarks, looks, and contact.- There is one scene (not giving away spoilers!) where Loki does something pretty violent and gross- a part I would consider to be the most gruesome part of the movie. A parent should be able to anticipate this scene since it's set up pretty clearly.-There are some pretty ugly aliens.-Profanity (that I can recall): d**n, s.o.b. (again, mostly by Tony Stark)
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I have to admit, I don't know all the comic characters involved in this movie, but that didn't keep me from enjoying the story.  Several character, Iron Man, Thor, Captain America had some very funny lines.  I think the characters were cast to perfection and each of them played off the other perfectly. I like how the movie showed them coming together as a team and not being perfect when that happened. Emotions, egos got in the way, but in the end it all worked out. Not to mention all the butt kicking that happens eventually. I hope they make a sequel to this movie so we can see how the Avengers work together without all the character development involved that came with this movie.

reviewText: I rarely say "wow!" when I see a film, but this did it.  I honestly thought this was going to be a bad movie for a number of reasons, so I put off watching it for a long time.  Had I known Joss Whedon (my favorite director) was directing it, I would have watched it sooner.  The action, the dialog, the acting, the effects; everything was fantastic, and I didn't have a single "oh that's stupid" moment -- which I thought I was going to have with a big budget movie that was capitalizing on prior blockbusters. Very very cool, and a must see if you're at all a fan of comics and superheroes.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: ...and I've watched it multiple times at home.  This was the BEST of all the Marvel movies made so far.  Joss Whedon is a phenomenal director, and it's such a fun movie to watch! In fact I would recommend that you get these other movies along with "The Avengers" and have yourself a Marvel movie-fest.

In the movie it overly depicts Hulk as invincible, everyone is afraid of him, he gets shot with hundreds of lasers and nothing happens, at the end he utterly destroys the bad guy without help from any of the others. Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The Avengers is, without a doubt, the best comic superhero movie yet. While there are other, single-superhero movies that have done well (Batman series, Iron Man, Thor, Captain America, X-Men, Amazing Spider-Man, etc.), this movie stands out for combining so many superheroes and doing it so well.Joss Whedon, known for his character development, does a great job not only weaving a bunch of individual stories together, but keeping it interesting at the same time.Anyone who's a fan of superhero movies, comic book movies, action movies, or well-done CGI should give this movie a watch. Or two. Or three. Or four...

reviewText: I have been watching DVDs for years, so it was with great excitment that I heard Marvel was going to release their smash hit "The Avengers" onto the digital video disc.Now, I ain't much of Robert Downey Jr. guy but I love Sammy Jackson and I once ate at the same restaurant at Mark Ruffalo. I like that Captain America holds up good old fashioned American values and that the Hulk can be reasoned with. I did not care for Bill Bixby's Hulk very much and Eric Banyon and Ed Norton's weren't much better neither.Scarlett Johanson is not much of an actress but you don't have to be when you have a figure like that. Though I don't care much for her nose, so I wish she would get rhinoplasty. Which reminds me, when is The Rhino going to be the villain in one of the SpiderMan movies.  If he ever is I am going to "charge" out and see it ASAP and I'll probably use a credit card to pay for the ticket (charge it? Get it?)I did once have a dream that Thor and I got married and he let me play with his hammer and you should have seen the smile on his face.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: It's hard to say why I give this film 4 stars when all I can think of is the negative. Not being a 15 yr old boy, I found the frequency and length of the fight scenes boring. The dialog for Tony Stark is smarmy to the extreme. It does not make the Stark character funny, edgy or quick witted but actually makes him obnoxious and very unlikable. As a matter of fact, the only Avenger I did like was The Hulk. Mark Ruffalo as Dr. Bruce Banner is wonderful. I also think Tom Hiddleson is outstanding as Loki. Samuel L. Jackson chews up the scenery, as usual. Thor is boring. Captain America is extremely trite.  Scarlett Johansson as the Black Widow is very good as an actress. Unfortunately, she does not have much screen time. So how on earth can I give it 4 stars? Because, above all that, it was entertaining. It looks vivid and fun on screen and while after having rented it for 48 hrs I was not tempted to watch it more than once, nor would I purchase it, I was fairly well entertained for 155 minutes.
summary: Fun movie but not all that
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: It's all been leading up to this folks: the grand spectacle known as The Avengers.  While Iron Man, The Incredible Hulk, Iron Man II, Thor, and Captain America: The First Avenger all the set the stage and were great superhero films in their own respective rights, none of them could really convey the sheer amount of pure awesome that The Avengers contains.  Loki (Tom Hiddleston) has returned to Earth wreck havoc in his quest for the Tesseract (i.e., the Cosmic Cube), forcing Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson) to set forward his Avengers Initiative.  Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), Captain America (Chris Evans), Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Bruce Banner/Hulk (Mark Ruffalo), Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson), and Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner) unite to take down the baddies, resulting in some brilliant action set pieces and massive amounts of destruction that you've got to see to believe.  Director Joss Whedon, best known for creating Buffy the Vampire Slayer and Firefly, as well as launching Marvel's brilliant Astonishing X-Men comic series, manages to handle the proceedings shockingly well and equally balance (for the most part, sadly Hawkeye seems to get the short end of the stick) each character, with all of them getting their own respective moments in the limelight.  That, and Mark Ruffalo is an absolute smash (no pun intended) as Banner, and the Hulk moments are some of the best and most insanely enjoyable segments you'll see in any mainstream superhero film ever.  While it isn't without it's flaws, The Avengers is a smashing blockbuster that will be extremely hard to top in terms of spectacle or action set-pieces...and of course, like any of Marvel's recent films, the post-credits sequences set the stage for even bigger (and more cataclysmic) events to unfold in future installments.
summary: The best Marvel movie ever, and one of the best superhero movies ever made
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This review is my general opinion of the movie and a response to another persons review. I personally thought that the movie was amazing in every aspect, the action, effects, and oddly enough, humor. this is definitely one of my favorite movies of all time, my mother hated all of the other superhero movies leading up to The Avengers ( except for Iron Man ) and she loved The Avengers. And to one of the people who wrote a negative review about this movie, the one who said Frosty The Snowman was better, I respect your opinion and I am sorry that you lost your brother's co-workers family in 9/11 but the thing is you have to understand that people are going to keep making movies with explosions in New York, and that this franchise is much more than Marvel trying to " make a buck ", because if Marvel was trying to " make a buck " they would not be making a movie that cost $250,000,000 to make plus 5 movies before that. Also The Avengers is the 3rd highest grossing film of all time and the fastest movie to reach the milestone $300,000,000 in the U.S.  which by the way was 9 days. In this review if you are even reading it is not to offend you or upset you and I am deeply sorry for your loss and mean no disrespect by this review/reply, this was just for the purpose of explaining to you that this was not to " make a quick buck " and that it was a very successful, entertaining, and overall excellent movie. I do respect your opinion, you are entitled to think what you want and this is what I thought. I would have made this a comment on your review but my phone would only let me do reviews. To the people reading this as a review, I simply think that everybody even the people who don't like superhero movies should see this movie at least once and see what they think.

reviewText: I am a 45+ female, I watched this movie today with my 22-yr old nephew and his friend.  On the 5-star scale, the friend gave it a 5, my nephew gave it a 4.5 and I give it a 4. (We did NOT watch the 3D version and after seeing this version we were glad we decided not to go the 3D route.)This movie is VERY GOOD, FUN with LOTS OF ACTION, good acting and best of all LOTS OF GOOD LINES!  Basically, if you don't overthink this movie YOU SHOULD ENJOY IT A LOT.I did enjoy this movie a lot, but I still downgraded it to a 4 because there was also quite a bit of camera work that I didn't like.  Like how they move the camera and for a moment it's a little out of focus, or the worst - when they are just way too close to the action. I really don't care for the in-your-face action, pull it back enough to let us see all the action! But fortunately, they didn't do it often enough to ruin the film for me.*** There is a little bit more movie midway through the end credits, so don't be too quick to exit the theater or turn off the DVD. ***The acting is good (though I would have much preferred Edward Norton as the Hulk). The sets and some of the effects are pretty awesome - they didn't "cheap" on this movie and I appreciate that.  [I did wonder why Tony Stark's gal (& business partner???) Pepper Potts (played by Gwyneth Paltrow) is always in shorts and barefoot in his classy office, and yet seemed more business dressed elsewhere though...]We were not familiar with some of the characters, so here's a little more about them for you.*  Samuel L. Jackson plays "Nick Fury" the Director of the S.H.I.E.L.D. peacekeeping agency (sorry, I have no idea as to what the letters stand for)*  2nd in command at SHIELD is Maria Hill (serious Brunette who seems over botoxed or something as only her lips and eyes move on her face - Spock was more animated than this woman!)*  "Phil Coulson" (the guy in the suit) is a veteran agent (I actually thought he was in charge until I looked up some information after I saw the movie)*  Clint Barton (aka "Hawkeye" or "the Hawk") - is one of SHIELDs most elite agents, and the greatest living marksman on Earth. His weapon of choice is the recurve bow with custom augmented arrows.*  Scarlett Johansson plays Natasha Romanoff (aka the Black Widow) - she is a top SHIELD agent, one of the world's greatest spies and skilled assassin. She's supposed to be armed with an extensive arsenal of specialized weapons like widow stings and cluster bombs and a vast repertoire of martial arts skills...I don't remember her with specialized weapons, just guns and the martial arts skills.You should probably already be familiar with the other characters:  THOR (demi-god), his evil brother LOKI (who is trying to take over and rule Earth in this movie), IRON MAN Tony Stark (inventor, playboy, billionaire, philanthropist), THE HULK/Bruce Banner (scientist), CAPTAIN AMERICA (thawed out and back in action) . . .In this movie you see (twice) that Thor is actually stronger than the Hulk, and can take a real beating without getting scratched up (here's that over-thinker kicking in). And while I think this was an oversight, Captain America was able to stretch out his hand and call his shield to him in the way Thor can call his hammer to him. Also, while he's been given incredible strength, Captain America was evidently physically strong enough to rival Superman in that he deflected something that his shield could withstand but the pressure on the shield should have crunched him supporting the shield.  Also, while in reality people ARE actually stupid enough to not immediately clear the street and get inside when vehicles and buildings are raining down on the street - and to be staring out the windows at the action instead of getting to safety - I would think the police and firemen would've been smart enough to be shooing them out of the streets and underground where possible without having to be told by Captain America. But, it gives an additional chuckle to the movie (as you'll see) so I won't be too hard on them for that.  :-)But hey - that's the worst I can come up with on this, and as you can see it's small potatoes.  If you enjoy these types of movies, this one will not let you down!  GO SEE & ENJOY IT!!  :-)

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The massive action scenes that are the heart of The Avengers just do not come across in home theater-even on a great system-as they do in a theater. Blu-Ray shows the details, but this film was shot for massive scale and thunderous sound. In normal viewing, the weaknesses of the film wear badly. The format consists of a 5 minute lecture by one of the characters about some ridiculous/complicated aspect of the story, followed by 10 minutes of massive action, then another lecture, then more action, etc. Everyone knows the characters (and the actors) from previous films, and they are introduced poorly and hardly developed at all, each given the spotlight for a minute here and there. Dialogue is terrible; the characters just mouth one ridiculous, convoluted explanation after another. Other than Thor, the characters are dull and flat, just doing the same old schtick. The film goes on forever. And ever. Even the astoundingly kinetic action scenes get boring. I'm a lifelong follower of the Avengers, liked many of the previous Marvel movies, and was predisposed to like this one. I didn't. I found "The Avengers" to be shallow and tedious, lacking any of the qualities needed to make it work in a home setting. I wanted to like this movie, thought I would, but to me it came across like Alvin and the Chipmunks on meth, playing with dynamite.  Jabber... Boom! Jabber... Boom!

reviewText: This movie is indeed a bloated and long clunker. The script and the story (is there even a story here?) don't make any sense. It's one of those movies that 30 minutes after watching it, you don't even remember what it was about. If one wants to say something good about the movie, at least one can point out that for a while it's fun watching a number of good actors (Robert Downey Jr., Mark Ruffalo, Jeremy Renner, etc) playing it for laughs. On the other hand, it is hard not end up annoyed by watching so many good actors wasting their talents with a very mediocre script.

reviewText: Joss Whedon.Okay, some of you need more reasons to see this movie.  Robert Downey Jr, Samuel L. Jackson, Scarlett Johannson, Chris Hemsworth.  More?  If you're familiar with Joss Whedon, you'll know that he's got the plotting, dialogue, and directing aspects of the movie covered.  If you've enjoyed the recent movies featuring these characters, this movie keeps everyone in character with no jarring discrepencies.Re: the title of my review - in my mind, "The Avengers" is in a 3-way tie with "Spider-Man 2" and "X-Men: First Class."  The movies "Thor" and "Iron Man" are pretty much pre-requisites to seeing this movie, but you can get away without having seen "The Incredible Hulk" or "Captain America".  If you haven't seen "Thor", you won't really understand who Loki is or what his motivation is.  Hmm, on second thought, even having seen "Thor," I'm not quite clear on that.  Nit-picks: the alien invaders are too easy to kill (Black Widow and Hawkeye can dispatch them easily with guns and arrows.)  During the final battle, surely some humans must be killed, but do you see any?  So, that's not very realistic.  The 3D isn't quite realistic: there appear to be three different and distinct layers of objects.  Inside his Iron Man suit, Tony Stark's face appears flat while the 3D computer graphics are floating in space.  Plot hole: at one point, Loki could have easily escaped, although this is somewhat "explained" later.If DC ever gets around to making a Justice League movie, they'll have their hands full trying to top, or even match, this one.  (Psst.  Hawkeye is Marvel's version of Green Arrow.  C'mon, everybody knows it.)
summary: My favorite Marvel movie to date...almost.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I've always preferred the Marvel superheroes to the DC crew for one important reason--character development. Marvel's heroes aren't just one-dimensional superheroes, they're fully-developed characters, people with personalities and histories and lives outside their hero personas. Whether it's the wisecracking playboy genius Tony Stark, aka Iron Man, who's grown up believing his father didn't love him...the arrogant prince of Asgard, Thor, whose father Odin sent him into exile to teach him a lesson and led him to love the people of Earth enough to become their protector...the troubled Bruce Banner, whose inner demons appear in the form of the angry green giant Hulk...Captain America, Steve Rogers, who emerged from a 70-year coma to find adjusting to his new life in the twenty-first century difficult enough without the added pressures of war...or the two elite assassins, Black Widow (Natasha Romanov) and Hawkeye (Clint Barton) who want to atone for the blood on their hands, each character has impressive depth.In The Avengers, the S.H.I.E.L.D. team has been working on harnessing the power of the Cosmic Cube (now known as the Tesseract). They inadvertently open a portal that allows Thor's adopted brother Loki, until now presumed dead, to enter the SHIELD complex and take possession of Dr. Eric Selvig and Hawkeye, physically and mentally...and launch an attack on the Earth. Loki is a king without a kingdom, and he plans to make the people of Earth bow to his will. He's quickly captured, but as he's being transported to his prison, a storm erupts. His reaction surprises Captain America, who asks if he's afraid of a little thunder. "I'm not fond of what comes after," he grumbles.What comes after is his brother, the God of Thunder, who has come from Asgard to take him home to face justice there. This results in a heated battle--literally--between Thor and Iron Man. Loki escapes, and the Avengers--a team of superheroes who don't even like each other (except for Black Widow and Hawkeye, who I suspect have more than a working relationship)--must learn to work together to save the Earth. Will they ever become friends? The obligatory after-end-credits scene might offer a clue.I'm fighting the urge to go into detail here. There are so many great scenes, including the death of a long-standing character, but I don't want to be accused of being a spoiler! Screenwriter/director Joss Whedon (Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Angel, Firefly and Serenity) gives The Avengers the perfect balance of heart, humor and nonstop action. The special effects are amazing but don't detract from what's most important in this film. The actors--Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, Chris Evans, Scarlett Johansson, Jeremy Renner, Mark Ruffalo, Tom Hiddleston, Cobie Smulders, Clark Gregg and Samuel L. Jackson--are all perfect for their roles. As Mark Ruffalo (Dr. Bruce Banner) said in an interview, there are a hundred reasons why this movie shouldn't have worked--but it does. Does it ever!There's something in The Avengers for everyone, and I can't recommend it strongly enough!
summary: Actually, I'd Give It 25 Stars If I Could!

reviewText: I love this movie.  That said, I am extremely disappointed at the one-liner in the movie when Thor, in reply to Black Widow when she admonishes Loki for killing "80 people in two days" says, "he's adopted".  I remember being in the movie theater when this got a big laugh.  The laugh didn't come from me.  Since I have adopted family members I didn't find it funny or okay.  Shame on the filmmakers for allowing this.  Not cool.As for the rest of the movie, I love it.  Really liked Mark Ruffalo as the Hulk and though the Iron Man character is more Robert Downey than Tony Stark, I like enjoy how it works in this film.All characters were continued from the previous movies, maybe with the exception of the Hulk.  Thor is still comedic and naive and not arrogant.  I never liked Thor's arrogance so that works well for me too.  Works well as a movie character.  The Black Widow character is very strong.  There are two exceptional fight sequences with Black Widow.  One is in this movie, the other in Ironman II.  Loki is not very strong, but acted well.  Great grin!  How does Black Widow deceive Loki so easily?Shield and Nick Fury are appropriately "government" and the story makes that clear.  Agent Colson is a big star in these movies.  He has a collection of superhero items.  More great humor there!Marvel studios really pulled this one together well from the other individual movies.Once in a while the narrations are a little too obvious.  Hulk tells the story of how he tried to end his life as one example.  Everybody looks surprised, but this is just meant for us to know Hulk's character in this movie.  That happens a little more often than necessary, but it's only a minor distraction.Really enjoy this movie and now that it's out on Blu-ray I'm already enjoying it over again.It's a shame that Marvel couldn't have done something to about the inexcusable insensitivity.  That line will do damage and there's no excuse for it.Looking forward to Deadpool!!

reviewText: This movie is pretty good if you accept it for what it is and don't expect much by way of story, acting, dialogue, etc. Basically, this movie is a prolonged battle scene after a slow and uninteresting first half. That said, the big battle is VERY cool. There are a few good one-liners as well. I was disappointed that the movie uses the Thor/Loki thing to drive the story. I thought Thor was the least well-done of the movies and the least interesting of the characters. Still, the movie is good fun for anyone who ever picked up a comic book or watched cartoons when they were a kid.Anyway, they sure did make a lot of money so I'm sure they will come out with another movie just like this one...Recommended.

reviewText: When the only character that has any depth of character, albeit meagre, is the villain, and he never changes--not even changing his signature look and smile the rest of the movie, then you don't have much of a movie.  Yes, the wisecracker self-absorbed Stark "grows" for no apparent reason (Pepper is not enough by herself to justify this change for anyone over the age of 16) and haven't we seen that story before anyway?Action scenes all from other movies.  Some laughs--even if they are equally now predictable--saves it from being two stars.  But no more Marvel for me even when I want brainless action adventure.
summary: Even for comic book movie it's too much action, too little thought

reviewText: Is an art or science of filming motion pictures however its much more science when your trying for 3-D. 3-D's pupose is to bring the veiwer into another reality. This means the fore ground and background are in focus and you do not see stationary objects move unless thats the fantasy or veiw every thing thru muchas. You expect some ghosting during the action because the skill or technogy is not there yet but double image rocks is just bad. Captain America worked because art deco lighting gives off glare , creates shadows , and there is alot of dust in war so you could over look bad cinematography. It is a period piece and the old rules of film do not work for 3-D. Subtitles are just plain stupid for example because the only floating words that work are Si - Fi sign'age. I saw nothing wrong with the writing or acting in this film but I paid for 3-D and did not get it in The Avengers .Fact is the bad is in the sandard Blu-Ray too and only the DVD played on a up verted unit worked. I would get that for cheap instead and ask Marvel to hire someone who understands 3-D on the next try. I know they can do better because Ghost Rider Spirit of Vengeance was and others are doing stuff years ahead of Marvel.

reviewText: I had heard this was fun and thinking with nostalgia of the weekend mornings I spent with Superman, I gave this a look.  Trouble is, it takes itself too seriously in places that should be fun and goes for laughs when it should be serious.  It's poorly paced and misguided in its scope.  I think three stars is generous actually. I'd give it two were it not for some favorite actors in the flick.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewerName: Onalee "Avid fan of sci-fi and James Marsters...
reviewText: I realized quickly that there was back-history here that I didn't know when I started watching this. I didn't realize I needed to watch other movies FIRST, such as Iron Man, Hulk, Thor, etc. I'm sure there were many jokes that I didn't get because of not having that back-history. My other problem with the movie was the sudden and unexplained turnabout in the behavior of the Hulk. I won't go into it here for spoilers, but his behavior changed 180 degrees at the end of the movie when it was convenient. That change was completely unexplained and didn't sit well with me. It's disappointing for a director like Joss Whedon to do that kind of cheap thing. Lastly, the battle at the end was much too drawn out and simply got boring after a while. They should've used about 5 minutes of that to explain the Hulk's change in behavior.I'd rate it an average movie, which was a disappointment coming from Joss Whedon.
summary: Really need to watch the other Marvel Movies (Iron Man, Hulk, Thor, Capt. America) First to fully get this
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: It's not horrendous, but there is just so little value in these kinds of movies anymore.  There's nothing here to encourage people in any kind of moral behavior, which I shouldn't be surprised about, and I'm becoming convinced that it's not good for people to live in fantasy all the time anyway. I recommend finding a better way of wasting your time...
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is the quintessential movie that relies on special effects over a substantive plot.  Waste of time in my opinion.

reviewText: well, at least 4-5 times a year, if the current record holds.if you haven't seen Thor, of all the backstories aside from iron man, that is a must-see.i love the avengers more every time i see it.  having it in 3D only increases watchability.  I have noticed that in 3D - including 2d to 3d conversion, as i commonly do with my favorite tv shows - i pick up on details (particularly expressions) that i missed even after multiple viewings.  well worth the investment in TV and player.now: what i can't wait for is...1) hawk and black widow backstory.  when will this be made film?  i'm hooked on black widow.  please, marvel and paramount, give us some more; i'd love the story where these two met.  i know black widow has a long and convoluted marvel history, but that's the point where their stories seem to most intersect with the film version of the Avengers.2) the best hulk to date.  i want more!3) iron man 3!!!!and i wouldn't miss another Thor, either.  mmmmmm mmmmm mmmmmm.  Maybe they can show us what happens when Thor gets Loki back to Asgard...

reviewText: And there came a day, a day unlike any other, when Earth's Mightiest Heroes found themselves united against a common threat! On that day, The Avengers were born, to fight the foes no single Super Hero could Withstand!This is the event comic fans have eagerly awaited. The culmination of every Marvel movie over the last several years...The AvengersWhen Loki, the maniacal adopted brother of Thor returns (having seemingly survived his fall from the Bifröst Bridge in "Thor") he delivers an Ultimatum to humanity, surrender or die. To combat this worldwide threat, Nick Fury the director of S.H.I.E.L.D (Strategic Homeland Intervention, Enforcement and Logistics Division) enacts The Avengers Initiative. The Team consists of Living Legend Captain America, Thor Loki's foster brother and Thunder God, The Invincible Iron Man, Master Archer Hawkeye, Super Spy The Black Widow and The Hulk strongest hero there is.Loki desires above all else, the Tesseract a sort of power source a Cosmic Cube (that once powered the Jötunn Casket of Ancient Winters) S.H.I.E.L.D came into possession of after Red Skull's defeat during World War II (Captain America: The First Avenger). Loki along with his Chutauri Alien Army plan to use the power of the Tesseract to enslave humanity.Can the Avengers defeat not only the invading Chutauri Army, but a crazed Norse God bent on conquest?
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I've read several of the reviews on this movie and while some nail it, others just make no sense.  WW says that he liked the Spiderman and Batman Franchises but stated he didn't like The Avengers as it was nothing but a "cash cow".  Really WW?  Are you saying that Spiderman III was made to better the franchise and wasn't a cash cow?  All of the movies you mentioned are cash cows and pretty good entertainment.The Avengers surpassed my expectations like no other movie ever has.  I had watched all the movies prior to the Avengers and was critical of a few of them.  I thought Captain America felt rushed and only created to move the franchise towards the Avengers movie.  Iron Man 2 was ok, but not as good as the first.  I happen to be very critical of movies and it drives my wife nuts.  I'm a penny pincher and will never go see a movie at the theater unless I think it's worthy.  I happened to go to this movie twice in the theater and loved it even more the 2nd time around.  Hands down the best superhero flik I've ever seen.  It surpassed the Batman and Spidey franchises and left me speechless and grinning ear to ear.  Even now, I will watch the trailer with my 3 year old and get chills.  Can't wait to watch it with him in the comfort of our own home !  September 25th I'm buying the movie for myself and my sister for her birthday.  She asked for it and she's not even a superhero movie fan.Thank you Joss Whedon for creating a movie with wonderful entertainment value.  Don't get me wrong, the movie was much more than just entertainment, it was great writing, great balance between characters, great humor, and just a little character development although none was needed since we had all the prequels.Joss is my hero.  Can't wait for phase II.
summary: Don't let the artsy farts critcs deter you from seeing this gem !
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is the third time I've watched this movie; and I gotta tell ya, although I felt it ran a bit long in the tooth towards the end of the first viewing; I now relish the ending and the pure beat down that ensues. Truly, the full embodiment of the Avengers as a child born in the 60's would expect.The characters are allowed to be fully independent while working together within a unit. The affects and directing are beautifully done. The script (does run a bit long towards the end, as I've already posted) is full and rich and doesn't miss much.If you are an Avengers fan, you will no doubt enjoy this movie again and again, just as I did.Pamela J. OlsonCitrus Heights, Ca.
summary: Loved it the first time, and the second, and the third.....

reviewText: I am very happy with my purchase.  The this package has it all: The Bluray, 3D, DVD, and Digital Copy versions and as an extra it includes the soundtrack for downloading.  The picture clarity is wonderful, even on the DVD copy (I checked).  It's just like being in the movies.  My family enjoyed watching it in the theatres, and now we can re-create that experience at home.  Fantastic actors, great director, and a fast-paced plot that tells the viewer a little more about each character/superhero.  Definitely one of my favourite movies.

reviewText: It's already released here in Oz for the past few days and have to say of all the live action 3D films presently ( excluding documentaries ) the full potential of 3D technology was used to great effect on this film. It really will blow your mind.The story is an absolute ripper all thanks to the genius of Joss Whedon his wit and humor and also trademark killing off unexpected important and well loved character/s ( agent Phil Coulson played by actor Clark Gregg ) is quite known during the Buffy/Angel/Firefly era.The feature film is an absolute Legend although sadly even with the amount of special features included on the 3D Blu Ray disc it is quite lacking in content.. but then you have to think hey -- The Hulk, Iron Man, Captain America, Thor and even Black Widow and Nick Fury already had heaps of special feature interviews and the like done in every one of those DVD/Blu Ray discs, fans just need to collect them to see it all.
summary: Best use of 3D tech in film although special features is a little bit lacking in greatness.

reviewText: This was the first Marvel movie I saw that I actually liked ( the only other phase 1 movie I saw was Iron Man, which I didn't like).  Before this I'd been disappointed by every Marvel movie I saw (which was everything except for the good ones related to this; & I still haven't seen the Incredible Hulk).  But this was by far the best comic book movie ever (The Dark Knight is overrated)!  It was excellent all the way through.  I kept expecting something really stupid to happen & ruin it but no such luck.  Everybody was prefectly portrayed in thi film, except for Iron Man who was funny but still a bit too much of a jerk for me to like, but that's the only disappointment here.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: For comic fans we are truly living in a golden age. At one time getting a cartoon of your favorite super hero made was a giant victory. Movies were rare and TV shows even more rare and unlikely.Avengers is the dream of every kid who spent rainy afternoons adoring four color masterpieces from the likes of Marvel comics.The  Genius Joss Whedon has used his skill at working with ensemble casts to create a movie packed with action, thrills and comedy. One of the top grossing movies in the history of movies is still fantastic on Blu-Ray and DVD.The extras are great and includes a mini-movie not seen anywhere else which is actually a prequel to the S.H.I.E.L.D. TV Show.The Video and sound are great the packaging looks terrific.
summary: The Dream of a fanboy's Lifetime

reviewText: This was a gift from Amazon due to the delay of the release of Marvel Cinematic Universe: Phase One - Avengers Assembled (10-Disc Limited Edition Six-Movie Collector's Set). I want to thank the folks from Amazon...They Rock!  It's a nice Blu-Ray /DVD combo which is perfect if you don't need 3-D or a digital copy. I've review films before, but there's nothing I could add to the Avengers that you haven't already read or seen for yourself. If you haven't watched it with Joss Wedon's comments going on, do it! DO  IT  NOW!  He's makes some really excellent comments and tells some good stories. I saw it 7 times in the theaters and 81 times at home. The Only thing I would Change is I would have liked to Have Captain America do a little more damage to Loki in Germany. Loki tossed him around a little too much for my tastes. Remember, Capp defeated the HULK and is worthy enough to lift Thor's Hammer, so I would have preferred to not have him bounced about like a rag doll. That said, Everyone should own a copy of this movie and this version is perfect for every level of collector...or for a non-collector. I just want to say this last bit: If they put Spider-Man in Avengers 2, I want Toby ! (I know that is not likely to happen, but if it did...Cool!)
summary: They Don't Call It "The Greatest Super Hero Movie of All Time"  for Nothing!

reviewText: The writing of the movie - especially in the early going - was poor.  The writers played up the ego issues too much and made the characters too immature.  At the end, the heros are able to survive too much against too many.  Could have made all more credible by using the threat of what was coming before the miraculous conclusion.  Keep the action but keep it believable.  Give your audience a chance to be a little smarter.
summary: Some nice special effects, content kept me interested - barely
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The only way this movie could be better is if it was an adult film with gritty cinematography. Created as it is in the Marvel Style ( bright, clear, witty, sarcastic, comic-book-y ) this movie is fabulously entertaining. Now for the critique: the story makes little if no sense. It is just an excuse to have a big fight in Manhattan. I actually pity the poor screenwriters; they have to take the Marvel Universe, excerpt parts of it, and weave together a story with certain characters. This seems like an impossible task. It is surprising that the film holds together at all. There is also the problem of showing real damaged bodies. There must have been horrible dismemberment and wounding of people, but none of it is shown. There is also the problem of the heroes; we have a group made up of a God, a man in an armored super-suit, a super-enhanced soldier man, an indestructible hulk, a regular woman who can fight well, and a regular man who can shoot nifty arrows. If there was any reality in this movie, the God, the iron man, and the hulk MIGHT be able to fight. The Black Widow, Hawkeye, and Cap would have been killed almost instantly; but it's a comic-book movie... anything can happen. I admit that the digitally-designed SHIELD facilities and heli-carrier look fabulous and almost believable... not too enormously complex. Some of the sequences in this film work very well; probably the best is when the Hulk thrashes Loki around like a rag doll... very satisfying. The movie does have a bit of a problem with continuity. There are lulls that go on too long, and a sort of a part 1 and part 2 to the action... but it does all come together nicely. we adults who watch it realize that in any remotely realistic universe the only ones who would have survived would be the Hulk and Thor, and why in tarnation didn't anyone think of shooting some nukes up into that portal in the first place. And I always like the little afterthought-endings that Marvel tacks on, to entice us towards the next development. This time we get the inference that the bad guys have to answer to another more powerful alien ruler, who we only see briefly as he turns his head. I got the impression somehow even before he turned his head that it was the Super Skrull. Thanks to obsessive people avidly reading reviews, I now know that the character is someone named Thanos, whom I very vaguely recall from reading Marvel comics 30 years or so ago. I have no idea what he does or where he fits in, but obviously, it's easy to find out nowadays. One last thought, I just watched a few bits and pieces again of the movie, a day later. It is even better than I thought. The set designs, the dialogue, the witty banter, the costumes... it is breathtaking.
summary: probably as good as possible in the Marvel style
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: We saw this movie three times in the theater and have watched it twice at home. We will likely wear it out!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Wow, some of these reviewers take themselves way too much seriously. I will try to be brief-er. I will try not to result to expletives. I rented. I am overjoyed at this movie. The cast supreme, the story line excellent, the acting (except Samuel Jackson) prime. The whole movie-epitome. Some of the acting scenes may have been a bit glitchy, and scenes may seem sometimes too comic book, well that's what the movie is about, Free your mind & enjoy it without trying to be a film critic. A Disney movie where people die? Awesome. The battle between Iron Man & Thor? Iron Man & Hulk? Epic. The flying battleship with cloaking abilities? Insane, gotta get me one of them!. I finally after the second viewing, got the scene after the credits, that was the Scharma Iron Man referenced after the battle, whatever that is. We don't got them in central Ms, probably would have to wear my shoes or sumpin'. If you can let go of your senses, your elite-ism & just want to enjoy something, then this movie is for you. I laughed in some scenes until I cried. I might have been over enthusiastic about it, but it was what I perceived. Also, it was a good set up for the sequels. Rent or own this movie.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: These movies make me feel like I am re-living my tees all over again and those were fun times.I gave four stars to this movie because I don't believe in the perfect story. There is always a glitch and what usually make a story good is how hard it is to find that glitch. Can't tell you what. You have to watch the movie carefully and pay attention to all the characters. However one comment on one super hero I have to point out: Tony Stark, alias Iron-Man. I like his positive attitude, never turn down and always ready with a solution. We all should be like him. Great special effects, as usual, and acting was wonderful. If you're a comic freak like me, go ahead watch it.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I am a huge fan of the Christopher Nolan 'Dark Knight' trilogy...but, nowhere is it written that all legends have to be dark paths to redemption. Sometimes, the greatest myths and legends are simply the kind of tales that demand to be re-told...generation after generation.Joss Whedon's 'Avengers' ascends the icy slopes of the superhero Olympus; and lays claim to that pinnacle and its throne.There are layers of earthbound and extraterrestrial treachery threatening the human race; but, their potential saviors often distracted (and, hilariously) by a variety of rivalries that run the gamut from sibling, to battle of the sexes all the way to 'my hammer's bigger than yours'.What makes this cocktail really fizz are the expert proportions poured by Director Whedon: the cold calculations of Hawkeye and Black Widow, duplicity of Nick Fury and Loki, the stalwart heroisms of Captain America and Thor, wild card unpredictability that is the Hulk and the champagne patter of Iron Man make for a highly addictive and intoxicating mix.The talented cast rises to the the challeng of a witty, juggernaut script; and, the final elements of eye-tickling effects and a rousing score are what all combine to earn my (very rare) perfect 5-star score.Its a rare movie that makes me feel absolutely satisfied at the end; while immediately yearning for the next adventure. "The Avengers" is truly the stuff of legends.
summary: Epic, exhilerating, heartfelt and humorous myth-making
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: If you like anything, you should probably like this. Some things you might like would be: Hulk saving Ironman like WHOA! and Bruce Banner saying "I'm always angry" as well as Scarlett Johannsen looking way too hot, and Captain America taking command.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Awesome Movie for the whole family. Has lots of action in it, if you like action movies. Bought as Christmas Gift
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is Joss Whedon at his very best.  If you are in the extreme minority and have not seen the prequels, you must see the first Iron Man and Captain America.  All the others are much lesser films and unnecessary to enjoy the full impact of The Avengers.  There are only two other films that have engendered a greater desire to partake of the next installment with a given cast of characters.  Those being The Empire Strikes Back and The Fellowship of the Ring.  Regardless, this is an excellent film on its own merit, and I know of no one regardless of age or sex that has not raved about this film.  I do except certain film critics that I am certain do not actually belong to the human species, like Matt Pais of the Chicago Tribune, but then it never hurts to know whose reviews you can ignore with vehement disdain (and he or it certainly qualifies).
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: It's already been said by many, but if you want great action, beautiful special effects, a bit of great well-balanced humor in a sci-fi action adventure this one should not be missed.  If for any crazy reason you have not yet seen this film, it is a must - among the best most well-directed action movies.  Great mix of characters, and the acting is right up there - fun, fun fun!  I own it and will watch it multiple times in the years ahead.

reviewText: While this movie is of course fine entertainment, I was disappointed to discover that the item Amazon is selling is a version intended for sale in Canada. I have noticed this before with some other DVDs purchased from Amazon. The first tip off is that the normal warning screens (anti-piracy, etc) are phrased differently from what is normally sold in the States, referring to 'territories', etc. This is not a problem, but on this DVD of The Avengers, I noticed a couple annoying things:- the DVD is apparently programmed to turn subtitles on automatically, and those subtitles are in French. I had to turn them off to watch normally.- even with the subtitles turned off, every time a character spoke in another language (during the scenes in India and with the Russian criminals), French subtitles appeared on the screen. I don't recall of, in the theatrical presentation, of there were any subtitles in these scenes, but I was unable to get English subtitles to appear in these instances, and could not get rid of the French ones (which do me no good). I tried this DVD in a couple different players and got the same results.I don't know if the DVDs being sold in stores in the States are a different version from the ones being sold by Amazon, but I intend to find out. If the one I buy in a store is free of these inappropriate subtitles (assuming my perspective as somebody from the States), I will be returning this DVD to Amazon and complaining strongly that they lost no other version unless one buys Blu-Ray.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I have seen this movie several times and loved it each time. Hulk is my favorite. Great cast, really good story line. Can't say enough. Best movie of the year. You have to really dislike science fiction not to like this movie. Action packed and great graphics. Must see.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Until now each of the movies have been about only individual heros but now they team up.  Joining forces to fight the evil Loki and prevent the destruction of the earth.  They need to figure out how to work together and what Loki is up to and how to stop it.  The credits contain some revealing details about a possible sequel.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I waited a long time for this movie, and the pay-off was definitely worth it. I saw it 3 times at the theater. Measly words like 'epic' or 'awesome' are not even close to describing this brilliant film. This movie is jam-packed with action, explosions, fight scenes, and comedy. There is never a dull moment, and time just flies by during this 142 minute extravaganza. The agency of SHIELD accidentally use the Tesseract to open a mysterious portal and unleashes Thor's evil brother, Loki. Loki brainwashes Dr. Selvig and Hawkeye to help him bring his army, the Chitauri to Earth. Nick Fury assembles Iron Man, Captain America, Black Widow and the Incredible Hulk to help stop him. Thor joins the group later. (Thor is my absolute favorite Avenger and he had some decent action scenes and funny moments. I wish he had a little more screen time) Tony Stark and Steve Rogers often clash with each other, but they must all work together to defeat Loki and become....THE AVENGERS!!!!!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: With a five-movie ad campaign preceding it there was a lot riding on this movies success...and it delivers.  And even with the baggage of what amounts to 5 prequels, The Avengers stands by itself as a perfectly capable and well-done movie without need for a cap or a buffer.  The principal actors (Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, RDJ, Mark Ruffalo, Samuel L Jackson, and Tom Hiddleston) all deliver great performances and shine in their roles.  The sidecast (aside from the paint-by-numbers Hawkeye and Black Widow) also do a great job of carrying their weight, and Joss Whedon certainly knows how to write a movie when he isn't bogged down in overly-witty banter and staring at Scarlet Johanssen's ass.
summary: The Superhero Movie Everyone Was Waiting For
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers
