Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This review is for those interested in the 3D for Avengers 3D.AVENGERS 3D:The 3D in Avengers 3D is good overall, and generally has the best 3D moments in the final epic action sequence, where the 3D, usually on par with Captain America 3D, steps up the depth, parallax 3D layers, and Pop Out Moments closer to the strong 3D level. If you are a 3D fan, this one is worth a purchase for the 3D.3D Highlights:All of the Avengers combined their powers to take down the enemy by the final act, with each 3D shot looking great in 3D featuring:Iron Man jetting past buildings,Thor slamming his 3D hammer into the back of a soaring beast,Captain America tossing his shield into the screen towards the enemy foot soldiers,The Hulk smashing rock into rubble as it flies out at the screen,and plenty more 3D worthy moments including Loki, Jeremy Renner and Scarlett Johannsen in 3D kicking butt.Does the 3D enhance the movie? If you want an extra dimension, with characters like Thor or Iron Man, standing out apart from the background, as though you were almost seeing them in real life, then this is the closest you'll get for now. Would it have been better if it was filmed in 3D instead of post converted from a 2D source? If done right, yes, but what is here is done really well.3D overall: 4/5. (not an average) Better than average, but there is room to increase the 3D power in the sequel.3D Parallax Layers: 4/5. Good. But Great by the lenghty end battle.3D Depth: 4/5. You can see deep into the screen generally.3D Volume: 3/5. Characters look generally lifelike with depth to their features.3D pop out: 3/5. The pop out moments by the end are nice.3D Consistency: 3/5. The end really stood out strongly, the rest was good.3D Highlights: The end battle throughout, the outer space stairs.3D strength similar to: Captain America 3D, Thor 3D, not as strong as Avatar 3D, which was mostly filmed in 3D, the others converted from 2D.3D Worth a Buy? Yes. Recommended in 3D. If you have a 3D TV, don't miss it.Quick Movie Review: With plenty of great action moments throughout, Avengers is one of the best action movies I've seen in years, thanks to one of the most epic, action packed, and incredible ending battle scenes gracefully combining all of the current Avengers working together to take down the overwhelming enemy, under Loki's command. The best thing about Avengers, despite a slow build up, is the well done balancing of showcasing each lead hero, offering them plenty of time in the spot light to feel like they each contributed a very important role to the movie. This is how to do it. Rating: 9/10 for the movie. Awesome.
summary: 3D Review of The Avengers 3D: Good, but not as strong as the movie

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: If I was 12, I think I would have enjoyed this film. It was beautifully filmed fluff, through and through, all style and no substance, like the G.I.Joe cartoon's I watched on Saturday mornings as a little girl. The dialogue was unrealistic, endless, and annoying. The script had to be three hundred pages long and I never thought I could find Robert Downey Jr. enough of an unfortunate presence in a film that I'd be fantasizing they'd kill his character off but, in spite of my abiding love for Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang, I wanted Ironman squashed. None of the characters were interesting, endearing, intelligent, crafty, or even useful in the most general of terms. They were, however, witty. Yes, witty. Witty when the villain was attacking. Witty when they were about to die. Witty when they were sitting on the toilet. Witty when they were talking in their sleep. I haven't heard this much punning since I was in high school watching immature high school themed movies to try and "fit in" with the less intelligent girls who though X-files was too complicated and political science was so confusing. If you are young and easily impressed by flash, you'll like it. If you also love the comics, you'll probably love it. If you are thirty or older, a lover of cinema, a person who appreciated Singer's X-Men as well as shows like Battlestar Galactica, then this film will bore you half to death. I fell asleep each time I tried to watch it until, finally, I doped up on coffee and forced myself to suffer through it. It took a rewatching of The Returned Season One and Season One of Battlestar for me to cleanse myself of the dialogue laden nightmare of standing around and misogyny that was The Avengers. First Buffy's lady parts stole Angel's soul and now the only female lead is a psychopathic serial killer who is "dripping red". What will Whedon think of next. Perhaps a snuff film about Eastern European tween girls or pushing old ladies off cliffs. In any case, I wrote this for one reason: if you have a daughter at an impressionable age, this could do real damage to watch. Get her something French or British to watch and leave this for the future rapists of the world to enjoy. Even I felt devalued after watching this and I'm basically in love with myself. Incidentally, Psychomania was the zombie biker flick staring George Sanders, from the seventies I believe, and it was my old worst film ever. I've seen thousands and this takes the prize.
summary: Worst film I've ever seen and I've seen Psychomania.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Oh, goodness me.Why couldn't I have just enjoyed this movie? That would've been so nice. I really have no desire to lambast a movie I anticipated for months. After watching five films and only liking two of them (Iron Man and Captain America), I was so ready for the pay-off. I would like nothing more than to gush about how great it was.That would be nice.Sadly, The Avengers just didn't do it for me.The whole point of this movie is its characters, the team the movie gets its title from. It's the characters most of all we want to see done right, because they can liven a mediocre plot. Character, unfortunately, is a major problem in The Avengers.I get that Cap's development is being saved for Cap 2, but guess what? That's STUPID. We should've seen him reacting to cell phones, reacting to the internet, reacting to the god damn fact that everyone he used to know is dead. Something. Joss Whedon said he had a scene where Steve meets an aged Peggy Carter, but he cut it. Damn. Steve Rogers isn't even REMOTELY explored here. What does it mean to be looked up to? What does it mean to be that one person that everyone counts on to do the right thing? And where's the *world's* reaction to *him*? Cap is a renowned hero that kids in the Marvel universe read about in school. Thousands of people admire him. Him being alive in the present day is a big deal for the whole world. It isn't touched on at all. Also during the final battle, just how the flying frak is Steve able to bark orders in a world he's SEVENTY YEARS displaced from?!Stark and Thor aren't explored much either. They are static, relying on past characterization, and their individual personalities aren't done justice. Stark is his old witty self but I feel like they've almost exhausted everything they could do with him in Iron Man 1 and 2, making him feel kind of hokey here. He seems to develop respect for Steve later on, but there is no defining moment in which he admits it. That and discussing his dad would have been easy opportunities to develop him and remind us what kind of person he is. After all, we want to know just what sort of people are protecting Earth.Thor is just *there*, not shown to be struggling with the notion that if he fails, his love interest is doomed. Does he find comfort in knowing that Asgard will be spared? This is the person willing to sacrifice himself to the Destroyer (sort of...). He doesn't even apologize for his (half) brother's actions, does he? It would have been nice if we saw him in Asgard, to ease us into things, to give a sense of character, to remind us who he is and to show just how the HELL he got back to Earth.Only Scarlett Johansson as Black Widow and Mark Ruffalo as Bruce Banner get any semblance of a character arc. I actually thought Black Widow was one of the highlights of the movie. She isn't forced into a formulaic romance with Hawkeye or any of the other leads and she generally gets to do a lot of things important to the plot (tricking Loki, closing the portal, etc.).I thought The Incredible Hulk was pretty bad. Edward Norton's strong performance aside (and I was *very* dismayed he wouldn't be returning), I wouldn't care if that film was written out of continuity. That's because Ruffalo is just as good in the role and gives Banner a very different but appropriate feel. It's like they started over with the character again, in ways such as Banner calling the Hulk "the other guy". He seems to learn that the Hulk can be a force for good, but there's no big moment where he decides to be a hero (there's definitely a trend of things being glossed over). In any case, he's now a willing member of the Avengers. See, he actually came out of this movie different than when he began. I hated that he only becomes the Hulk twice though, and the first time he's completely crazed. It did result in a cool Thor/Hulk fight, but what's the point?As for Hawkeye, why oh why oh WHY was he brainwashed until the last act of the movie? What waste of the character *and* Jeremy Renner!I realize with alarm that the problem is not that anyone steals the show, it's that no one does. I wasn't connected to anyone. Relationships between the characters are not developed. While the characters' initial distrust of S.H.I.E.L.D. is a very good way of bringing out their contrasting personalities, a lot of what you get is bickering. No one seems willing to form a team and everyone is quick to argue. Why would I want to sit there and watch them argue? I wanted to see them become a team. They did, eventually, but that was out of pure necessity, not because they learned to work with and respect each other.Coulson's death really pissed me off. Clark Gregg was fantastic in that role and his fanboyism towards Steve Rogers was delightful. My heart soared with glee when I saw him confront Loki with that oversized blaster. We needed a supporting character like that. It was at that moment he practically became my favorite character. But who cared about him other than Fury and Maria Hill? Even Stark barely knew him. I felt something, but no one else did.Special mention must go to Samuel L. Jackson as Nick Fury. His useless appearance in Iron Man 2 was goofy, but I really liked him here. He gets his fare share of action and you can take him seriously. His final conversation with Coulson is great; he looked how I felt. Cobie Smulders as Maria Hill was also good, and I think she did a lot, contrary to what others say. She could have been used more though, I mean if Black Widow and Hawkeye can get in on the climactic action, why not her?Now my thoughts on villains. Tom Hiddleston is brilliant as Loki, and it's clear from interviews that he's very enthusiastic about the role. Yet the character seems very different from when he was in Thor. There he was on the tip of being a tragic villain, while still held back by the fact that every time it seemed like he was going to turn out to be a complex character, it just didn't happen. Still his magical and manipulative nature brims with potential. In The Avengers, something about him feels oddly...jumbled. It seems to be implied that something is wrong with him. Maybe he's been floating through the cosmos, which drove him mad. Maybe he has been abused by the Chitauri and Thanos, making him exasperated, desperate, and crazy, or he's actually being controlled by them. At the very end of the film it looks like he's snapped out of it, mellowed somehow. The extent of his magic power is also not clear; did he really make Banner pick up the scepter? I don't know what to make of it.I wish he weren't so constrained by his new masters, that he was doing something a bit more personal than taking over the world. Showing what exactly happened to Loki after the events of Thor would have helped. In any case I don't see why so much time needed to be spent on Loki and the Chitauri, considering that their actions aren't very interesting. Why not get to Thanos already? Disappointingly, Loki appears to be genuinely afraid of Thor now, is easily fooled by Black Widow, is somehow downed by one of Hawkeye's arrows, and generally gets smacked around more than he gets to be menacing. As funny as it was to see him get ragdolled by the Hulk, Loki really doesn't get his due. I mean, why not see him actually fight the Hulk? Better yet it would've been good to see him *really* let loose and fight all the Avengers at once.This myriad of character-based problems is disturbing considering director/writer Joss Whedon's usual management of ensembles. He's been known to center an entire episode around one supporting character, from their perspective, multiple times in shows such as Buffy the Vampire Slayer. Where was the love here?The Avengers doesn't have a good plot to fall back on. I don't know if I'm too demanding a viewer, but I need to be eased into things. So I find that there's something very wrong with the first Loki battle. Captain America just shows up, and we have absolutely no idea how this guy is reacting to fighting an Asgardian. Bam, here's the Cap/Loki fight, enjoy! Then Iron Man arrives, but no relationship was developed between him and Rogers beforehand. Because of that, when I saw them fight together, I just felt empty. Maybe if Loki had some minions, or a second in command, and Stark and Rogers had formed some camaraderie through fighting them, I would've been satisfied. Amora the Enchantress or Absorbing Man could easily have filled that role. Why the rush to fight Loki?How about if all the Avengers (including Banner) had met at the Helicarrier first and gotten to know each other? Then they might have heard about Loki's minions and gone to fight them, to see how they all work together in the field. When they find out Loki is in Germany, that's when Cap, Iron Man, and Black Widow deal with him. That might have been cool.Throughout most of The Avengers, I was intensely bored. The Iron Man/Thor fight is so forced and stupid it's practically offensive. Then comes the assault on the Helicarrier, which goes on for an *insanely* long time. This leads to the extremely long final battle. Maybe I wouldn't have minded that the final act was long, but having such a pointlessly massive action sequence before that burned me out. So much time is spent on this action, so much time that could have been used for other things. It's no wonder the original cut was three hours.I find it funny that I went out of my way to make I sure I didn't know what exactly Loki's army was, only for it to be revealed within the first few minutes of the film. But why even mention that they're the Chitauri? Who cares? They don't have a word of dialogue. They don't have any indication of personality. We don't know their goals. We don't know where they come from. They can be killed rather easily. Hell it isn't even explained that they're supposed to be aliens. As if that weren't insulting enough, they're a hive mind that can conveniently be defeated by destroying their...monthership? Fleet? Homeworld? Space station? Colony? And you know what made me laugh? From the front, those big leviathan things look just like Terry Pratchett's Discworld, but without the four elephants. Talk about anti-climactic. Can you imagine if Earth was invaded by lots of Great A'Tuins? They're just not making very good use of the Marvel source material.Like I did with Captain America, I will compare this movie to the TV show The Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes. The villain Dr. Franklin Hall, Graviton, escapes from imprisonment and decides to use his mastery over gravity to destroy an entire city as revenge against S.H.I.E.L.D. (he also happened to get his powers while trying to revive Abraham Erskine's work for them). This is how the Avengers are formed; they spend a whole twenty-minute episode fighting Graviton. It's ridiculously awesome. Everyone gets there due, Graviton's powers are *terrifying* to behold, and the characters realize they work well together. Franklin Hall is a very interesting character to boot. Having that one human threat makes everything focused. This movie would have benefited from something like that. Instead we got faceless, highly destructible aliens and Loki getting pummeled a lot.People say the film is supposed to be nothing but fun. Then I must ask you why it tries to be dramatic. If it's nothing but fun, why kill Phil Coulson? Why the nuclear dilemma during the final battle? Why the distractingly tear-jerking shift to Iron Man's peril when destroying the Chitauri fleet? And this amidst such things as Thor's rather silly "He's adopted" line. If The Avengers was originally intended to be pure fun, in practice it has an identity crisis.The Avengers wore me out, it's made me wary of the "Marvel formula" that permeates these films. I feel reluctant to continue further into the Marvel Cinematic Universe. But being the fan I am, I undoubtedly will be there whether I like it or not...
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: KIDS FIRST! Film Critic, Talia Rashba reviews this film below:This movie is absolutely fantastic!  It is packed with a ton of action and humor and will transport you into an amazing supernatural world where it is all about the good guys fighting the bad.The story is about a group of famous superheroes that come together to defeat the evil Loki, who has stolen a powerful energy cube that he intends to use to take over the world.The superheroes include Iron Man, Captain America, The Hulk, Thor, Black Widow and Hawkeye. Each one has a unique and special supernatural power that they use to help them do their job. At first, the superheroes fight about being a team but eventually they work together to complete the mission. The Avengers could have ended up being a typical superhero movie but it isn't.  Because there are so many heroes, it is much more creative and entertaining.The Avengers is packed with fabulous actors. Robert Downey Jr. plays Tony Stark, also known as Iron Man.  Just like he was in the Iron Man movie, he thinks he is better than everyone else, but luckily, he is really quite funny so you end up liking him a lot. Captain America (Chris Evans) is strong and serious, and he is always ready to get the job done. Actor Mark Ruffalo plays the ferocious green form known as the Incredible Hulk. He really stands out and takes over the scenes he is in. Superhero Thor (Chris Hemsworth) has some of the most incredible battle scenes and Black Widow, portrayed by the beautiful Scarlett Johansen, is the one who convinces the others to put aside their differences and work with each other.An interesting fact is that actor Lou Ferrigno, who has played the Hulk in almost every film since 1978, is actually the Hulk's voice in the movie. Avengers is written and directed by Joss Whedon who does an amazing job.  He makes sure that there is a lot of humor in the movie and that the action scenes really grab your attention.  The special effects were incredible. The super heroes change from their every day selves into their super natural selves in an interesting and fun way. The fight scenes and explosions are unbelievable.  Also, there is a really neat headquarters for the agency that you just have to see for yourself!Even though it is rated PG-13 I think kids ages 11, as well as all adults will love this movie, especially if action is their thing. I am giving this film a 5 out of 5 stars and recommending that you see it right away!
summary: Absolutely Fantastic! Tons of Action and Humor!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Marvel's The Avengers is by far the best movie of the summer. Rarely do we get the opportunity to see movies with so many spectacular action figures. The fight scenes are phenomenon and exciting with dashing colors and explosions. I was so excited to see this movie when it came out. The movie starts with an attack from an alternate universe who wants to destroy the world. The Avengers must come together to save the world with their unique skills. The challenge with bringing so much talent together, is figuring out how to tame their massive egos.I cannot say enough about how well the action is sequenced together. The creativity with the characters costumes are so fantastic. This is a masterpiece and to see some of the most outstanding figures working together, makes this a must see film! Great experience for children of all ages!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie. Especially the scene at the end of the credits. It had a lot of heart and friendship in it.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

They do a good job of presenting the characters individually, so that even if you've not seen the previous films, you can still enjoy it. Well done!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Finally!  A superhero movie that's an unapologetic reproduction of the story you would see in a real comic book!  All the same cheesy dialogue and witty one-liners we would see in a comic overlaid above a surprisingly well-written and intelligent story on a very large scale.  This is what you may have missed if you aren't into comics, or set them aside with your youth.There is nothing anyone could say is bad about this movie.  It is well done in every way, superbly acted, visually stunning and a lot of good old-fashioned fun.  The sets are highly detailed, the visual effects are outstanding and the story moves without pause to a climax that you would not see coming if you haven't already heard about it.Lots of action, lots of laughs, lots of awesome visuals, lots of fun for the young and young-at-heart.  Must-see.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I know there has been some criticism of this film, that it was too childish, boring, silly or ridiculous!  Everyone ofcourse is entitled to their opinion.  Having said that, I think the movie started off a bit slow in certain areas but eventually it did live up to the action.  Did I think it was the best film ever?  To be honest, I can't really say at this point. I thought it was alright, definitely not boring by any means!  All the super heroes did an excellent job in all respects, therefore I am giving it 5 stars.  I just didn't care for Samuel L. Jackson's role in this film, perhaps they could have chosen someone else.I hope you watched the credits at the end which includes some additional footage.As far as the bluray is concerned: 10/10 for sound and picture quality.****MINOR SPOILER BELOW, PLEASE DO NOT READ IF YOU HAVEN'T SEEN THIS MOVIE!!****In my opinion, it was Iron Man that actually saved the day in the end.  The other super heroes played their part well, but Iron Man put a stop to all the violence by taking the missile to the mothership.
summary: A bit of a slow start building up to the ultimate climax.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Summer Movie season's here! Finally some movies worth going to the cinema for. My 1st anticipated movie and...it's a HIT! Hats off to Whedon on handling this ensemble. No main character was given too much/too little time. It was well rounded. I loved the banter between them and the acting was good as well. Loki had charisma as the villain. Superb action scenes. It was a living comicbook. My only complaint is it didn't have that suspense. Why? Because Marvel already made it known that sequels are in the works. So you knew they all were going to make it. I look for the heroes to make it anyway but give me the illusion they might not. Also, the Chitauri punked Loki but Loki gave The Avengers more trouble than they did. How's that? Hmm. And there were some impossible feats by Hawkeye & Black Widow; regular humans. Anyway, not a disappointment at all. Fun! And it should be. Batman it isn't. I don't expect the darkness or as much complexity. TDKR will give me that in spades. Meantime, The Avengers gets an A.I still love this movie and still would give a 4.5 score but on the high end. The only small problem for me still is the weak aliens. They just posed no real threat to me. Loki, however, was great. Glad I own this movie.

reviewText: *authors note this is for the one disc dvd version of this movie*hello alli have been a marvel fan for a long time and this movie is the reason why. This movie proves that superhero team up are possible and when you got the right crew, are incredible. This movie is the movie DC comics wish it could make with superman(although the dark knight series comes close) if they make a justice league movie they need to get the entire phase one line up including this movie and make every director, actor, and crew men watch them all to know how a incredible movie should be made. first of we get the hulk all of the marvel fans especially fans o the incredible hulk have been wanting or soooooooooo long. Mark ruffalo does and excellent job of portraying the hulk as he should be a doctor trying to help people as payment for what the other guy does. He truly shines in this movie.The rest of the avengers also are incredible and take the characters that they portrayed in the other phase one movies and with joss whedon's help make them more incredible. however there is one minor gripe. And that comes from hawkeye played by Jeremy Renner. I believe he should have been also given a little more background in the movie and if allowed too would have also shines as well. But this is a minor gripe. This movie is one of those once in a generation movies that will be remembered and i can not wait for the next round of movies. Still this is a movie that should be seen by all and while there was not much in the way of extras on this dvd version the assembling the ultimate team feature was a nice little add on and i liked it alot. SO if you are movie fan get this movie, if you are a comic fan you should have already own this movie and if you are a Avengers fan you should preorder this movie or buy it as soon as you can.
summary: Marvel's The Avengers a must own for any xcomicbook movie fan

reviewText: The third biggest grossing film of all time, not only was this a huge box office hit, it was also critically acclaimed. We've seen Marvel films featuring the individual superheroes, Iron Man, Captain America, The Hulk, Thor, Black Widow, and Hawkeye. Here in one movie they are all assembled to fight Loki, the rogue half-brother of Thor and his army of extraterrestrials, known as the Chitauri. The film has stunning CGI visuals, which have almost become routine in superhero films...but this effort manages to take CGI visuals to another level. Joss Whedon does a fine job behind the camera in crafting and coordinating a complex melange of super heroes and their various sci/fi apparati. He also scripted the film, so he gets double credit for it's excellence.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: My inner child is something I value most, and that inner child remembers my days of being a little kid and playing with my Iron Man and Captain America toys, as well as wishing I was the Incredible Hulk. I also remember watching the Hulk cartoons and begging my parents to get me the latest issue of of the next Captain America comic books. So as you can tell, I'm a comic books have played a huge role in my childhood, and that being said, it was with great excitement that I awaited The Avengers. Having seen all the Avengers movies until then and owning them all on blu-ray, I remember even watching them all up until Thursday May 3rd, which was when the midnight premiere took place. My buddy and I even wore Iron Man masks to the screening.I'm most happy to report, to say The Avengers did not disappoint is an unforgivable understatement. It may just be the best comic book movie I've ever seen. It shines dozens of lamps on The Dark Knight and it makes the previous Avengers movies (even Thor, which I loved despite not having been familiar with the Thor mythos before seeing it) look like the Fantastic Four movies.Everything about this movie was pitch perfect. Starting with the script. Joss Whedon had penned the script and it's obvious he has done his homework on not just the mythos and everything else in the world of The Avengers, but also what the audience loves about the heroes and expects from a movie about The Avengers. Everyone was given a sense of humour and played their cards right- Tony Stark was his usual lovable jerk self, and had his typical attitude problems that were hard not to love. He was given a great amount of action as well and the scene near the end where he pushes the nuclear bomb into the portal was purely beautiful intensity. Captain America was his usual kickass self, and every one of his action scenes were hard to not love. Thor was hilarious as well and his scenes with Loki were just amazing. Particularly the scene near the end on Stark tower where he forces Loki to watch the mayhem going on in the city and asks "Is this what you want?". Aso, FINALLY the Hulk has had justice done. He's given a sense of humour, which the other movies absolutely failed on. I'm happy to report the movie did not fail there. And who can forget the dialogue? Classic Avengers dialogs, down to the last inch. "We need a plan of attack!" "I have a plan. Attack." and "WhTs the matter, not fond of thunder and lightning?" "I don't like what comes after."The characterization is really what counts here too. Obviously if you're going to a movie called The Avengers for a character study you're going to the wrong movie (and you need to lay off the artsy movies too, as they're clearly doing serious stuff to your brain), but for the type of movie it is, it's done supremely well. Each character is unique in their own right- I've already mentioned the eponymous superheroes, but Black Widow is one sexy and fun character that's hard not to love. Her action scenes are just incredible and her backstory, while thankfully kept to a minimum is interesting as hell. Hawkeye is stone cold and scary in the first half when  possessed by Loki, then is cool and badass near the end when he resides to kick some Loki butt.The movie is also one of the funniest movies I've ever seen thanks to lots of clever, Whedonian humour and appropriately placed Comic book style exaggeration. The scene where Hulk smashes Loki around like a rag doll made me laugh harder than anything in 21 Jump Street and any other comedy this year. And the scene where Hulk sucker punches Thor!The performances are amazing as well. Pure commitment from all involved, with Downey Jr., Evans and Hemsworth, as well as Johannson, Smulders, Jackson, Hiddleston and Renner giving amazing performances all, but Ruffalo is the real surprise here. He brought something new to the table here as Hulk- every line he spoke sounded like he was trying hard to hold back his inner monster and boy was it chilling. His monologue about how he tried committing suicide was delivered very chillingly beautifully. He was the biggest surprise and got everything about the Hulk perfect. Props to Ruffalo for FINALLY getting The Hulk exactly right!!!I'm going to conclude my review with one more little piece of praise. Whedon is my favourite TV writer And he's managed to make me proud to be a comic book nerd. Justice was done to the best superheroes ever and I can tell superhero movies are going to not be the same ever again. A big thanks to Ll involved for the commitment and true dedication to making ths movie possible, and the great success it was. I've seen this movie twice already and I can't wait to see it again and again. Now I've only got two more words to say: AVENGERS ASSEMBLE!
summary: If you didn't even remotely enjoy this movie, there is "some assembly required" on your brain

reviewText: Hollywood did an amazing job with this movie! Even those who aren't into Marvel and superheroes will enjoy it. They took time to develop the characters (in case you hadn't seen the earlier solo movies.) My only complaint is that they didn't have Hawkeye included as much as I would have liked. :-/ But other than that, they had great visuals, so awesome action scenes, and lots of humor (can you say "Tony Stark"?) :-D It was surprisingly clean...I was very impressed. Out of all the Marvel movies, this is the best! Now I just hope they come out with a solo movie for Hawkeye and Black Widow. I'll be looking forward to seeing Captain America 2, Thor 2, Iron Man 3, and Avengers 2. (ALL of which they ARE coming out with, if you didn't already know that!!)Here's some statistics: (from [...]) They made $200.3 million in JUST THREE days to become the biggest opening weekend of all time. Before it had been in theaters even a week, globally it had produced over $700 million!Here are the dates for the future Marvel movies!! =) Can't wait!Captain America 2: April 4, 2014!Thor 2: November 15, 2013Iron Man 3: May 3, 2013Avengers 2: Already in development. Expect to see in a theater near you sometime in the no-so-far-off future!Black Widow and Hawkeye solo movies also EXPECTED to come soon! :-)BE SURE TO WATCH IT ALL THE WAY THROUGH THE CREDITS!!! Very important! (Unfortunately, I did not. YouTube saved me.)To sum: There is some brief mild language. Violent content. Action-packed. Very exciting. Impossible to feel sleepy or bored when watching the Avengers. A must-see! :-) So what are you waiting for? It's definitely the best movie of the year so far, IMO.But of course they haven't come out with The Hobbit yet. :)
summary: The Avengers: Best Yet! Can't wait for Avengers 2!

reviewText: I remember being so amped to see this flick in theaters. I let my son miss school so we could see it ASAP on opening day! It was awesome!!! Needless to say, we we're looking forward to getting this on Blu-ray. I just ordered & recieved this Blu-ray(2 disc version)off of amazon. I'm not going to go into details about the film...Cause I would say a vast majority of people reading this has seen this. What I will bring up is things about the Blu-ray. The product comes with a slip cover to put over the case. The slip is well designed, with sharp imagery,vibrant color,and has a texture to it so you can feel the outline of the characters,ect.. on the slip. This set comes with both a Blu-ray & DVD disc. You also get instructions on how to sync the movie to your ipad,ipod,ect...to play on it, while it's playing in your Blu-ray player. You'll need to get an app to do that (go figure). This feature in my opinion isn't really necessary. But some people may like that....The quality of the DVD is good (especially on LCD's,Plasma,& LED). The sound is good and will be awesome if you have a surround sound set up! It's really sharp picture and crisp sound if you play the DVD in a Blu-ray player with HDMI hook-up 7 surround sound. The Blu-ray disc is of course better quality. But in all honesty, if you have a newer TV w/ Blu-ray player.HDMI, and surround sound, it's great either way (and damn near identical). I had seen this film in 3D upon it's theatrical opening day. And so I was looking forward to watching it in 2D too! I was great!!!! I've been a big fan of super heroes, their comics,toys,cartoons,ect...since I was a kid. So because of that reason I won't say this flick is for everyone. However, I know many people which haven't been into any type of comic book/super heroes. And they have really enjoyed some of the Marvel films that have been released (especially this)!!! I do definetly recommend this Blu-ray set to anyone that does follow comic book characters on all levels (comics,TV,film,ect..).
summary: Great Adventure in a great Blu-ray format!!!!!

reviewText: When I first heard that they were working on an Avengers movie, a crossover of several Marvel movie characters, I was skeptical.  I really didn't know what to think, but after having seen some of the Marvel movies, my expectations were low.Boy was I wrong.This movie was awesome.  The actors fit their respective parts very well; the visuals are stunning, but are not a lame excuse to gloss over the story being told.What I liked about it was that the heroes all have their own agendas, their own reasons for being involved, and as a result, there is conflict in the group from the very beginning.  You believe that their battles and arguments with each other have real genuine weight as each of them is trying to follow their own path.  As Bruce Banner notes, in the beginning, they are not a team, but rather a volatile chemical mixture, a time bomb.And yet, when the earth really needs them, they don't merely set aside their differences for the sake of the greater good; they actually become a real team.I especially like that, when the Hulk first shows up, he is downright dangerous, a complete monster, not a good guy at all.I am amazed at how many scenes I saw in this movie that could have been very melodramatic, but were somewhat downplayed.  I liked this, because it made them all the more believable as characters, rather than comic book cliches.Were there some weaknesses to the movie?  Yes.  For one thing, I felt that there really needed to be more development for Captain America, at least in the beginning.  This is a man almost 3/4 of a century beyond his time, and yet we see very little of him trying to adjust to his new life.  There's some in the deleted scenes, and I realize some had to be cut for time, but still, I would have liked to have seen Cap having to deal with more future shock.Second, the story really isn't all that original.  It's the old cliche "bad guy trying to take over the world" ("OF COURSE!" - M. Bison), mixed with an alien invasion.  But, even so, it still works.  It's not The Lord of the Rings or The Odyssey, but it doesn't need to be.Third, I really felt Natasha needed a Russian accent.  Given that she was born in Russia, was a Russian spy for most of her early career, and still does a lot of her work in Russia, it would have helped to sell her past a bit better.Overall, this is one fun movie to watch.  I have to say, this is one of my favorite superhero movies of all times.

reviewText: Due to the most convoluted POS redemption system possible, getting the digital album and digital comic book posed more of a challenge than expected. However getting the digital copy of the movie was easy thanks to iTunes (why can't other companies be this easy to work with?). After you get through all the BS, then you still need to download a Marvel app to read the digital comic book (why couldn't I just get a simple PDF download?)Other than that, this is a great film with great extras. You get both the 3D and 2D versions of the blu-ray, as well as the DVD. Plus a digital copy for use with either Apple or Google products (iTunes/iOS or Android). The digital album is all MP3s at 312-319 kbps (VBR). Although a constant bit rate would be better than variable, it's still a pretty decent bit rate.
summary: Great set of features, poor redemption system

reviewText: The Avengers does everything you want a movie to do... entertain for each second we're watching!  Each Super Hero stays true to their character, and watching the Hulk have a fit is just so much fun!!  The plot is good (as far as aliens are attacking us again can be), but even Tony Stark takes a little poke at the plot, and so all is forgiven!  Brilliant acting, great CG, wonderful script; yes, I would recommend this to anyone who ever wanted to see a good flick.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Earth's Mightiest Heroes unite in the crowd-pleasing superhero blockbuster The Avengers. The rogue asgardian Loki (Tom Hiddleston) has stolen the Tessaract cube and plans to use its limitless power to launch a massive invasion upon the world and subjugate all mankind. In response to this imminent threat, Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson), director of S.H.I.E.L.D., reactivates the Avenger Initiative that brings together Tony Stark / Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), Steve Rogers / Captain America (Chris Evans), Thor (Chris Hemsworth) and Bruce Banner / the Hulk (Mark Ruffalo). The Avengers is a rousing action-packed summer movie that lives up to its tremendous hype. Director Joss Whedon (Serenity) manages to create a well-structured thrill ride with enough fanboy enthusiasm to make it one of the most entertaining comic book movies to ever hit the big screen. The Avengers delivers some spectacular visual effects and great action scenes that culminates to a thrilling battle sequence on and above the streets of New York City. The all-star cast also includes Scarlett Johanson, Jeremy Renner, Clark Gregg, Cobbie Smulders and Stellan Skarsgard.If you were worried that the Blu-Ray release of The Avengers wouldn't live up to your expectation, the you'll be pleased that this is a must-have for your Blu-Ray collection. The superhero blockbuster is presented in 1.78:1 widescreen format. The HD transfer is wonderfully detailed and sharp, and its DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 delivers an astounding home theater experience. Its special features includes an audio commentary by director Joss Whedon, the video short "Item 47", a 4-minute gag reel, 15 minutes of deleted end extended scenes, 2 behind-the-scene featurettes (A Visual Journey & Assembling the Ultimate Team) and the Soundgarden Music Video "Live to Rise". Overall, The Avengers scores a highly recommended "A".

reviewText: For a movie producer to make many movies about heros who have character to display that's something worthwhile for our youths to watch (within the context of a fun story) and then connect them all together within another story that includes all their character traits is, I think, genius. All the movies leading up to this final tale where they all contribute their own idiosyncracies for the good of all were fun along the way and certainly not disappointing in this final tale....AND...this final new twist of putting some candid shots at the end of the credits that either announces the next story or shows a candid shot of the group in their human form doing something they mentioned in the movie, is just another bit of creative genius....I loved it...it just keeps getting better and better. Iron Man is my favorite with Captain America as a close second....

The only area I wasn't upset with, but more puzzled was the special features such as the trailers and deleted items were repeated under several categories. Likewise the screen control in selecting the special features was not always reliable. That wasn't my Blue ray player as some other Blue Ray operate fine. I did like the fact that it actually displayed on the screen you can use the top menu button to skip around the trailers.

reviewText: The evil brother of Thor opens up a portal allowing alien beings up to no good to wreak havoc upon humankind. A group of superheroes is formed in order to save the planet as we know it. This is the culmination of a series of superhero films and this one features all the main characters, bringing them together, allowing them to use their unique gifts in order to dispose of the bad guys. Bringing all of these alpha males (and one female) together does present its problems, as they at times are competing with each other. However, they are able to put aside any differences and work together for the common good. There are also a few laughs, but the highlights of this one are the spectacular visuals. This is a visually stimulating film that is a solid start to the summer movie season.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: The Avengers is out on DVD and Blu-ray and wow was it ever well-worth the wait. I watched the 3D version first thing and it just blew me away with how fantastic it looks on my home setup. I saw it in the theater in 3D on opening weekend and it looked pretty good but at home it just looks so much better. Get the 3D version if you can, it is fantastic.The movie itself is really great also and does not disappoint in the least. It is a very worthy addition to the Marvel Movie Universe, along with the Iron man, Thor, and Captain America movies. To have all of these great actors and superheroes all on the screen together in the very same movie is just a real treat and this was definitely a summer blockbuster movie that truly lived up to the hype and then some. The action scenes are plentiful and intense, the special effects are jaw-dropping and stunning, and the story is really good too with some good revelations and some unexpected twists and turns. I cannot wait to see what they do in the sequel to this one, it is going to be a very tough act to follow, that's for sure.I rate it HS for HULK SMASHTASTIC.
summary: A Super Duper Slam Bang Superhero Smackdown!

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: In Joss Whedon‘s “The Avengers,” three Marvel Comics superheroes - Iron Man (Robert Downey, Jr.), Captain America (Chris Evans) and The Hulk (Mark Ruffalo) - are recruited by S.H.I.E.L.D. to do battle against Loki (Tom Hiddleston), the brother of Thor (Chris Hemsworth), who has come to Earth with an alien army to claim the world for his own. But can three such distinctly talented yet strong-willed individuals put aside their differences and egos long enough to function as a team - as the Avengers - to save the planet?There’s no question that gathering three classic superheroes into a single film was a stroke of marketing genius, as well as a considerable treat for fans. The movie itself is lively, loud, and epic in scale with just enough character delineation to keep us engaged on a human level. Plus, it culminates in a spectacular jamboree of destruction in New York City that turns into a veritable Valhalla for CGI aficionados.All the above-mentioned actors enter into the spirit of the enterprise, as do Scarlett Johansson, Jeremy Renner, Clark Gregg, Samuel L. Jackson, Gwyneth Paltrow, Powers Boothe, Jenny Agutter, and Harry Dean Stanton as the pure humans in the cast.Good fun.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: ....And what fun it is.*Spoilers Ahead*Marvel's "The Avengers" is an expertly-crafted movie that makes 2 1/2 hours fly by like....well....I don't really know...SOMETHING FAST. My thoughts on seeing this movie--the first time (yes, you WILL go to see this more than once)--were: "This was just as good as 'The Dark Knight'....how is THAT even possible?" Well...consider first that Marvel has always had the best storylines, and the know-how to mix all of their characters' comic books together into one, all-encompassing storyline. Then, consider they decided to apply said formula to their movies. Third, they went out and expertly casted the parts.How could this NOT be good?Who else but Robert Downey, Jr could be a multi-billionaire, techno-wizard, armor-wearing snark-artist? Acts like he doesn't care, but is willing to sacrifice his life to save New York.Chris Evans is Captain America. A 1940s guy living in the present day....brings "a little old-fashioned" to the role and shows old-fashionedness isn't cheesy, it just depends on how it is presented. It is presented very well, with Evans being the heart and soul (not to mention team leader) of The Avengers--by the way: love the shot, at the movie's end, of him on his motorcycle riding off into the sunset.Mark Ruffalo, (great casting here; now I feel the Hulk movie franchise finally has hope) channels Bill Bixby in his performance (good idea!) but adds a "Hulk-sized" portion of world-weariness to his character...his over-the-shoulder "I'm always angry" is one of my favorite moments in an entire movie of favorite moments. And....The Hulk gets two more "Hulk-sized" moments that totally bring the house down.Oh, nice touch having Lou Ferrigno voice the Hulk.Chris Hemsworth as Thor is the only character in the movie whom I feel was under-utilized. No fault of the actor's; he does a great job with what he is given....and DOES have his moments ("He's adopted")....I just felt they didn't give him as much as they did the other three leads.Rounding out The Avengers are Scarlett Johansson and Jeremy Renner as the assassin/couple: Black Widow (Natasha Romanoff) and Hawkeye. Ms. Johansson is a master interrogator (albeit by making use of quite unorthodox means). Hawkeye is the steely-cool expert marksman--I had my doubts as to how an archer could work in such a high-energy movie. It works.The Avengers are put together by SHIELD: Samuel L. Jackson as Nick Fury (need I say more?); Clark Gregg (Agent Phil Coulson, and very funny in the role); Colbie Smulders (Agent Maria Hill--doesn't get nearly enough screen time) and Stellan Starsgard.Loki is portrayed by Tom Hiddleston; whom, for a character thinking of himself as a god, brings some amusing vunerability to the character: His embarrassment at being unable to kill/brainwash Tony Stark: "This usually works."; or, "If it's all the same to you, I'll have that drink now."I was initially skeptical about this movie. I didn't think Loki was the best choice for a screen villain. Er, was I wrong....this tale of an immortal/meglomaniac/demigod/god-wannabe who enlists an alien race to help him conquer Earth (Question: if Loki *really* was a god, why would he need alien help?) made for some great popcorn, big-tent, summer viewing.....My other initial fear was that this wasn't going to be "The Avengers" as much as it would be "Iron Man and Friends".Thankfully, I was wrong again.To sum up: The Avengers is cinematic excellence. Many have complained about it being too long--and, the first 20 minutes or so setting up the story *do* take a moment....but once "Marvel's The Avengers" splashes across the screen: The movie takes off and never looks back. It is packed with great moments and memorable lines/one-liners. The action sequences are the best I've ever seen and it all looks real. Seems I read somewhere online the battle in New York would have done (in reality) 39 billion dollars' worth of damage. You WILL believe it.Oh, one last thing: sit through ALL of the credits.Thank you, Joss Whedon and co.Please go all-out on the blu-ray release. Please.QuotesNatasha: "I'd sit this one out, Cap."Captain America: "I don't see how I can."Natasha: "These guys (Thor and Loki) come from legend. They're basically gods."Cap: "There's only one God, ma'am. And I'm pretty sure he isn't dressed like that."Cap: "Dr. Banner, now might be a good time for you to get angry."Dr. Banner: "That's my secret, Captain." (looks back over his shoulder at Cap) "I'm always angry."Loki: (embarrassed) "This usually works."Tony Stark: "Well, you know, performance issues...""The Avengers"PG-13 for language (non-harsh) and violence; no gore or sex to be found, parents.Marvel Studios in association with Paramount PicturesDirected by Joss Whedon**********UPDATE: Oct. 2, 2012**********Ok, the Blu-Ray/DVD has finally arrived, here is what you get:DISC 1*Blu-Ray Feature Film in 3D  (3D viewing requires Blu-Ray 3D player, 3D capable display and 3D glassesDISC 2*Blu-Ray Feature Film*An original SHORT: "Item 47". I won't give the story away, but it could have been called, "Fun at the gas pump".*FEATURETTE: "A Visual Journey". Documentary about the film's look, ranging from the set-building and visual effects all the way through to the film's cinematography, too.*Marvel's First Ever Gag Reel:  The outtakes are presented are entertaining enough, but the whole featurette is barely five minutes long. I wish it were a half-hour in length--at the least.*Deleted Scenes: and, a LOT of them. One very interesting one concerning a present-day Captain America *and* his love interest from "Captain America-The First Avenger". I had heard a rumor these deleted scenes WOULD BE INSERTED SEAMLESSLY  into the original movie, giving us a new, special edition version....said rumor was wrong.*Soundgarden Music Video: :Live To Rise".*The Avengers Initiative: A Marvel Second Screen Experience. This works on your iphone, ipad or laptop. Once enabled, it "breaks you into" S.H.I.E.L.D.'s data base and allows you to explore:1) Marvel's cinematic history2) The comic book history of The Avengers3) Avenger personnel files and originsDISC 3*DVD Feature Film*Audio Commentary (full-length) with director Joss Whedon. I've listened to it--very well done.*Featurette--Assembling The Ultimate Team: the movie casting process, what the actor's bring to their roles, character interactions, etc, etc.DISC 4*Digital Copy (for Mac and PC)*Digital Album1)  Soundgarden-Live To Rise2)  Shinedown-I'm Alive3)  Rise Against-Dirt And Roses4)  Papa Roach-Even If I Could5)  Black Veil Brides-Unbroken6)  Scott Weiland-Breathe7)  Redlight King-Comeback8)  Bush-Into The Blue9)  Evanescence-A New Way To Bleed (Photek Remix)10) Pusher Jones-Count Me Out11) Buckcherry-Wherever I Go12) Five Finger Death Punch-From Out Of Nowhere13) Cherri Bomb-Shake The GroundFINALLY*Technical Specifications:Blu-Ray: 1080p High Definition Widescreen (1.78:1) * Audio: English 7.1 DTS-HD MA, English DVS 2.0 Dolby Digital, 7.1 DTS-HDHR French, Spanish 5.1 Dolby Digital Language Tracks * Subtitles: English SDH, French and SpanishDVD:  Widescreen (1.78:1) Aspect Ratio * Audio: English, French, Spanish 5.1 Dolby Digital, English DVS 2.0 Dolby Digital Language Tracks * Subtitles: English SDH, French and Spanish (Applies To Film Content Only)Film's RUN TIME is 143 Minutes (Approx.)Avengers.Marvel.com****ALL SPECS AND RELATED INFO ARE TAKEN FROM THE BLU-RAY/DVD PACKAGING--WHICH FEATURES A NICE (DARE I SAY, "COLLECTIBLE?") HOLOGRAM OF ONE OF THE MOVIE'S (FULL TEAM ASSEMBLED) POSTERS ON THE FRONT.Thank you again for reading.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: This is a fun romp with an impossible group of super heroes all gleaned from other action movies and improbably jammed together to be pitted against an incredibly powerful demi-god rivalI.  But hold on, it's Josh Whedon ya'll.  No one directs science fiction like Whedon does.  Here is all the heart, all the intergroup rivallry, all the humanity (well as much humanity as you can give super heroes anyway) and all the action you can pack into a movie like this.  This is not "Serenity" or "Buffy The Vampire Slayer", but it is "The Avengers" done in about the best way possible.  "The Avengers" will appeal to the 12 year old in your heart but not leave you with that funny aftertase that the other syrupy action hero movies do.  All the heros are played by the original actors from the movies that they individually starred in - that had to be a directors nightmare.  Each actor, especially Robert Downey Jr., was a star in their own right, with a currently living franchise and yet they all had this enormous shared bill.  Yikes!  JUST WATCH THIS MOVIE FOR THAT REASON ALONE.  Whedon always has something to teach in his films and if anything is to be learned from this one it's that this can be done.  Watch it.  But get your popcorn first.  You won't want to stop once you get started.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I have not watched the dvd that came with this yet but the Blu-Ray and 3D Blu-Ray are great and play without issue.  I bought this version because I have a TV that does 3D and it is only the second 3D title that I have purchased.  The first was just because I could - bought it at the same time as my tv.  This one was just because it was The Avengers so why not?  As for the complaints of most...the information about what's included on the DVD and Blu-Ray discs is available.  So is it really anyone else's fault that they didn't get what they wanted out of the product they bought?  As for the people with problems playing it, it's more common for it to be a problem with their hardware or a dirty disc.  I don't have a top-of-the-line blu-ray player but I also know not to expect the same results from a cheap one as a more expensive one.  They're not there yet.  You can get a cheap dvd player that works fine.  You still can't really get a cheap blu-ray player that works fine.  It's unfortunate but it's true.  The same can be said for early-adopters.  People who have had blu-ray players for years where subtle differences that have evolved as the technology matured have had to watch their expensive players age-out already.  But that's the price of being an early adopter.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I resisted seeing this movie in the theaters because I have a great 3D TV and figured I could wait. In fact, I'm glad I did. The movie is spectacular and the special effects come through brillantly on my TV. One thing I am really excited about is the movie is not shown in letter box format. It fills the entire screen of my widescreen TV, which is just fantastic. The sound is also great. Unlike some movies where the sound effects are louder than the actually dialouge, you can hear everything perfect in this movie and there isn't a need to turn it down when the action starts. It's very even and smooth, which is a plus. The 3D is also surprisingly good. If you have a 3D TV this is one movie you'll want to spend the extra money for.My only real complaint is the actual packaging. The movies and special features are loaded on top of each other, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but you'd think they could have at least sprung for better packing. Aside from that, this is definitely worth the investment.
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Love, love, love this movie! All my favorite Marvel heroes assembled in one place? Hell yes! The Blu-Ray presentation looks and sounds amazing. I haven't had time to go through all the bonus materials, but it appears there's plenty to keep a nerd like myself occupied.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: I can't really say anything negative or critical about The Avengers, but I sure can't give it more than 3 stars.  Yes, it was a special effects extravaganza. It was "fun" to watch most of the time. It was satisfying in many ways.  BUT, it lasted WAY too long. Two hours and twenty minutes is too dang long to sit through anything; The Avengers could have used a ruthless editing of at least 45 minutes of film. I caught myself wondering, "Will this thing ever end?"I couldn't figure out Scarlett Johansson's role in the scheme of things. What exactly was her "super-power" other than her ability to kick butt?  Was her casting just a fulfillment of a female part?  Neither Johansson nor her character worked in this film.Capt. America and Thor: Terrible actors. Painful to watch.Robert Downey, Jr./Ironman stole the show. Hawkeye was pretty awesome too.  And casting Ruffalo as the Hulk rather than Edward Norton was a smart move.Maybe I was tired and The Avengers was too much stimuli late in the evening. Hell, maybe I'm getting too old for this stuff. I mean, almost 700 Amazon reviewers can't be wrong, right?  All I know is, The Avengers just didn't grab me as I had hoped, and I was ready to cut it off after 90 minutes.
summary: Amazing effects but needs editing for time

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewerName: Scotman's Film & Book Reviews "Film & Book Re...
reviewText: AssemblageThere have been many reviews written about The Avengers, the latest Marvel Comics/Disney film for 2012's first summer blockbuster!The film is really a sequel to several other films and though the film does a good job of catching up the audience, really seeing the other films first would really help - Hulk, Captain America, Iron Man and Thor.The film is part science fiction alien invasion, part team-making, part knock down drag out fights with Thor, Captain America, Iron Man and Hulk beating each other up, and the non-powered characters with issues of their own - Black Widow, who fakes being helpless to gather intel and Hawkeye, who has worked with B.W. on many occasions (this part of the film was a weakness - there was not enough expository reveal regarding their relationship - minor quibble).The best part of the film really is the writing.  I've always liked Josh Whedon's television programming from Buffy to Angel to Firefly to Dollhouse.  The snappy writing and silly banter was real, not forced.  The characters were real, too!Captain America, a man out of time.  I saw the first film and clearly Avengers was a sequel to Cap.  What happened after the big freeze?  What's his relationship with Nick Fury and SHIELD?Thor - his film ended with a Jane Foster crush and a beat-down by a very large villain, as well as an apparent loss into space by Loki.  Again, a sequel of sorts - Thor as I have imagined him, he is torn between a brother who kills indiscriminately (Thor:  "Loki's my brother."  Widow:  "He's killed 80 people."  Thor:  "He's adopted!") and has the sly deceptive character that the actor brings out so well.Philosophy:  Yeah, always some of that.  Loki prefers to think of Freedom as an aberration, that mankind was made to be ruled by strong rulers and gods.  Great scene of an old man, no doubt a Holocaust survivor, at the Stuttgart, Germany orchestra scene, where the man stands up against Loki - and Cap makes an appearance, makes a speech alluding to the Nazis, before beating up on Loki.Heroes and Villains:  As with other Marvel characters, you have to have some heroes with something to hide, some inner agenda.  SHIELD has secrets - no spoilers - and Cap and the rest smell something bad.Hulk/Bruce Banner - We enter his life in a similar way to the second Hulk movie - hiding out in a foreign country, getting waylaid to help and ends up Hulking out!  A lot of the second half is a Hulk/Thor fest that is really fun to watch.Scripts:  The writing is very much Marvel, you really get the feeling that Stan Lee wrote it!  The Avengers are planning out their next move as the alien invasion is in progress - Captain America is calling the shots - he turns to Hulk and says "Hulk?  Smash!"  -- Hulk:  Big grin, Rarrh!  Great scene.Bottom Line:  I could go on and on about the great effects, great development and characterization, fast paced action.  The film had a proper balance of effects, fan-style gimmees, and enough humor to entice a wider audience - much better than Thor, Ironman 1, 2, 3 or Hulk (2008) and Captain America: First Avenger for sure == and I loved those films.Tip:  There are TWO after-credit scenes - learn the true meaning of "Shawarma."Cast:Robert Downey Jr. Tony Stark / Iron ManChris Evans  Steve Rogers / Captain AmericaMark Ruffalo  Bruce Banner / The HulkChris Hemsworth  ThorScarlett Johansson  Natasha Romanoff / Black WidowJeremy Renner  Clint Barton / HawkeyeTom Hiddleston  Loki
summary: Avengers -- Sequel to Four Films!  Great Job!
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: OK, let's get the criticisms out of the way.Not enough of Jeremy Renner's Clint Barton/Hawkeye.If you're a guy, not enough of Cobie Smulders' Maria Hill (My goodness, that catsuit...it actually has made me pay more attention to "How I Met Your Mother"...).Got it??!?  Because those are about the ONLY complaints there are here.Simply put--the climax of Marvel Studios' Phase I Series got it right.  But honestly, the whole series--the two Iron Man movies, The Incredible Hulk, Thor, and Captain America: The First Avenger--set a great path to this movie.  It stayed true to the essence of the Marvel Universe, which has always dealt with their heroes and their character quirks--humanized their super-humans.  This movie threw together the crew and their quirks--Tony Stark and his general lack of humility, Thor and his imperiousness, Steve Rogers dealing with being out of his time, Bruce Banner and his issues of anger management,and Nick Fury, simultaneously manipulating and cajoling the different individuals to work together.Yet, because Joss Whedon was the writer/director, I wasn't very surprised to see that Joss drew liberally from his "Buffy The Vampire Slayer" years, especially when it came to the expansion of Scarlett Johannsen's Natasha Romanoff from where she was in "Iron Man II".  The Black Widow ends up being much more complicated, world weary and vulnerable--giving much depth to her thoughts about having "red on her ledger", and the point that she is truly fearful of Dr. Banner's Other Self.  But ScarJo also ends up with those brilliant throwaway lines during the battle for New York that were also so typically Whedon.Performance-wise, no one slacks off.  Robert Downey Jr. still embodies all of Tony Stark's brio and ego.  Chris Evans gives that sense of traditional heroism and loneliness to Steve Rogers.  Chris Hemsworth tones down Thor a little from the movie, but the "he's adopted" line--which caused a bit of a minor stir after the release--is timed out perfectly.  Samuel L. Jackson finally sees expanded time in this series as Nick Fury.  Much has been made of Mark Ruffalo's turn as Banner, and it's pitch-perfect.  Mark plays Banner with a little bit of a smile, but certainly knowing what lies beneath himself.  Clark Gregg's Phil Coulson cannot be forgotten--as we've seen in the "Marvel One-Shot" episodes that have accompanied the Blu-Ray/DVD releases, Coulson has been a straight man for many of the hijinks of both SHIELD and the heroes.  Seeing him suddenly turn into the gushing fanboy of Captain America ends up being rather charming.The show-stealer in all this--and again, given the director this shouldn't be much of a surprise--is Tom Hiddleston's Loki.  Again, this goes back to the "Buffyverse" with Whedon.  Frequently, the "Big Bad" during the seven seasons that series ran was an over-the-top destroyer with a smirk.  Hiddleston played Loki in "Thor" more as an Agent Provocateur in Kenneth Branagh's eyes.  Whedon takes Loki to the level of Angelus or the Mayor of Sunnydale...but also mixes in some Wile E. Coyote, especially in the "Destruction of Manhattan"--Loki catching Hawkeye's arrow as if it wasn't a big deal, only to have the arrow expode, knocking Loki off the Skycycle only to be caught by the Hulk, leading to Loki's verbal assault, leading to...well--the best scene of all the summer pictures...Overall--Marvel Studios and Paramount did right with Phase 1, and the culmination is on the short list of The Most Entertaining Movies of 2012.  Certainly, "The Avengers" is also in the room as being The Most Fun Superhero Movie Ever.So, let Phase II begin....HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Let me start by stating that I am a Joss Whedon fan.  His firefly series was excellent.  I guess everyone has a bad day.  His story line for this movie is uninspired.  The writing is below the level of most comic books.  Most of the actors seemed to be cashing a pay check.  Scarlett Johansson was miscast.  A true 100 pound imposter.  And she and Mark Ruffalo as Dr. Banner mumble their lines.  There is a spark when Robert Downey, Jr. is on the screen.  Scenes like the fight between Thor and Iron Man were illogical and contrived.  Thor is made to look like more of a stupid brute than Hulk.  Iron Man, Captain America and Thor are better films.  I hate saying that because I wanted to liike this film a lot.  I am not sorry I watched this film, but I am sorry I purchased the DVD.  I hope Whedon gets back on his game for the inevitable sequel.

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: When Joss Whedon came on board to helm "The Avengers," I knew that this film was not only in good hands, but that something wondrous would come of it.  Having been the creator, writer, director, and producer of some of the best TV shows in recent years (Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Angel, and Firefly), I was familiar enough with his work to know that the story, dialogue, and characterization would all be well done.  Whedon is a master at balancing all of these things, and not allowing special effects to overshadow the story.Marvel did a very smart thing leading up to The Avengers.  Rather than spending time trying to explain the origins and backgrounds of these six characters, this was already taken care of in their subsequent films leading up to this film.  At nearly two and a half hours, the story wouldn't have to suffer distractions of an hour-long origin introduction.  In other words, they could just jump right in!  And, boy, does The Avengers jump right in!This is easily, in my view, the best superhero team film done yet.  The only thing that matches it is the animated TV series, "The Justice League."A crisis is threatening the planet.  It is a threat that no one superhero can deal with on his/her own.  And so, Nick Fury the Director of SHIELD (and wonderfully played by Samuel L. Jackson) has arranged to assemble a group of superheroes to deal with the crisis.  However, the question becomes, can these heroes put aside their egos and differences in order to work together?  This is the question that the film spends half of the time dealing with.Loki is the principal villain in this film, and Tom Hiddleston plays him superbly with a type of cunning and pleasure that Loki is renowned for.  He has made a bargain with beings from another dimension, to help him conquer Earth.  He holds the Cosmic Cube (Tesseract Cube), a source of nearly unlimited power.  Loki agrees to give these beings the cube in exchange for help in his conquest.The members of the Avengers do not come together easily.  We are treated to the first great battle of the film.  Iron Man vs. Thor.  The other thing that makes this film so much fun is that in addition to watching the Avengers fight the villains, we also get to see them fight each other!  Anyone who is a fan of superheros, comic books, or both, hold the eternal debate: who is stronger?  Who can beat whom?  Message boards are littered with people arguing about these things.  And while the film doesn't necessarily answer these questions outright (and the comics rarely do either), it is still fun to watch!  Later on, the ante is "upped" when we get to see the two juggernauts of the team go head-to-head: Thor vs. Hulk.When all differences are put aside, and the members of the Avengers realize that they must work together, then we see what happens through the power of unity.All of the actors fit their roles beautifully.  What can be said of Robert Downey Jr. that hasn't already been said?  Whedon's script gives him a chance to shine even brighter than he has in previous films.  Stark must answer the ultimate question for himself: is he willing to give everything of himself to save humanity?Chris Evans is a good Captain America.  In the comics, Cap is the natural leader of the team, and he's always giving strategical orders to the members.  He commands a presence, that regardless of his lack of real power, is highly respected.  I hope to see more of this quality in the next film.Another standout for me is Scarlett Johannson as the Black Widow.  As the only female member of the team, she has a covert intelligence that is sorely needed on the team.  Johannson plays Natasha with a quiet cunning.The final battle scene, which takes up nearly a full hour of the movie, is a battle of epic proportions.  We see the Avengers fighting an endless sea of Loki's minions in the heart of New York.  The battle is superbly done, and it never detracts or overshadows the story.  The build-up to this point gives the film epic climax.The Avengers is just a ton of fun.  But it is a far more complex and deep film than people may realize.  Whedon never loses sight of the human element, which again, is so characteristic of his other heroes like Buffy and Angel; that it isn't so much what you do, but who you are while you're doing it; that there is a lot more to being a hero than simply fighting the bad guys.This epic film will be a fan favorite for a long time to come, and we can only hope that the second entry will be as good as this one was.  And if you want a sneak-peek at the villain for the next installment, then don't turn the film off during the credits!  Nearly everyone in the theater gasped and cheered when they saw who it was!
summary: The Pinnacle Superhero Team Film To Date!

reviewText: This isn't the type of movie I'd want to go see in a theater, but it was Mother's Day and my mother has wanted to see this movie for two weeks so she got her wish. The beginning of the movie was painfully boring and I (who usually avoids food concession stands) grabbed a pink lemonade to stay awake. Because I'm not usually into superheroes I thought, "Maybe it's just me," but when I glanced over at my mother (who LOVES this kind of stuff) falling asleep I knew something was wrong. This movie did not pick up until Richard Downey Jr. came on the scene as Iron Man (and I own both "Iron Man" movies solely because he was SO good at blending sarcasm, humor, action, a great story line and the usual superhero come-to-our-rescue plot together). That's when I sat up and paid attention. Then Iron Man started messing with The Hulk, another character I used to get into as a kid. That's when I stopped daydreaming.I shrugged through Captain America's heroism because it seemed forced like a Ken doll. Black Widow didn't do it for me, and the film spent entirely too much time showing the back of her costume or her glaring at someone. Again, too forced. I saw the movie "Thor" and neither Thor or Loki were interesting to me, although I did find Idris Elba's character Heimdall pretty cool. Unfortunately Heimdall wasn't in this film, which was a disappointment.But right when I was all set to go to the bowling alley next door and let my mother watch the movie alone, the movie picked up speed. The more Downey's Iron Man and Mark Ruffalo's Bruce Banner (The Hulk) were on the screen, the less I slumped in my seat. And when Bruce Banner turned into The Hulk, I FINALLY got into the film. Watching superhero characters save the day just doesn't do it for me. It's the actors and the dialogue that'll make me cheer for those superheroes, and The Hulk and Iron Man were as funny in their costumes as they were outside of them. There were moments when I (and the huge audience surrounding me) laughed out loud at The Hulk's antics. Those saved this film.Would I buy it? No. But I'm definitely looking forward to seeing "Iron Man 3" as soon as it releases and would be interested in "The Hulk" movie (if there ever is one).
summary: Started off dreadfully slow but then picked up
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Not much more can be said about this movie than has already been said about it.  The movie is a comic book come to life, perhaps the first of its kind.  Marvel has spent the past 4 years developling their Cinematic Universe, resulting in this masterpiece that recently even came under fire from Christopher Nolan's cinematographer (not understanding all that, but it was disregarded).  What started as mentions of SHIELD and Captain America's shield in Iron Man in 2008, culminated in a cameo appearance by Nick Fury who actually name-drops The Avengers.  Now, in 2012, we get a team up picture featuring the solo characters from their own franchises:  Iron Man, Hulk, Thor, and Captain America.One liberty taken for this movie was character development, but remember, Marvel developed these characters over the course of 4 years, giving the main characters their own movies to develop character and give the origin stories required to explain who everyone was.  That said, it is strongly recommended that you watch Iron Man, The Incredible Hulk, Iron Man 2, Thor, and Captain America: The First Avenger before you sit down to enjoy this movie.  It will help with your understanding of why the characters are where they are and why they are doing what they are doing.  What results is a witty, action packed movie that fully entertains the entire time.  There are moments that can be nitpicked, such as Thor's appearance, which negates the finale to his own film, and no mention whatsoever of the other hero, War Machine, who was introduced and used by the US government in Iron Man 2 during an alien attack of New York, but those are moments that do not ruin the movie completely.  Memorable scenes you will walk away with are the Hulk's handling of Loki, the team coming together culminating in Captain America's marching orders to each person, and a couple more, now tradmark, post-credits scenes.Of course we were bound to get a mega combo pack, something that came in the form of a Blu-Ray 3D/Blu-Ray/DVD/Digital/Soundtrack (and also a regular combo pack and single DVD and Blu-Ray releases), maybe the first of its kind to have so much together at once.  The special features are actually not as great as you would think or hope, although there is a commentary by writer/director, Joss Whedon.  There is no 'Making Of' feature, outside of a couple short moments discussing the actors and the formation of the team through the course of the 4 year period developing the Marvel Cinematic Universe.  A Marvel One-Shot short film, Item 47, is present, featuring characters from the movie, and set within the MCU, and it does not disappoint.  Also featured are some deleted scenes that, for example, shed light on Captain America's acclamation into present day society.  However, it was briefly mentioned before the release that there may be a Director's Cut of the film, with as much as 30-40 minutes of deleted scenes added in to the movie, but sadly, this is no where to be seen on this giant release.  Does this mean Marvel will double-dip with a further release in the future?  The answer is probably a resounding yes, which is unfortunate for people who bought this thinking it would be the ultimate release.  But, this movie has made loads of money, both from its release in theaters and from the home release, so it goes to stand that it would make even more with a further release of all-new material at some point in the future.  Other highlights include a digital copy (which is curiously not present on either the other Blu-Ray packs or solo Blu-Ray or DVD releases) and the soundtrack download, a cool code that allows you to get the entire soundtrack from online, for free.  This combo is packed to the gill with stuff, just not everything that could have been, or that was even discussed before the final release.That all said, definitely get a combo pack to enjoy the film in either all its Blu-Ray glory, as this movie is fantastic seen on 1080p and with a full audio surround sound transfer.  Despite the shortcomings of the home release, get this movie and share with friends and family, whether they've seen it already or not (and chances are they have seen it), this will only get better with age.  And we'll all be in line again waiting for Marvel to show else they have their sleeve, from a further release of The Avengers on Blu-Ray, all the way to Phase 2 beginning with Iron Man 3 in 2013.
summary: A Modern Achievement in Film & Entertainment
Title: Marvel's: The Avengers

reviewText: Tried to make my 100th for the year a kick-ass one, and boy was it; LOVE this film! When Loki (see 'Thor') strives to bring an army of demons (who, once seen, give new meaning to the word "bad-ass ugly") through a portal to attack earth, Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson) of S.H.I.E.L.D. brings together a band of superheroes - Iron Man, Thor, Hawkeye, Captain America, Black Widow, and one very grudging Incredible Hulk - together to save mankind. Joss Whedon's script blends the seriousness and humor together with near perfection, and the kick-ass finale between the gang and Loki and his butt-ugly mutants in and over New York City is worth watching the film for ALONE. One of my favorites of the year, and a guaranteed MUST-SEE if you haven't seen it already!
summary: One of the best superhero/action films ever, for the final battle ALONE!
